Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Bradenton, Florida," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1971, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Charter. The term "charter" shall mean the charter of the City of Bradenton as printed in Part I, subpart A of this volume. 
    City. The word "city" shall be construed to mean the "City of Bradenton, Florida." 
    City boards, committees, commissions, officers, employees, etc. Whenever reference is made to a board, committee, commission, officer, employee, etc., in this Code, it shall be construed to mean that of the City of Bradenton, Florida. 
    Code. The word "Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Bradenton, Florida. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall not be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be counted. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, Fla. Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 1.090(a). 
    Council or city council. Whenever the words "city council" or "council" are used, they shall be construed to mean the "City Council of the City of Bradenton, Florida." 
    County. The word "county" shall mean the County of Manatee, Florida. 
State Law reference- Boundaries of Manatee County, F.S. § 7.41. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision or section appears requiring the head of a department or some other city official, officer or employee to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty, unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    F.S. Whenever the abbreviation "F.S." is used, it shall refer to the latest edition or supplement of the Florida Statutes. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things as well as to one person or thing and a word importing the plural number may extend and be applied to a single person or thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as defined in this section. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery or open space adjacent thereto and any river or stream. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The word "state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city and it shall also be construed to include a sidewalk or footpath, unless the contrary is expressed or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. 
    Tenant or occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, except where otherwise provided. 
(Code 1971, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions in Florida Statutes, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1971, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-5. - References to chapters or sections. 
    All references in this Code to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Bradenton, Florida, 1971, and of ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-8. - Code does not affect prior offenses, penalties, contracts, rights. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
State Law reference- No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, or any law impairing the obligation of contracts, shall ever be passed, Fla. Const., art. I, § 10. 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for any offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1971, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-10. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred before the effective date of this Code. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issue of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract, right, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument or obligation assumed by the city. 
(3)  Any administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with this Code. 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance. 
(5)  Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(6)  Any appropriation ordinance. 
(7)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes, charges, rates or fees. 
(8)  Any ordinances prescribing through streets, parking and traffic regulations, speed limits, one-way traffic, limitations on load of vehicles or loading zones. 
(9)  Any rezoning ordinance or amendment to the zoning map. 
(10)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city. 
(11)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(12)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(13)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory or any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city. 
(14)  Any ordinance establishing positions, classifying positions, setting salaries of city officers and employees or any personnel regulations, or any ordinance regarding pension or retirement plans, funds or benefits. 
(15)  Any temporary or special ordinances. 
(16)  Any ordinance calling elections or prescribing the manner of conducting the election in accordance with state law. 
(b)  All such ordinances described in subsection (a) of this section are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code and are on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be renumbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from this Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Bradenton, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows:... (set out new provisions in full)." 
(c)  When the city council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature on a subject not then existing in the Code, which the city council desires to incorporate into the Code, a section in substantially the following language shall be made a part of the ordinance: "Section _____. It is the intention of the governing body and it is hereby ordained that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made a part of the Code of Ordinances, City of Bradenton, Florida, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1971, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code and shall also include all amendments to the charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____." The inserted section numbers will indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code; and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-13. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of the court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1971, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-14. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Bradenton to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1971, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-15. - General penalty; continuing violations; violation as public nuisance. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code, or in any ordinance or resolution of the city, or rule or regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared unlawful and no specific penalty is provided for the violation thereof, the violation of any such provision of this Code or of any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties provided in this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or of any ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order of the city or its authorized agents shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the city, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1971, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation for ordinances, F.S. § 162.22.

ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Number and qualifications of councilmen, compensation to be fixed by ordinance, § 7(a); term, residence of councilmen, § 12; election, general powers, duties of city council officers, § 13; council to judge qualifications, election of its members; filling of vacancies, § 14. 
Cross reference- Execution of contracts and deeds of conveyance, § 2-236 et seq.; elections, ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public records act, F.S. ch. 119. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - President of the council. 
    The president of the council shall have such powers as provided in the charter and may fine delinquent members and perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as are usual, customary and required of presiding officers by parliamentary usage. 
(Code 1971, § 2-20) 
Charter reference- Election, general powers and duties of city council officers, § 13. 
Secs. 2-32-2-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES 

Sec. 2-46. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of each member of the city council and the mayor shall be as established in the annual budget which is on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(Code 1971, §§ 2-15, 2-38) 
Sec. 2-47. - Fixed expenses. 
    The mayor and members of city council have budgeted expense allocations authorized in the annual budget in city travel expenses. These fixed expense allocations are not subject to citywide travel expense procedures. The amount budgeted is used to offset day-to-day costs of performing official duties not otherwise budgeted. All other travel by mayor and members of city council will need to be supported by the procedures in article IV, division 3, of this chapter. 
(Code 1971, §§ 2-200, 2-201) 
Cross reference- Traveling expenses, § 2-181 et seq.; business expenses of the city council, § 2-216. 
Secs. 2-48-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Council to hold at least two regular monthly meetings and such special meetings as called by the mayor, § 11. 
State Law reference- Open meetings law, F.S. § 286.011. 

Sec. 2-71. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2618, § 1, adopted February 23, 2000, repealed former section 2-71, which pertained to time of regular meetings, and derived from the Code of 1971, § 2-16. 
Sec. 2-72. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the council shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1971, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-73. - Adjournment. 
    A number of councilmembers not sufficient to form a quorum may meet at regular or duly called special meetings and adjourn from time to time. 
(Code 1971, § 2-19) 
Secs. 2-74-2-95. - Reserved.

State Law reference- Code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; removal procedure for certain board members, F.S. § 112.501. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2628, adopted July 12, 2000, created a community redevelopment agency to be known as the Central Community Redevelopment Agency (CCRA), pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 163.356, Florida Statutes. As this ordinance was not specifically amendatory of the Code, §§ 1-6 of said ordinance were set forth herein, with the approval of the city, as a new Subdivision 2 within this division. 
State Law reference- Community redevelopment authority, F.S. § 163.330 et seq. 

SUBDIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-116. - Designated. 
    The Bradenton Downtown Development Authority as created by Laws of Fla., ch. 74-245, pursuant to this division and F.S. § 163.357(2), is designated and appointed as the community redevelopment agency for the city. 
(Code 1971, § 2-211) 
State Law reference- Authority to appoint downtown development authority as community redevelopment agency, F.S. § 163.357(2). 
Sec. 2-117. - Requests for funds, approval of projects. 
    Any agreement to fund a grant or request for funds or approval of any projects by the Bradenton Downtown Development Authority acting as the community redevelopment agency may be rescinded by a three-fifths vote of the city council, which vote to rescind such action of the downtown development authority acting as the community redevelopment agency shall be taken within 30 days after the action by the community redevelopment agency. The city council may, upon request from the downtown development authority by a three-fifths vote, waive its right at any particular action. 
(Code 1971, § 2-212) 
Sec. 2-118. - Right of mayor to veto rescinding action of city council. 
    The mayor shall have the right to veto the rescinding action of the city council under section 2-117, which veto shall be exercised at the next regular city council meeting, in which case if the veto is not overridden the action of the downtown development authority acting as the community redevelopment agency shall be cancelled. The city council, however, may override the mayor's veto with a four-fifths vote at such meeting, in which case the rescinding vote shall stand and the downtown development authority's action as the community redevelopment agency shall be cancelled. 
(Code 1971, § 2-213) 
Sec. 2-119. - Limitation on time for veto action. 
    No action taken by the community redevelopment agency shall be considered final nor shall any party have any right to rely on such act or acts or grants until the period of time for the veto action by the city council under this division has passed or until the city council has firmly expressed its approval of the action of the community redevelopment agency. 
(Code 1971, § 2-214) 
Sec. 2-120. - Annual budget. 
    The annual budget of the community redevelopment agency shall not be considered final until approved by the city council or until 30 days have elapsed from the period of time the budget was passed and adopted. 
(Code 1971, § 2-215) 
Sec. 2-121. - Effect of division on previous actions. 
    This division does not affect any previous actions of the community redevelopment agency or actions taken by the city council acting as the community redevelopment agency. 
(Code 1971, § 2-216) 
SUBDIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 2-122. - Created. 
(a)  Pursuant to F.S. § 163.356 there is hereby created a public body, corporate and politic to be known as the community redevelopment agency. 
(b)  Pursuant to F.S. § 163.357 and city resolution, the city council, shall serve as the governing body of the community redevelopment agency. 
(c)  The community redevelopment agency shall be governed by and act in conformity with the provisions of the general law and this section as shall be amended from time to time and may adopt rules and procedures it may deem appropriate from time to time to govern its meetings and carry out its duties and powers. 
(d)  The area of operation of the community redevelopment agency shall be the redevelopment areas as set forth in Resolution 79-55, as amended and Resolution 93-62 and Resolution 00-39. 
(Ord. No. 2967, § 1-5, 6-24-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2967, § 1, adopted June 24, 2015, repealed § 2-122, in its entirety; and §§ 2-5 enacted a new § 2-122 to read as set out herein. Former § 2-122 pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Ord. No. 2628, § 1, adopted July 12, 2000. 
Sec. 2-123. - Board of commissioners-Terms of office; qualifications. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  All the commissioners shall in addition to the above [section 2-122(a)-(d)] be subject to the qualifications, restrictions and conditions contained in chapter 163.356, part III of the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2628, §§ 2, 3, 7-12-00; Ord. No. 2649, § 1, 2-28-01; Ord. No. 2967, § 2, 6-24-15) 
Sec. 2-124. - Powers; authority. 
    The CCRA shall have all those powers as granted to it pursuant to chapter 163, part III of the Florida Statutes subject to the provisions of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 2628, § 4, 7-12-00) 
Sec. 2-125. - Funds. 
    Any agreement to fund a grant or request for funds or any project requiring the expenditure of funds by the Central Community Redevelopment Agency (CCRA) may be rescinded by three-fifths vote of the Bradenton City Council, which vote to rescind such action of the CCRA shall be taken within 30 days after the action of the CCRA. The city council may upon request from the CCRA by a three-fifths vote waive its right to rescind any particular action. 
(a)  The mayor of the City of Bradenton shall have the right to veto the rescinding action of the city council which veto is to be exercised at the next regular city council meeting, in which case if the veto is not overridden the action of CCRA shall be cancelled. The city council, however, may override the mayor's veto with a four-fifths vote at such meeting in which case the rescinding vote shall stand and the CCRA's action shall be cancelled. 
(b)  No action expending funds taken by the CCRA shall be considered final nor shall any party any right to rely on such act or acts or grants until the period of time for the veto action of the city council under this section has passed or until the city council has formally expressed its approval of the action of the CCRA. 
(c)  The annual budget of the CCRA shall not be considered final until approved by the city council or until 30 days have elapsed from the time the budget was passed and adopted. 
(Ord. No. 2628, § 5, 7-12-00) 
Sec. 2-125.1. - Term of existence. 
    The Central Community Redevelopment Agency (CCRA) shall exist for a period of 30 years from the passage of this subdivision and may incur no obligation or commitments that extend past the expiration of such term of existence unless specifically authorized by resolution of the city council of the City of Bradenton, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 2628, § 6, 7-12-00) 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2982, § 1, adopted June 22, 2016, repealed div. 3, §§ 2-126-2-130, in its entirety. Former div. 3 pertained to "Enterprise Zone Development Agency," and was derived from Ord. No. 2532, §§ 1-3, adopted April 26, 1995. 

Secs. 2-126-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter and related law references- City officers enumerated; duties generally, § 7; office of city manager, § 7A; election, general powers and duties of mayor, §§ 8, 10; selection, term of city clerk; attendance at council meetings; duty to keep records of city, § 18. 
State Law reference- Code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; social security for public employees, F.S. § 650.01 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-141. - Authority of council. 
    In addition to the offices created in charter § 7, the city council may establish such departments in the city as seem necessary and employ any persons as seem necessary, and such departments and employees thereof shall perform such duties and receive such compensation as prescribed by the city council. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 22219(1943), § 7(d); Laws of Fla., ch. 28912(1953), § 1; Laws of Fla., ch. 57-1149, §§ 1, 2; Laws of Fla., ch. 61-1892, § 1; Laws of Fla., ch. 67-1124, § 1; Ord. No. 2063, § 1, 4-14-76; Ord. No. 2205, § 1, 2-13-80) 
Sec. 2-142. - Expiration of terms; bond. 
    All of the officers of the city shall hold office until their successors are elected and qualified, and the council shall have the right to provide that any of such officers shall give bond for the faithful performance and discharge of their duties and shall prescribe the amount thereof. 
(Laws of Fla., ch. 22219(1943), § 28) 
Sec. 2-143. - Form of oath of city officers. 
    The following oath of office shall be administered to all city officers, elective or appointive: 
STATE OF FLORIDA, City of Bradenton. 
    "I, ___________, do solemnly swear, or affirm, that I will support, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States and of the State of Florida against all enemies, domestic and foreign; and that I will bear true faith, loyalty and allegiance to the same, and that I am entitled to hold office under the Constitution; that I will faithfully perform all duties of the office of ___________ on which I am about to enter. So help me God. 
___________" 
    Sworn to and subscribed before me this _____ day of ________, A.D. 19___. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-144. - City clerk as city treasurer; custodian of funds. 
    The city clerk shall perform the duties of the treasurer of the city. He shall be the custodian of the funds of the city and receive and disburse all moneys in the manner prescribed. 
(Code 1971, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-145. - Adoption of the ADA and Title IV Compliance and Non-Discrimination Statements, Policies and Procedures. 
    The city council for the City of Bradenton approves and adopts the ADA and Title VI Compliance and Non-Discrimination Statements, Policies and Procedures and proposed forms attached hereto as "Exhibit A." 
(Ord. No. 3033, § 1, 8-22-18) 
Editor's note- Exhibit A is not attached hereto but is on file with the City Clerk and Treasurer's Office. 
Secs. 2-146-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MERIT PERSONNEL SYSTEM 

Sec. 2-161. - Established; department heads; exempt personnel. 
    There is hereby established a merit personnel system for the city. The city clerk and treasurer, director of public works, chief of police, fire chief and director of planning and development shall be department heads. The following shall be considered exempt from the merit personnel system: 
(1)  Elected officials and persons appointed to fill vacancies in elective offices. 
(2)  Members of boards, committees and commissions. 
(3)  Members of boards, committees and commissions appointed to conduct a temporary or special investigation or inquiry. 
(4)  All department heads. 
(5)  City attorney and assistant city attorneys. 
(6)  City auditor. 
(7)  Temporary and probationary employees. 
(8)  Personnel director. 
(9)  Administrative aide to the mayor. 
(10)  Any other position which may be exempt by resolution or as may be exempted pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement. 
(Code 1971, § 2-121) 
Sec. 2-162. - Authority and responsibility of department heads. 
    The department heads shall have authority and responsibility for administration of the merit personnel system. Each shall have authority to appoint, remove, suspend and discipline personnel employed by his department. The department heads shall recommend to the city council the employees required in their respective department, their duties and compensation. The merit personnel board and personnel director shall establish a formal procedure for handling review requests of employees in the system. 
(Code 1971, § 2-122) 
Sec. 2-163. - Merit personnel board-Appointment, composition; term of members; organization; filling of vacancies; removal of members. 
(a)  The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint the merit personnel board, to be composed of five members and one alternate member, each of whom shall be a person of a different vocation from the others, not employed by the city in any capacity, official or otherwise. The term of office for such board members shall be for three years. 
(b)  The merit personnel board shall meet annually after the appointment of the members to organize and select one of its members as chair and one of its members as vice-chair. The board may appoint such other assistants to the chair as may be necessary. All five members of the merit personnel board shall serve without compensation. All vacancies, whether by resignation, dismissal or expiration, shall be filled within 30 days by the mayor with the approval of the city council. Any members of the board may be removed by the mayor with the approval of the city council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance, or similar cause after written notice and a public hearing. 
(Code 1971, § 2-124) 
Sec. 2-164. - Same-Duties. 
    The merit personnel board shall hear review requests from any employee of the city in respect to any dismissal, demotion or suspension. Any such request for review shall be initiated within 30 days after such personnel action has been taken in respect to any employee. The board shall have the power to examine witnesses under oath and to compel their attendance for the production of evidence before it by subpoena issued in the name of the city and attested by the city clerk and treasurer. The board shall make a written statement of the facts of each appeal and its findings and recommendation, all of which shall be submitted to the city council for such action as the council, in its judgment, determine to be proper. 
(Code 1971, § 2-125) 
Sec. 2-165. - Personnel director. 
    The mayor, subject to the confirmation of the city council and the merit personnel board shall appoint a qualified person to serve as personnel director who shall be responsible for the internal administration of the merit personnel system and who shall perform the following duties under the supervision of the city council and the merit personnel board: 
(1)  Establish and maintain a roster and personnel records for all city employees in the merit personnel system and all employees appointed by the city council. 
(2)  Recommend to the merit personnel board and city council changes in personnel regulations as he deems advisable. 
(3)  Promulgate a position classification and compensation plan and suggest amendments thereto when appropriate. 
(4)  Certify to the city clerk and treasurer the correctness of all payroll classifications, rate of pay and attendance. 
(5)  Develop and administer such recruiting and examination programs necessary to obtain an adequate number of applicants for positions with the city. 
(6)  Develop and coordinate educational and training programs for all employees of the city. 
(7)  Process review requests in accordance with procedures established by the merit personnel board. 
(8)  Such other duties as may be required to administer the personnel system. 
(Code 1971, § 2-123) 
Sec. 2-166. - Rules and regulations-Promulgation; amendment. 
(a)  The personnel director and department heads shall promulgate personnel rules and shall submit such rules to the city council for adoption by resolution. Such rules and regulations shall declare the official policy of the city in the areas of personnel administration. 
(b)  Amendments to the merit personnel system rules and regulations may be initiated at any time for consideration of the city council, but such amendment shall not become effective until approval of the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1971, § 2-126) 
Sec. 2-167. - Same-Mandatory provisions. 
    The merit personnel system rules and regulations, among other matters, shall provide: 
(1)  For employment of persons on the basis of merit except as to temporary appointments, shall make provisions for recruiting and employment of persons from established lists. 
(2)  For temporary appointments not in excess of six months to be made by the appointing officer in absence of eligibility lists and renewal of such temporary appointments for additional like periods by the appointing officer when in his judgment extenuating circumstances require the continued employment of such individuals. 
(3)  That during a period of suspension of any impending final actions of any proceeding to review the demotion or dismissal of any employee, any vacancy thereby created may be filled by the appointing officer by temporary appointment. 
(Code 1971, § 2-127) 
Secs. 2-168-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAVELING EXPENSES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Fixed expenses for the mayor and members of the city council, § 2-47. 
State Law reference- Per diem and traveling expense, F.S. § 112.061. 

Sec. 2-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized person means: 
(1)  A person other than a city official or employee as defined in this section, whether elected or commissioned or not, who is authorized by the mayor, city council, or department head to incur traveling expenses in the performance of his official duties; 
(2)  A person who is called upon by the mayor and city council to contribute time and services as a consultant or advisor; or 
(3)  A person who is a candidate for an executive or professional position called at the request of the mayor and city council. 
    City official is an elected official of the city or is an individual who in the performance of his official duties is charged with certain responsibilities of the city who is commissioned or appointed by the mayor or is appointed or commissioned by the mayor with the consent of the city council and who has jurisdiction extending throughout the city or is a department head. 
    Common carrier means train, bus, commercial airline operating scheduled flights, or rental cars of an established rental car firm. 
    Employee is an individual, whether commissioned or not, other than a city official or authorized person as defined in this section, who is filling a regular or full-time authorized position with the city and who is responsible to a department head. 
    Travel day means a period of 24 hours consisting of four quarters of six hours each. 
    Travel expense means traveling expenses, necessary expenses while traveling, actual expenses while traveling, or words of similar nature. The usual ordinary and incidental expenditures necessarily incurred by a traveler. 
    Travel period means a period of time between time of departure and time of return. 
    Traveler means a city official, employee or authorized person, as defined in this section, when performing authorized travel. 
(Code 1971, § 2-146) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-182. - Scope of division. 
    City officials, authorized persons and employees may be reimbursed for certain expenses incurred while traveling on city business. The procedures in this division are applicable to all city officials, employees and authorized persons when making claim for travel expense allowances; all department heads and the mayor when authorizing and approving travel; and the finance department when paying travel allowances. 
Sec. 2-183. - Travel allowances. 
    All travel allowances must be for official city business and within the limits prescribed in this division. Convention, conference or school travel is further restricted by the provision that attendance must serve a direct public purpose with relation to the city. 
Sec. 2-184. - Authority to incur. 
(a)  All travel must be authorized and approved in advance by the department head from whose budget the funds to such traveler is paid. 
(b)  Traveling expenses of travelers shall be limited to those expenses necessarily incurred by them in the performance of a public purpose by ordinance or state law to be performed by the city council or city department and must be within the limitations prescribed by this section. 
(c)  Local mileage allowance shall be authorized by budgetary or city council action and approved in advance by the department head. 
(d)  Travel by city officials, department heads, or employees serving temporarily in behalf of city officials or another department head or employees or partly in behalf of more than one city official, department head, or employee at the same time, or authorized persons who are called upon to contribute time and services as consultants or advisors, may be authorized by the mayor, the city council, or department head. Complete explanation and justification must be shown on the travel expense report or attached thereto. 
(e)  Traveling expenses of public employees for the sole purpose of taking merit system or other job placement examinations, written or oral, shall not be allowed under any circumstances, except upon prior written approval of the department head. Candidates for executive or professional positions may be allowed traveling expenses pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1971, § 2-147) 
Sec. 2-185. - Method of travel. 
    All travel methods must be approved by the department head. Air travel will be done by coach class on scheduled airlines using the most direct route available. Use of other than coach class will not be authorized if coach class service is available. Reimbursement for travel by city-owned vehicle is limited to actual automotive expenditures and must be supported by paid bills or receipts. Travel by privately owned vehicle may be authorized in lieu of common carrier or city-owned vehicle. Reimbursement is limited to a mileage allowance computed on the basis of current state road maps, plus local destination travel. No reimbursement shall be paid when the traveler is gratuitously transported by another person who is entitled to a transportation allowance. Private airplane expense may be authorized when justified by convenience for the city. 
Sec. 2-186. - Rates of subsistence allowance. 
    Rates and substance [subsistence] allowances shall be provided for by resolution. 
(Code 1971, § 2-151; Ord. No. 2765, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-04; Ord. No. 2765, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-04) 
Sec. 2-187. - Transportation. 
(a)  All travel must be by a usually traveled route. If a person travels by an indirect route for his own convenience, any extra costs shall be borne by the traveler and reimbursement for expenses shall be based only on such charges as would have been incurred by a usually traveled route. 
(b)  The department head shall designate the most economical method of travel for each trip, keeping in mind the following conditions: 
(1)  The nature of the business. 
(2)  The most efficient and economical means of travel, considering time of the traveler, cost of transportation and subsistence required. 
(3)  The number of persons making the trip, and the amount of equipment or material to be transported. 
(c)  The city clerk and treasurer's office may provide any forms necessary to cover travel requests for traveling on official business and when paid by the city. 
(d)  Transportation by common carrier when traveling on official business and paid for personally by the traveler shall be substantiated by a paid receipt. 
(e)  The use of privately owned vehicles for official travel in lieu of publicly owned vehicles or common carrier may be authorized by the department head if a publicly owned vehicle is not available. Whenever travel is by privately owned vehicle, the traveler shall be entitled to a mileage allowance at the rate provided in subsection 2-186(3) or the common carrier fare for such travel, to be determined by the department head. Reimbursement for expenditures related to the operation, maintenance, and ownership of a vehicle shall not be allowed when privately owned vehicles are used on public business and reimbursement is made pursuant to this subsection, except as provided in subsection 2-186(4). 
(f)  All mileage shall be shown from point of origin to point of destination and shall be computed on the basis of the current map of the department of transportation. Vicinity mileage necessary for conduct of official business is allowable, but must be shown as a separate item on the expense voucher. 
(g)  Transportation by chartered vehicles when traveling on official business may be authorized by the department head when necessary or where it is to the advantage of the city, provided the cost of such transportation does not exceed the cost of transportation by privately owned vehicle pursuant to subsections (e) and (f) of this section. 
(h)  The department head may grant monthly allowances in fixed amounts for use of privately owned automobiles on official business in lieu of the mileage rate provided in subsections (e) and (f) of this section. Allowances granted pursuant to this subsection shall be reasonable, taking into account the customary use of the automobile, the roads customarily traveled, and whether any of the expenses incident to the operation, maintenance, and ownership of the automobile are paid from funds of the city or other public funds. Such allowance may be changed at any time, and shall be made on the basis of a signed statement of the traveler, filed before the allowance is granted or changed, and at least annually thereafter. The statement shall show the places and distances for an average typical month's travel on official business, and the amount that would be allowed under the approved rate per mile for the travel shown in the statement, if payment had been made pursuant to subsections (e) and (f) of this section. 
(i)  No contracts may be entered into between a city official, department head, or employee, or any other person, and the city, in which a depreciation allowance is used in computing the amount due by the city to the individual for the use of a privately owned vehicle on official business; provided, any such existing contract shall not be impaired. 
(j)  No traveler shall be allowed either mileage or transportation expense when he is gratuitously transported by another person, or when he is transported by another traveler who is entitled to mileage or transportation expense. 
(Code 1971, § 2-151) 
Sec. 2-188. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city clerk and treasurer's office shall promulgate such rules and regulations as may be necessary to effectuate the purposes of this division. 
(b)  Each city department shall promulgate such additional rules and regulations not in conflict with the rules and regulations of the city clerk and treasurer's office as may be necessary to effectuate the purposes of this division. Such rules and regulations shall be recorded in the official minutes of the city council or maintained in a special file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(Code 1971, § 2-154) 
Sec. 2-189. - Forms. 
(a)  The following forms which are on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office shall be used in compliance with the procedures outlined in this division: 
(1)  Travel expense report: This form provides for entering all information necessary to support claims for travel allowance. 
(2)  Mileage certificate: This form provides for entering all information necessary to support claims for local or vicinity mileage. 
(3)  Check request: This form provides for funds requested in advance for prepayments. 
(b)  The city clerk and treasurer's office will furnish the travel voucher forms which shall be used by all city officials, department heads, employees, and authorized persons when submitting traveling expense statements for approval and payment. No traveling expense statement shall be approved for payment by the city clerk and treasurer unless made on the form prescribed and furnished pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1971, § 2-156) 
Sec. 2-190. - Advances. 
    Notwithstanding any of the restrictions and limitations in this division, a department head may make, or authorize the making of, advances to cover anticipated costs of travel to travelers whose duties require such travel. Such advances may be made only pursuant to regulations of the city clerk and treasurer's office requiring application for funds and accounting therefor when the travel has been completed. Such advancements may include the costs of subsistence and travel of any person transported in the care or custody of the traveler in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1971, § 2-157) 
Sec. 2-191. - Travel expense reports. 
    A travel expense report will be submitted within ten days after return from travel. The expense report form shall be prepared in duplicate and processed as follows: 
(1)  The traveler will sign the report, obtain department head approval as appropriate and forward the original to the city clerk and treasurer. If the payee is not a city employee, a direct expenditure voucher must accompany the report. 
(2)  Upon approval of the department head and city clerk and treasurer, accounting will issue a reasonable travel advance. If the travel advance is more than the expense, the traveler must attach a personal check or cash for the difference with the report. 
Sec. 2-192. - Mileage certificate procedure. 
    A mileage certificate form will be used in making claims for mileage travel on local trips in the immediate vicinity of the city. The certificates will be submitted no later than the last day of the month in which mileage was traveled. The form will be prepared in duplicate and processed as follows: 
(1)  The traveler will sign the report, obtain appropriate approval on both copies, file a duplicate copy in the departmental divisional file, and forward the original to the city clerk and treasurer. 
(2)  Upon approval of the city clerk and treasurer, accounting will effect payment in the amount shown. 
Sec. 2-193. - Statement as to verity; fraudulent claims; penalty. 
    Claims submitted pursuant to this division shall not be required to be sworn to before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths, but any claim authorized or required to be made under any provision of this division shall contain a statement that the expenses were actually incurred by the traveler as necessary traveling expenses in the performance of his official duties and shall be verified by a written declaration that it is true and correct as to every material matter. Any person who wilfully makes and subscribes to any such claim which he does not believe to be true and correct as to every material matter, or who wilfully aids or assists in, or procures, counsels, or advises the preparation or presentation under the provisions of this division of a claim which is fraudulent or is false as to any material matter, whether or not such falsity or fraud is with the knowledge or consent of the person authorized or required to present such claim, shall be guilty of a violation of this division and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished according to section 1-15. Whoever shall receive an allowance or reimbursement by means of a false claim shall be civilly liable in the amount of the overpayment for the reimbursement of the public fund from which the claim was paid. 
(Code 1971, § 2-155) 
Secs. 2-194-2-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[9] 
Footnotes:
