(A)  This section shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Bradenton Proportionate Fair Share Transportation Ordinance". 
(B)  The city council is required to adopt this section in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 163.3180(16). 
(C)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all developments within the city that impact a road segment where the road segment has failed to achieve transportation concurrency by having an level of service below that adopted in the City of Bradenton Comprehensive Plan. 
(D)  This section shall not apply to multiuse developments of regional impact (DRIs) or to developments exempted from concurrency or to developments creating de minimis impacts. 
(2)  Intent and purpose. The purpose and intent of this section is to establish a method whereby the impacts of development on transportation facilities can be mitigated by the cooperative efforts of the public and private sectors. 
(3)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Capital improvements. The outlay of capital dollars for the planning of, engineering for, acquisition of land for, and construction of roads, turn lanes, intersection improvements and signalization, but does not include maintenance. 
    Community investment plan (CIP). The five-year capital improvement element adopted in the City of Bradenton Comprehensive Plan. 
    Developer. Any person, corporation partnership, association, trust, estate, business trust, agency, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, governmental entity, or any other entity undertaking the development of land. 
    Fair share transportation facilities impact fee or impact fee. The fee required to be paid in accordance with the terms of the City of Bradenton Fair Share Transportation Facilities Impact Fee Ordinance. 
    Land. The earth, water, and air above, below, or on the surface, and includes any improvements or structures customarily regarded as land. 
    Land development activity generating traffic. The carrying out of any building activity or the making of any material change in the use of any structure or land that attracts or produces vehicular trip(s) over and above that produced by the existing land development activity, and consequently places an additional demand on the major road network system. 
    Level of service. A qualitative measure that represents the collective factors of speed, travel time, traffic interruption, freedom to maneuver, safety, driving comfort and convenience, and operating costs provided by a highway facility under a particular volume condition. Levels of service vary from A to F. "Level of service C" shall mean a roadway condition as determined and established by the 2002 Florida Department of Transportation's 2002 Quality/Level of Service Handbook. 
    Major road network system. All arterial and collector roads within the city including proposed arterial and collector roads necessitated by new land development activity generating traffic. 
    noncommencement. The cancellation of construction activity that is proposed to make a material change in a structure or land. 
    Person. An individual, developer, corporation, governmental agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, two (2) or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other entity. 
(4)  Rules of construction. In the construction of this section, the rules set out in this subsection shall be observed unless such construction is inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this subchapter which contains any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content of such section would be inconsistent with this section. 
(A)  Generally. All provisions, terms, phrases, and expressions contained in this subsection shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. Terms used in this section, unless otherwise specifically provided, shall have the meanings prescribed by the Florida Statutes for the same terms. 
(B)  Text. In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this subchapter and any figure, the text shall control. 
(C)  Delegation of authority. Where there is a provision requiring the head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or to perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize that person to delegate professional level subordinates to perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
(D)  Gender. Words of the masculine gender shall be construed to include the feminine and vice versa. 
(E)  Day. A calendar day. 
(F)  Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
(G)  Number. A word of the singular number only, may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. The use of the plural number shall be deemed to include any single person or thing. 
(H)  Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
(I)  Tense. Words used in the past tense include the future as well as the past or present. 
(J)  Written or in writing. Any representation of words, letters or figures whether by printing or otherwise. 
(K)  Year. A calendar year unless a fiscal year is indicated. 
(5)  General requirements. 
(A)  A developer may choose to satisfy the transportation concurrency requirements of the city by making a proportionate fair share contribution pursuant to the following requirements: 
(1)  The proposed development is consistent with the comprehensive plan and applicable land development regulations; and, 
(2)  The city five-year community investment program (CIP) includes a transportation capital improvement that, upon completion, will accommodate additional traffic generated by the proposed development. 
(B)  The city may choose to allow a developer to satisfy transportation concurrency requirements by making a proportionate fair share contribution by contributing to an improvement, that upon completion, will accommodate additional traffic generated by the proposed development, but is not contained in the five-year CIP, where one of the following conditions apply: 
(1)  The city adds the improvement to the five-year CIP no later than the next regular capital improvements update of the Comprehensive Plan, provided that the improvement is financially feasible as defined by F.S. § 163.3180(16)(b)(1); or, 
(2)  If the funds in the five-year CIP are insufficient to fully fund the construction of the improvement, the city may enter into a proportionate fair share agreement with the developer authorizing construction of that amount of development on which the proportionate fair share amount is calculated if the proportionate fair share amount in such agreement is sufficient to pay for one or more improvements which will, in the opinion of the city council, significantly benefit the impacted transportation system, provided that improvement(s) is(are) adopted into the five-year CIP no later than the next regular capital improvements update of the comprehensive plan. 
(C)  Any transportation capital improvement proposed to meet the developer's proportionate fair share obligation must meet the design standards of the city for city-maintained roads and the design standards of the applicable governmental entity for all other roads. 
(6)  Application process. 
(A)  A developer who shall commence any land development activity generating traffic which results in a failure of a road segment to achieve transportation concurrency may apply to the city for a proportionate fair share agreement. 
(B)  Prior to submitting an application for a proportionate fair share agreement, a preapplication meeting shall be held to discuss eligibility, application submittal requirements, potential mitigation options and other relevant issues. If the road segment that has failed to achieve transportation concurrency is on the strategic intermodal system, the Florida Department of Transportation shall be requested to participate in the preapplication meeting. 
(C)  Procedures for review of application for proportionate fair share agreement. 
(1)  The developer shall submit an application to the planning and community development director that includes a nonrefundable application fee of $5,000.00 and the following: 
(a)  Name, address and contact information of the developer; 
(b)  A drawing and legal description of the land; 
(c)  Phasing schedule; 
(d)  Description of the requested fair share mitigation; 
(e)  If the requested fair share mitigation involves a road segment on the strategic intermodal system (SIS), evidence of concurrence from the Florida Department of Transportation. 
(f)  Traffic study performed by a licensed traffic engineer demonstrating failure of road segment to achieve transportation concurrency. 
(2)  Within 20 days of receipt of the application, the planning and community development director shall review the application to determine if the application is complete. If it is determined that the application is not complete, the planning and community development director shall send a written statement to the developer delineating the deficiencies. If such deficiencies are not remedied by the developer within 30 days of receipt of the written notification, then the application shall be deemed abandoned. The planning and community development director, in his sole discretion, may grant an extension to cure such deficiencies, provided the developer has shown good cause for the extension and has taken reasonable steps to effect a cure. 
(3)  Once the Planning and Community Development Director determines the application is complete, he shall provide written notification of such to the developer and forward the application to the City Attorney who shall, within thirty (30) days, draft a proportionate fair share agreement for consideration by the City Council at a meeting no later than sixty (60) days from the date at which the developer received the notification that the application was complete. 
(4)  No proportionate fair share agreement shall be effective until approved by the City Council. 
(7)  Determination of proportionate fair share obligation. 
(A)  Proportionate fair share mitigation includes, without limitation, separately or collectively, private funds, contributions of land and contribution of transportation facilities. 
(B)  The methodology used to calculate a developer's proportionate fair share obligation shall be as provided for pursuant to §163.3180(12), F.S. and as represented by the following formula: 
_____
Proportionate Share = [(Development Trips)/(SV Increase)] × Cost 
Where: 
Development Trips = Those trips from the development that are assigned to roadway segment; 
SV Increase = Service volume increase provided by the improvement to roadway segment 
Cost = Adjusted cost of the improvement. 
_____ 
(C)  For the purposes of determining proportionate fair share obligations, improvement costs shall be based upon the actual cost of the improvement as obtained from the CIP, the Manatee MOP Transportation Improvement Program, or the Florida Department of Transportation Work Program. Where such information is not available, the improvement cost shall be determined using one of the following methods: 
(1)  An analysis by the public works department of costs, adjusted by the Florida Department of Transportation Price Trends Index from the previous year, by cross section type that incorporates data from recent projects; or, 
(2)  The most recent issue of Florida Department of Transportation "Transportation Costs", as adjusted based upon the type of cross section (urban or rural); locally available data from recent projects on acquisition, drainage, and utility costs; and significant changes in the cost of materials due to unforeseeable events. 
(D)  If the city has accepted an improvement project proposed by the developer, then the value of the improvement shall be determined using one of the methods provided in this section. 
(E)  If the city has accepted right-of-way dedication for the proportionate fair share payment, credit for the dedication of the nonsite-related right-of-way shall be valued on the date of the dedication at 120 percent of the most recent assessed value by the Manatee County Property Appraiser or, at the mutual agreement of the city and the developer, by fair market value established by an independent appraisal approved by the city and at no expense to the city. The developer shall supply a certificate of title or title search of the land to the city at no expense to the city. If the estimated value of the right-of-way dedication proposed by the developer is less than the city estimated total proportionate fair share obligation for that development, then the developer must also pay the difference. 
(8)  Transportation facilities impact fee credit. 
(A)  Proportionate fair share mitigation shall be applied as a credit against impact fees, if applicable. Credits will be given for that portion of the impact fees that would have been used to fund the improvements on which the proportionate fair share contribution is calculated. Additionally, if the proportionate fair share contribution is based on only a portion of the development's traffic, the credit will be limited to that portion of the impact fees on which the proportionate fair share contribution is based. 
(B)  At the time the proportionate fair share obligation is being determined, the city will also compute the transportation facilities impact fee obligation for the proposed development. If the developer's proportionate fair share obligation is less than the development's anticipated total transportation facilities impact fee, then the developer must pay the difference to the city. 
(9)  Proportionate fair share agreements. 
(A)  Should the developer fail to apply for a building permit within one year of the date of execution of the proportionate fair share agreement, then the agreement shall be considered null and void, and the developer shall be required to reapply in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter. 
(B)  Payment of the proportionate fair share contribution is due in full prior to issuance of the final development order or recording of the final plat and shall be nonrefundable. If the payment is submitted more than one year from the date of execution of the agreement, then the proportionate fair share cost shall be recalculated at the time of payment based on the best estimate of the construction cost of the required improvement at the time of payment, pursuant to [F.S.] § 183.36 and adjusted accordingly. 
(C)  Developer improvements authorized under this Ordinance involving dedications to the city must be completed upon final acceptance of the improvements and receipt of a warranty bond. The form of the warranty bond shall be approved by the city clerk and treasurer. 
(D)  Developer improvements authorized under this subchapter not involving dedications to city must be completed upon recording of a final plat or upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whichever event first occurs. 
(E)  Any requested change to a development project subsequent to a development order will be subject to additional proportionate fair share contributions to the extent the change would generate additional traffic. 
(F)  A developer may submit a letter to withdraw from the proportionate fair share agreement at any time prior to the execution of the agreement. The application fee to the city will be nonrefundable. 
(10)  Appropriation of fair share revenues. 
(A)  All proportionate fair share revenues shall be placed in the appropriate project account for funding of scheduled improvements in the CIP, or for use as otherwise established in the terms of the proportionate fair share agreement. 
(B)  In the event a scheduled transportation facility improvement is removed from the CIP, then the revenues collected for its construction shall be applied toward the construction of another improvement within that same corridor that would mitigate the impacts of development as determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2854, §§ 1-10, 1-10-07) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-291 et seq.; occupational license, § 66-176 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Appearing nude in business or commercial establishment. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words shall have the meanings set forth hereafter: 
    Business and commercial establishments: Any premises or the location of a retail or wholesale business or service establishment, frequented by the public, or where the public is present or likely to be present, or where a person may reasonably be expected to observed by members of the public, whether for profit or not for profit and whether open to the public at large or where entrance is limited by a cover charge or membership requirement. Business or commercial establishments shall include, but are not limited to, hotels, motels, restaurants, night clubs or cabarets where alcoholic beverages are not served, video stores, lingerie shops, meeting facilities utilized by any religious, social, fraternal or similar organization. Premises, or portions thereof, such as motel rooms, used solely as a private residence, whether permanent or temporary in nature, shall not be deemed to be a business or commercial establishments. 
    Entity: Any proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association, business trust, joint venture, joint-stock company, or other for-profit or not-for-profit organization. 
    Nude: Insufficiently clothed so that the person has not covered, with fully opaque covering: 
(1)  The male or female genitals or any portion thereof; 
(2)  The male or female pubic area or any portion thereof; or 
(3)  The areola of the female breast or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not exposed. 
    Places provided or set apart for nudity: An enclosed single-sex public restroom, enclosed single-sex functional shower, locker or dressing room facilities, enclosed motel rooms and hotel rooms designed and intended for sleeping accommodations, doctors' offices, portions of hospitals and similar places in which nudity or exposure is necessary and customary. This term shall not be deemed to include places where a person's conduct is being nude is used for his or her profit or where nudity is used for the promotion of business or is otherwise commercially exploited. 
(b)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly, intentionally or recklessly appear, or cause another person to appear, nude in a business or commercial establishment, except as is specifically provided for hereinafter. It shall also be unlawful for any person or entity maintaining, owning, operating or managing any business or commercial establishment, to encourage, suffer or allow any person to appear nude in such place, except as provided hereinafter. 
(c)  Applications: 
(1)  The provisions of this section shall not apply when a person appears nude in a place provided or set apart for nudity so long as (i) such person is nude for the sole purpose of performing the legal function(s) that is customarily intended to be performed within such place provided for or set apart for nudity and (ii) such person is not nude for the purpose of obtaining money or other financial gain. 
(2)  The provisions of this section shall not apply when the conduct otherwise prohibited hereby cannot be prohibited (i) because it constitutes a part of a bona fide live communication, demonstration or performance by a person wherein nudity is expressive conduct incidental to and necessary for the conveyance or communication of a genuine message or public expression and is not a mere guise or pretense utilized to exploit the conduct of being nude for profit or commercial gain and as such is protected by the United States or Florida Constitution or because it is otherwise protected by the United States Constitution (see for instance Board of County Commissioner v. Dexterhouse, 348 So. 2nd, 916 (Fla 2nd DCA 1977). 
(Ord. No. 2550, § 1, 12-13-95) 
Secs. 22-2-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTRACTORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 22-31. - Application of state law. 
    The provisions and statutes as contained in F.S. ch. 489 shall be applied to contractors and contracting within the city, and all definitions contained therein shall be applicable to this article. 
(Code 1971, § 7-1) 
Sec. 22-32. - Qualification of contractors. 
(a)  License required. Every person, firm, copartnership, corporation, association or other organization, or any combination thereof, engaged in or who shall engage in, offer to engage in, or advertise such services within the city shall procure and maintain either a state certification license or a city certificate of competency. 
(b)  Qualification of state-certified contractors. The qualification of state-certified contractors shall be done by the city upon presentation by the contractor of proof of his state certification and proof of his worker's compensation insurance or exemption. No administrative qualification fees are required from state-certified contractors. 
(c)  Qualification of other contractors. To qualify to work in the city, if not state-certified, contractors must submit the following: 
(1)  An application on department form C1-90. 
(2)  A letter of reciprocity from the county or municipality where the contractor took his exam. 
(3)  Proof that the contractor passed a "Block & Associates" test in the field of his specialty with a grade at least equal to 75 percent. 
(4)  Proof of worker's compensation insurance or exemption. 
(5)  Proof of registration with the department of business and professional regulation whenever the case applies (see section 22-33(b)). 
(6)  Pay the qualification administration fees. 
(Code 1971, § 7-2) 
Sec. 22-33. - Qualification administrative fees; registration with state. 
(a)  The bi-yearly administrative fees that are applicable to all registered contractors holding a city competency license are: 
Class A General contractor $110.00 Class B Building contractor 88.00 Class C Residential contractor 66.00 Class D All other contractors 55.00  
    After passage of this section the foregoing fees may be increased or decreased by resolution passed by the city council and kept on file in the city clerk and planning departments offices. 
Qualification can be done at any time during the year and shall be renewed during the month of September of all even years. Renewal notices are mailed bi-yearly before August 15th of every even year. Qualification renewed at anytime after October 1st of the even year shall require a double fee. 
Contractors who held a certificate of competency with the city and lost that certificate due to non-renewal within the specified time frame can re-apply for qualification and need only to submit items as required by the city. 
(b)  The following contractors who are not state-certified shall be registered with the department of business and professional regulation: General, building, residential, sheet metal, roofing, class A, B and C air conditioning, mechanical, commercial pool, residential pool, swimming pool servicing, electrical, plumbing, underground utility, solar, aluminum, asbestos abatement, carpentry, drywall, grading/paving, marine, masonry, specialty structure, steel erection, response action. 
(Code 1971, § 7-3; Ord. No. 2617, § 1, 2-9-00) 
Sec. 22-34. - Construction trade board-Created. 
    There is hereby created the City of Bradenton Construction Trade Board. The members of this board will be the same as the construction code board of rules and appeals. 
(Code 1971, § 7-4) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-96 et seq. 
Sec. 22-35. - Same-Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of the construction trade board to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by imposing administrative fines and other noncriminal penalties, and to provide an equitable, expeditious, effective method of enforcing the codes and ordinances in effect in the city where a pending or repeatable violation exists, including, but not limited to, violations of the building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, gas or fire codes, the provisions of this article and F.S. chs. 489 and 553. 
(Code 1971, § 7-5) 
Sec. 22-36. - Same-Derivation of authority. 
    The authority of the construction trade board emanates from the city council and from F.S. ch. 489, which delegates to municipalities the authority to discipline persons who violate applicable local code provisions pertaining to the activities of licensed contractors, including the authority to impose monetary fines against such violators. 
(Code 1971, § 7-6) 
Sec. 22-37. - Same-Rules for conduct of hearings; powers. 
(a)  The construction trade board shall adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
(b)  The construction trade board shall have the powers to: 
(1)  Subpoena evidence and alleged violators and witnesses to its hearing. Subpoenas may be served by the police department or any other duly authorized person. 
(2)  Take testimony under oath. 
(3)  Issue orders having force of law; and to command whatever steps necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(4)  Give notices of hearings and conduct those hearings upon charges of a violation of the provisions of this article. 
(5)  Impose disciplinary penalties against any person found by the board to have violated the provision of this article and F.S. chs. 489 and 553 or city ordinances pertaining to construction and contractors. 
(6)  Hear the appeal of any person who may be aggrieved by any ruling or order of the administrative official. 
(Code 1971, § 7-7) 
Sec. 22-38. - Same-Liability of members. 
    Any member of the construction trade board charged with the enforcement of this article, acting in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself personally liable and is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may occur to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against a member of the construction trade board because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this article shall be defended by the city until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Code 1971, § 7-8) 
Sec. 22-39. - Grounds for disciplinary action. 
    Grounds for disciplinary action of contractors shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Failure to obey a stop work order of the official. 
(2)  Misrepresentation of any material fact in the application for contractor licensing, or the renewal of the qualification by reciprocity and the workers' compensation insurance, or any other falsified documents. 
(3)  Abandoning a construction project in which the contractor is engaged. A project is to be considered abandoned after 90 days if the contractor terminates the project without just cause or without proper notification to the owner, including the reason for termination, or fails to perform work without just cause for 90 consecutive days. 
(4)  Committing mismanagement or misconduct in the practices of contracting that causes financial harm to a customer. Financial mismanagement or misconduct occurs when: 
a.  Valid liens have been recorded against the property of a contractor's customer of supplies or services ordered by the contractor for the customer's job; the contractor has received funds from the customer to pay for the supplies or service and the contractor has not had the liens removed from the property, by payment or by bond, within 75 days after the date of such payment. 
b.  The contractor's job has been completed and it is shown that the customer has had to pay more for the contracted job than the original contract price, as adjusted for subsequent change orders, unless such increase in cost was the result of circumstances beyond the control of the contractor, was the result of circumstances caused by the customer or was otherwise agreed to between the contractor and the customer. 
(5)  Departure from the approved plans or specification accompanying the application for a permit issued to such contractor by the city. 
(6)  Failing in any material respect to comply with the provisions of federal, state and city codes that directly relate to construction and contracting and in particular to F.S. ch. 489. 
(7)  Failing to report to the official or attempting to conceal a violation of any provision of this article. 
(8)  Knowingly combining and conspiring with an unlicensed person by allowing his license and/or any permit issued thereafter to be used by an unlicensed person when such person is not working under the supervision or as a regular employee of the license holder. Allowing one's certificate to be used by one or more business organizations without having any active participation in the operation, management or control of such business organization constitutes prima facie evidence of an intent to evade the provisions of this subsection. 
(9)  Proceeding with and/or completing any contracting work for which a permit is required without first obtaining all applicable permits and inspections. 
(10)  Being convicted or found guilty in a court of law regardless of location of a crime in any jurisdiction which directly relates to the practice of contracting or the ability to so practice. 
(11)  Committing fraud or deceit or misconduct; being negligent or incompetent in the practice of contracting, further described as follows: 
a.  Fraud occurs when there is an intentional perversion of the truth in order to induce someone to part with something of value. 
b.  Deceit occurs when a person has imposed a false idea or belief on another in order to obscure the truth. 
c.  Misconduct occurs when a person has intentionally done wrong or has deliberately violated a law or regulation. 
d.  Negligence occurs when a person has not attended to his duties or business with proper care and diligence. 
e.  Incompetence occurs when a person is not qualified, is inadequate or is unsuitable for a particular purpose and is unable to function in attempting to effectuate such purposes. 
(12)  Filing of a voluntary petition in bankruptcy with the intention of defrauding a property owner. 
(13)  Signing a statement with respect to a project or contract falsely indicating that the work is bonded. 
(14)  Falsely indicating that payment has been made for all subcontract work, labor and materials or falsely indicating that worker's compensation and public liability insurance are provided. 
(Code 1971, § 7-9) 
Sec. 22-40. - Disciplinary penalties. 
(a)  Upon finding that a contractor has committed more than one violation in one or more cases being considered together, the construction trade board shall issue cumulative civil disciplinary penalties. 
(b)  The following constitutes the range of civil disciplinary penalties which the construction trade board may impose upon a contractor whenever a violation occurs and a disciplinary action is justified: 
(1)  Reprimand. 
(2)  Suspend the permitting privilege for a period that can range from 30 days to three years. 
(3)  Suspend from all operations of construction for a period that can range from 30 days to three years. 
(4)  Revoke the permitting privilege for a state-licensed contractor; revoke the qualification by reciprocity for all other types of contractors. 
(5)  Require that the violator pay a monetary fine not to exceed $500.00 per violation up to a total not to exceed $5,000.00. 
(6)  Require that restitution be provided to any party aggrieved by a violation of any provision of this article. 
(c)  Any contractor disciplined by the construction trade board shall be assessed a fee corresponding to the reasonable investigative and legal cost incurred by the city in prosecuting any violation(s) against the contractor. The amount will be established by resolution of the board. 
(d)  In determining the amount of the fine and/or in imposing any other penalty authorized by this section, the construction trade board shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The gravity of the violation. 
(2)  Actions taken by the contractor to correct the violation. 
(3)  Previous violations committed by the contractor. 
(Code 1971, § 7-10) 
Sec. 22-41. - Investigation, enforcement and prehearing procedure. 
    The building department shall have the authority to investigate complaints and initiate enforcement proceedings against contractors. No members of the construction trade board shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceeding. 
(1)  If a violation of any portion of the Code is discovered, the building department shall notify the contractor and give him a reasonable amount of time to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for the correction, the building department shall complete its investigation and review the grounds of the existence of probable cause. 
(2)  The determination of probable cause shall be made within ten days of the review. If the building department finds that probable cause exists, it shall file a formal complaint against the violator and shall prosecute that complaint pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(3)  A formal hearing before the construction trade board shall be held pursuant to section 22-43. 
(Code 1971, § 7-11) 
Sec. 22-42. - Notice of proceedings. 
    Any contractor who is the subject of proceedings before the construction trade board shall be provided with timely notice of such proceedings in the following manner: 
(1)  All notices shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by hand delivery by an officer of the police department or any other person designated by the building department, or by leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of business or residence with some person of his family above 15 years of age or any employee and informing each person of the contents of the notice. 
(2)  In addition to providing notices as described in subsection (1) of this section, and at the option of the building department, notices may also be effected by publication in a local newspaper for a period of four consecutive days. 
(3)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand-deliver or mail notice together with proof of publication shall be sufficient to show that the notice required by this article has been met without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
(Code 1971, § 7-12) 
Sec. 22-43. - Hearings. 
    Hearings before the construction trade board shall be handled in the following manner: 
(1)  Hearings shall be held, whenever there is a case to be heard, on the first Monday of the month. The chairman of the construction trade board may call special hearings upon request of the board, the building department or any person who is the subject of formal complaint. A time and place shall be designated for the hearing and appropriate notice of the hearing shall be served pursuant to the provisions of this article upon the person who is the subject of the formal complaint and any other interested parties not less than eight days prior to the date of the special hearing. 
(2)  Minutes shall be kept of all hearings, specifically including the vote of each member upon each question before the board, and all hearings and other proceedings shall be open to the public. All testimony shall be under oath and electronically recorded. 
(3)  The city may provide a hearing room and clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the board for the proper performance of its duties. 
(4)  Each case before the construction trades board shall be presented by the building department. In addition, the city may employ attorneys to present cases before the board. 
(5)  The board initially shall take testimony from the investigator, inspector, clerk, the alleged violator and any other person whose testimony the board deems necessary. The board shall hear all relevant and competent evidence material to the issues and shall have the power to continue the hearing as in its judgment may be necessary and proper. Alleged violators and complainants shall have the right to appear personally or by counsel and to give testimony, present witnesses and to cross-examine adverse witnesses in person or through their attorneys. 
(6)  After the conclusion of each hearing, the board shall issue findings of fact and conclusions of law based upon the evidence of record and shall issue an order indicating any action taken by the board consistent with the powers granted by this article. The findings shall be by motion approved by a majority of those present and voting. The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specific date and that additional penalties may be imposed if the order is not complied with by such date. Findings of fact need not be issued the same day of the hearing. 
(7)  Every decision or order of the construction trade board shall be promptly filed with the building department and a certified copy shall be forwarded to the violator, the complainant, the department of business and professional regulation and any other interested party. 
(8)  In addition to any action taken by the construction trade board which effects a contractor's license or results in a fine, the board shall issue a recommendation as to further action to be taken by the department of business and professional regulation. The board may recommend that the department of business and professional regulation take no further action or that the department of business and professional regulation order suspension, revocation, restriction of registration or a monetary fine, or any combination thereof. 
(Code 1971, § 7-13) 
Sec. 22-44. - Rehearings. 
    The violator or the building department may petition the construction trade board for a rehearing within ten days of the execution of any order or decision of the board. A petition for a rehearing may be requested only if there is any information directly related to the hearing that was not available to be presented at the original hearing. In its order granting or denying a rehearing, the board shall notify all interested parties pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 7-14) 
Sec. 22-45. - Appeal of order. 
    Any aggrieved party may appeal a final order of the construction trade board to the circuit court. 
(Code 1971, § 7-15) 
Sec. 22-46. - Unlicensed contracting. 
(a)  F.S. §§ 489.127(1), 489.132(1), and 489.531(1), as amended are hereby adopted by reference. A violation of any provision of F.S. §§ 489.127(1), 489.132(1), or 489.531(1), as amended, may be enforced in accordance with F.S. § 162.21, and section 2-291 through section 2-358 of the City Code. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of F.S. §§ 489.127(1), 489.132(1), or 489.531(1), as amended, is a civil infraction. 
(c)  If the person who has committed a civil infraction does not contest the citation, the civil penalty to be assessed by a code enforcement officer shall be $2,000.00 for a violation of any provision of F.S. §§ 489.127(1), 489.132(1), or 489.531(1), as amended. 
(d)  If the person cited contests the citation and the county court finds a violation, the maximum civil penalty to be imposed by the court shall not exceed $2,500.00 per day for each violation of any provision of F.S. §§ 489.127(1), 489.132(1) or 489.531(1), as amended. Court fees and costs shall be assessed in addition to the civil penalty against any person who contests a citation and is found in violation. 
(Ord. No. 3022, § 1, 4-11-18; Ord. No. 3042, § 1, 1-9-19) 
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency management, F.S. ch. 252; authority to declare state of emergency, F.S. § 870.041 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS 

Sec. 26-31. - Declaration of policy. 
(a)  F.S. § 252.38 states that safeguarding the life and property of its citizens is an innate responsibility of the governing body of each political subdivision of the state. 
(b)  In order for the city to fully carry out its responsibility of protecting and ensuring the peace, health and lives of the city's citizens in time of disaster emergency, the council finds and declares it necessary to: 
(1)  Provide for a mechanism to declare a disaster emergency within the city; 
(2)  Provide for the exercise of the emergency powers conferred by F.S. ch. 252; and 
(3)  Prohibit certain acts by the citizens of the city during a disaster emergency when such acts would be detrimental to the overall interests of the other citizens of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-1) 
Sec. 26-32. - Legislative authority. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to the authority conferred by F.S. § 252.38(2). 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-2) 
Sec. 26-33. - Scope. 
    This article shall be effective throughout the city. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-3) 
Sec. 26-34. - Construction. 
    This article shall be liberally construed to accomplish its declared policy. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-4) 
Sec. 26-35. - Definitions. 
    The words, terms and phrases used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in F.S. § 252.34, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-36. - Supremacy of article; rules, regulations and orders. 
    Whenever the provisions of this article or of any part of this article are being exercised, they shall be supreme. Rules, regulations and orders issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article shall, during the time that they are actually being used or executed and to the extent of any conflict, supersede any other rules, regulations and orders with which they may be in conflict. This article being intended to secure to the government the emergency powers and authority required to handle a disaster emergency, it shall take precedence over any law, rule, regulation or order that may interfere with its execution or hinder the ability of city officials and employees to exercise its emergency powers. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-7) 
Sec. 26-37. - Uniformity in actions. 
    In order to attain uniformity in measures taken to mitigate disaster emergencies, all action taken under this article, and all rules, regulations and orders made or issued with due consideration for the orders, rules, regulations, actions, recommendations, and requests of the county, state and federal authorities relevant thereto and to the extent permitted by law, shall be consistent to those orders, rules, regulations, actions, recommendations and requests. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-8) 
State Law reference- Requirement to coordinate with county program, F.S. § 252.38(2). 
Sec. 26-38. - Disaster emergencies; council responsibility. 
(a)  The city council is responsible for meeting the dangers presented to the city and its people by a disaster emergency. The city council may issue proclamations or resolutions and regulations, and amend or rescind them, in the fulfillment of this responsibility, and these proclamations or resolutions and regulations shall have the force and effect of law during the period for which they are effective. During the continuance of a state of disaster emergency, the director shall have direct responsibility for the coordination of all disaster emergency relief activities and efforts, subject only to the direction and control of the council. 
(b)  A disaster emergency shall be declared by proclamation or resolution of the city if it finds that a disaster emergency has occurred or that the occurrence or the threat thereof is imminent. The state of disaster emergency shall continue until the city council finds that the threat or danger has been dealt with to the extent that the disaster emergency conditions no longer exist and the city terminates the state of disaster emergency by proclamation or resolution, but no state of disaster emergency may continue for longer than seven days unless renewed by the proclamation or resolution by the council. In such an event, the renewal may run for periods of 48 hours, as long as the state of disaster emergency continues to exist. At the same time that the state of disaster emergency is declared, the mayor shall convene the council in special meeting at which the director shall report to the council all facts and circumstances concerning the disaster emergency and the director's recommendations in connection therewith. 
A proclamation or resolution issued under this subsection shall indicate the nature of the disaster emergency, the area or areas of the city threatened by it, and the conditions which have brought it about, or which make possible the termination of the state of disaster emergency. A proclamation or resolution issued under this subsection shall be promptly disseminated by means calculated to bring it to the attention of the general public and, unless the circumstances attendant upon the disaster prevent or impede, it shall be promptly filed with the clerk of the circuit court. 
(c)  Whenever a mock or practice disaster alert is to be called for by the director, for the purpose of training and exercising a segment of the people located within the city, then the director shall notify the mayor. In that case, no state of disaster emergency will exist, and no proclamation or resolution shall be issued. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-9) 
Sec. 26-39. - Emergency powers of council. 
(a)  In order to facilitate the activities and efforts associated with the mitigation of disaster emergency, the city council shall have the power and authority to: 
(1)  Appropriate and expend funds; make contracts; obtain and distribute equipment, materials, and supplies for emergency management purposes; provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of any emergency; and direct and coordinate the development of emergency management plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans set by the federal and state emergency management agencies. 
(2)  Appoint, employ, remove, or provide, with or without compensation, coordinators, rescue teams, fire and police personnel, and other emergency management workers. 
(3)  Establish, as necessary, a primary and one or more secondary emergency operating centers to provide continuity of government and direction and control of emergency operations. 
(4)  Assign and make available for duty the offices and agencies of the city, including the employees, property, or equipment thereof relating to firefighting, engineering, rescue, health, medical and related services, police, transportation, construction, and similar items or services for emergency operation purposes, as the primary emergency management forces of the city for employment within or outside the political limits of the city. 
(5)  Request state assistance or invoke emergency-related mutual aid assistance by declaring a state of local emergency in the event of an emergency affecting only the city. The duration of each state of emergency declared locally is limited to seven days. It may be extended, as necessary, in seven-day increments. Further, the city has the power and authority to waive the procedures and formalities otherwise required of the city by law pertaining to: 
a.  Performance of public work and taking whatever prudent action is necessary to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of the community. 
b.  Entering into contracts. 
c.  Incurring obligations. 
d.  Employment of permanent and temporary workers. 
e.  Utilization of volunteer workers. 
f.  Rental of equipment. 
g.  Acquisition and distribution of supplies, with or without compensation, materials, and facilities. 
h.  Appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
(b)  Where circumstances warrant, the city council may designate the director as the individual authorized to discharge the power specified in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 252.38(3)(a). 
Sec. 26-40. - Prohibited activities; exemptions. 
(a)  During a disaster emergency, the following activities are prohibited in the city or in a portion of the city if so designated in the proclamation or resolution: 
(1)  The sale, dispensing or transportation of alcoholic beverages, explosives and combustibles, excluding fuels used for the ordinary and normal propulsion of jet, diesel, kerosene or gasoline or household appliances. 
(2)  The watering of grass or washing of structures, automobiles, boats, airplanes or other motor-propelled vehicles with water supplied by the city. 
(3)  The sale of merchandise by any business establishment at a rate or price that exceeds the rate or price charged immediately prior to the declaration of the disaster emergency by the council. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall have no effect in the following situations: 
(1)  Persons engaged in the prohibited activities solely for the purpose of survival of those persons or the families of those persons. 
(2)  Persons engaged in the prohibited activities solely for the purpose of self-defense. 
(3)  Persons who are duly authorized law enforcement officials in the official performance of duty. 
(4)  Persons who are in the military service and who are acting in the official performance of duty. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-11; Ord. No. 2934, § 2, 9-14-11) 
State Law reference- Automatic emergency measures, F.S. § 870.044; discretionary emergency measures, F.S. § 870.045. 
Sec. 26-41. - Limitations upon liability. 
    No officer, employee or agent of the city shall be held personally liable in tort for any injuries or damages suffered as a result of any act, event or omission of activity in the scope of his duties under this article, or specified by a disaster emergency plan, or assigned or ordered by the city council or director, unless the officer, employee or agent acted in bad faith, or with malicious purpose, or in a manner exhibiting wanton and willful disregard of human rights, safety or property. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-12) 
State Law reference- Liability outside jurisdiction, F.S. § 252.39. 
Sec. 26-42. - Compensation for services. 
(a)  Compensation for services or for the taking or use of private property during a declared state of disaster emergency shall be owed by the city only to the extent that: 
(1)  A claimant may not be deemed to have volunteered his services or property without compensation; and 
(2)  The taking or use exceeds the legal responsibility of the claimant to render the services or make the property available. 
(b)  Compensation owed for personal services during a declared state of disaster emergency shall be only such as the city may have fixed and for which funds shall have been specifically appropriated. Compensation for private property shall be owed only if the property was commandeered or otherwise used in coping with a disaster emergency and its use was ordered by the city council, the director, or an authorized member of the disaster emergency force of the city. A person claiming compensation for the use, damage, loss or destruction of private property or for services shall file a claim with the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(c)  Nothing in this section applies to or authorizes compensation for the damaging or destruction of standing timber or other property in order to provide a firebreak, or damage resulting from the release of waters or the breach of impoundments in order to reduce pressure or other danger from actual or threatened flood. Nothing in this section shall be construed as authorizing compensation to be paid beyond the amount of funds available for this compensation, nor except to the extent that the state legislature may have waived the sovereign immunity of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-13) 
Sec. 26-43. - Liability of private persons. 
    A person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants a license or privilege or otherwise permits the designation or use of the whole or any part of the real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster emergency, together with his successor in interest, if any, shall not be liable for the death of or injury to any person on or about the real estate or premises during an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster emergency or for loss or damage to the property of the person, solely by reason, or as a result of the license, privilege, designation or use, unless gross negligence or willful and wanton conduct of the person owning or controlling the real estate or premises, or of his successor in interest, shall be the proximate cause of the death, injury, loss or damage. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-14) 
Sec. 26-44. - Authority to accept services, materials, funds. 
(a)  When the state or federal government offers to the city services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds, by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of using in an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster emergency, the city council, or when designated, the director, may accept the offer on behalf of the city and utilize the services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. If funds are accepted by the director during an authorized designation, then such funds may be extended only after appropriation by the city council. 
(b)  Whenever a person offers to the city services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds, by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of using in an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster emergency, the city council, or when designated, the director, may accept the offer on behalf of the city and utilize the services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds subject to the terms of the offer. If funds are accepted by the director during an authorized designation, then such funds may be expended only after appropriation by the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-15) 
Sec. 26-45. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1971, § 71/2-16) 
Chapter 30 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Election, term of mayor, § 8; wards designated, § 11; councilmen to be residents of wards from which they are elected, § 12; city officers to hold office until successors elected and qualified, § 28; municipal elections generally, § 59. 
Cross reference- City council, § 2-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- State election code, F.S. chs. 97-104. 

Sec. 30-1. - Wards-Designated and described; polling places. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 11 of the Charter of the City of Bradenton, the city council hereby divides the city into five numerically designated wards by reapportioning same and changing the boundaries thereof to be as follows: 
(1)  Ward 1. North boundary: the city limits; east boundary: 51st Street West ending at Cortez Road and any northerly extension thereof; south boundary: Cortez Road; west boundary: city limits. 
(2)  Ward 2. West boundary: 51st Street West and any Northerly extension thereof and that portion of 66th Street West lying south of Cortez Road; south boundary: city limits, including all that incorporated area south of Cortez Road lying between 43rd Street West and 66th Street West; east boundary: that portion of 43rd Street West lying south of Cortez Road, that portion of the city limits lying south of Sandpointe Drive and 33rd Avenue West, Southern Parkway from Sandpointe Drive to 32nd Street West, 32nd Street West from Southern Parkway to Highland Avenue, 34th Street West from Highland Avenue to 23rd Avenue, 32nd Street from 23rd Avenue to 17th Avenue, 26th Street West from 17th Avenue to Manatee Avenue West, the centerline of Wares Creek from Manatee Avenue to North city limits; north boundary: city limits. 
(3)  Ward 3. West boundary: Southern Parkway from Sandpointe Drive to 32nd Street West, 32nd Street West from Southern Parkway to Highland Avenue, 34th Street West from Highland Avenue to 23rd Avenue, 32nd Street West from 23rd Avenue to 17th Avenue, 26th Street West from 17th Avenue to Manatee Avenue West, centerline of Wares Creek to north city limits; south boundary: city limits; north boundary: city limits; east boundary: 9th Street West. 
(4)  Ward 4. West boundary: 9th Street West; South boundary: Manatee Avenue West and Manatee Avenue east and all that portion of the city limits lying east of Braden River; east boundary: city limits; north boundary: city limits. 
(5)  Ward 5. West boundary: 9th Street West; South boundary: city limits; East boundary: Braden River; North boundary: Manatee Avenue West and Manatee Avenue East. 
(b)  Polling places for the designated wards shall be designated by resolution. 
(Code 1971, § 8-2; Ord. No. 2886, 3-26-08) 
Charter reference- City to be divided into 5 wards, § 11. 
Sec. 30-2. - Same-Constituted voting districts or precincts. 
    Each ward of the city shall constitute an election district or precinct. 
(Code 1971, § 8-3) 
Charter reference- Wards, § 11. 
Sec. 30-3. - Proclamation of elections by mayor; failure of mayor to act; publication. 
    All elections shall be proclaimed by the mayor at least 30 days prior thereto, except that runoff and special elections shall be proclaimed within five days after their necessity is determined. In the case of the refusal or omission of the mayor to make such a proclamation, such proclamation shall be made by the city clerk and treasurer. No want of proclamation, however, nor any defect in such proclamation or defect of notice, shall defeat any general election of any city officers. Notice of such proclamation shall be published in a newspaper having general circulation in the city once each week for four consecutive weeks, four publications being sufficient, the first publication to be not more than 30 days prior to the election, except that all runoff elections and special elections shall be advertised once in a newspaper having general circulation in the city at least seven days prior to the runoff or special election. In all proclamations of elections, the person making the proclamation shall prescribe the method of voting, whether by voting machine, ballot boxes, computers or electromechanical or electronic equipment, or by any other means allowed by state statutes. 
(Code 1971, § 8-4) 
Charter reference- Election dates, § 59. 
Sec. 30-4. - Proclamation to prescribe method of election. 
    The city clerk and treasurer shall see that all city elections are conducted in the proper and legal manner. Subject to the approval of city council, however, the city clerk and treasurer may delegate any or all of the responsibilities for administering the election to the county supervisor of elections. Subject to approval of the city council, the city clerk and treasurer may enter into any necessary contracts for the administration and conduct of an election by the county supervisor of elections. If any such contract is entered into, any required filings of petitions or expense reports or any other documents required to be filed by candidates may be filed with the city clerk and treasurer or the county supervisor of elections. 
(Code 1971, § 8-5) 
Sec. 30-5. - Petitions filed by candidates for mayor and council. 
(a)  Any elector desiring to run for the office of mayor or council member shall file with the city clerk and treasurer at any time after qualifying opens for county and state elections, which is noon of the 71st day prior to the county primary election and not later than the date qualifying closes for county and state elections, which is noon of the 67th day prior to the county primary election, a petition signed by not less than 25 qualified electors, who in the case of the mayor reside within the city at large and which qualified electors, in the case of a council member, reside in the ward in which the candidate for council member resides. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer to publish a notice, not less than two weeks prior to the expiration of the time for the filing of candidates' petitions, in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, one publication being sufficient, which notice shall advise of the date of the close of the period for filing candidates' petitions. The city clerk and treasurer shall preserve in his office all such petitions filed with him for six months after the election for which such petitions were made. 
(c)  Candidates for elective office in the city desiring to run for the office of mayor or councilperson shall have resided in the city for a period of 30 days prior to the first day of qualifying. 
(Code 1971, § 8-6; Ord. No. 2938, § 1, 3-28-12) 
Sec. 30-6. - Names to be placed on ballots. 
    A candidate who has filed a petition signed by 25 electors and who has otherwise qualified as a candidate pursuant to the charter, the Code and the ordinances of the city, is entitled to have his name printed on the official ballot. No candidate's name shall be printed on the ballot, however, who has notified the city clerk and treasurer in writing, at any time prior to the printing of the ballots sufficient to allow the ballots to be printed on time without his name. 
(Code 1971, § 8-7) 
Sec. 30-7. - Preparation of ballots. 
    The city council shall cause ballots to be printed for all general and special elections in substantially the same manner and form as provided for such ballots for the nomination of candidates for county and state offices under the general laws of the state, except as to political party designation. 
(Code 1971, § 8-8) 
Sec. 30-8. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the case of conflict with the state election law and any provision of the city election ordinance, where such conflict is permitted by general law, the city ordinance shall prevail. 
(Code 1971, § 8-9) 
State Law reference- Opening and closing of polls, F.S. § 100.011. 
Sec. 30-9. - Procedure for canvassing votes. 
(a)  The county canvassing board as organized and constituted by F.S. § 102.141, shall act as the canvassing board for canvassing the terms for each city elections. In the event, however, that the county canvassing board is not constituted or there is a special election or referendum to the city that is not concurrent with county wide or state wide elections, then the city clerk and treasurer and city attorney and supervisor of elections shall meet as a canvassing board and canvass the returns of the elections. In the event either the city clerk and treasurer or the city attorney is not available the supervisor of elections shall chose a person to act in his or her place. The canvassing board shall insure that the ballots cast for any election are fairly and accurately counted and shall certify the results of such elections. 
(b)  The canvassing board shall canvass the election returns in accordance with Florida Statutes. 
(c)  At such time as the canvassing board has canvassed the election returns, disposed of any challenges thereto, and ascertained and certified the results, the city clerk and treasurer shall issue a certificate of election to each candidate elected and shall issue a certificate of election of each issue. 
(d)  Recounts shall be governed by and in compliance with the provisions of F.S. ch. 102 and all protests and contests challenging the returns of any elections shall be filed in accordance with said F.S. ch. 102. 
(e)  If in any election, the return as certified, results in a tie vote, the election shall be decided by lot. 
(Code 1971, § 8-20; Ord. No. 2938, §§ 2, 3, 3-28-12) 
Sec. 30-10. - Proclamation of results of election; certificates of election. 
    Upon the canvass being completed and the elections certified the result of the election shall be publicly proclaimed. Certificates of such results shall be prepared containing the names voted for and the number of votes cast for each person. If any question is submitted, the certificate shall also contain the number of votes cast for and against the question. Such certificate shall be delivered without delay to the mayor and city council members. 
(Code 1971, § 8-21; Ord. No. 2938, § 4, 3-28-12) 
Sec. 30-11. - Vote required for election to office; runoff elections. 
    The person receiving a majority of the votes cast for an office shall be declared elected to that office for the term prescribed in the charter. Whenever at any election held by the city no one candidate for a particular office shall have received a majority of the total number of valid votes cast for such office, the city council shall so declare and shall forthwith proceed to call a runoff election between the two candidates for such office who shall have received the two higher numbers of valid votes cast at such first election, which runoff election shall beheld either on the third or fourth Tuesday after the first Monday of November, or on the first Tuesday following the subsequent Thanksgiving holiday after the first election as determined by the city council and proclaimed by the mayor. The manner of calling, conducting, holding, canvassing and making returns of such runoff election shall be in conformity with the provisions of all the elections of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 8-22; Ord. No. 2609, § 1, 10-27-99) 
Sec. 30-12. - Council to inspect returns, declare result. 
    The day after the election is certified by the canvassing board or, if such date falls on a weekend or holiday, the day after that the mayor and city council shall assemble at 12:00 noon in council chambers to review the certifications and returns as a result of the election and enter such result upon the minutes of council. 
(Code 1971, § 8-23; Ord. No. 2938, § 5, 3-28-12) 
Sec. 30-13. - Automatic reelection of unopposed candidates for office of city council. 
(a)  The names of unopposed candidates for the office of city council shall not appear on the general election ballot, unless a write-in candidate has duly qualified. Each unopposed candidate shall be deemed to have voted for himself. 
(b)  If there are only unopposed candidates qualified for election to the city council, the election shall be dispensed with and each unopposed candidate automatically deemed to have won such election shall be sworn in to a new term, as provided in this Code. Those sections of the election code of the city providing for the canvassing of votes and procedures concerning the conduct of an election, in the event that all candidates are unopposed, shall be dispensed with as being an unnecessary expense to the taxpayers. 
(Code 1971, § 8-24) 
Sec. 30-14. - Withdrawal, death or removal of candidate. 
(a)  If the withdrawal of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in only one candidate remaining on the ballot for that office the remaining candidate shall be declared elected and no election for that office shall be required. If after qualifying all candidates have withdrawn or been removed for the ballot or died, and an incumbent is in that office and has not qualified for reelection, the city council at the end of such incumbent's term shall declare a vacancy in such office and proceed to fill that vacancy as per the Charter of the city. Such appointment shall be for a period until the next general election after such appointment. 
(b)  In the event after qualifying, and if the qualifying period has ended and all candidates for that office have withdrawn, been removed or died and a vacancy then exits in that office, the remaining council members shall appoint by majority vote a person otherwise qualified to be council member and that person so appointed shall serve as council member until the next general election for which qualifying has not ended. 
(c)  The name of any qualified candidate who withdrew, died or was removed from the ballot shall not be printed on the ballot, however, if the ballot can not be changed any for vote for that candidate will be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 2938, § 6, 3-28-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2938, § 6, adopted March 28, 2012, amended section 30-14 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 30-14 pertained to vacancy in candidacy and derived from the Code of 1971, § 8-25. 
Chapter 34 - ALARMS AND EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3034, § 1, adopted September 26, 2018, repealed the former chapter 34, §§ 34-31-34-43, and enacted a new chapter 34 as set out herein. The former chapter 34 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1971; Ord. No. 2908, adopted September 9, 2009; Ord. No. 2580, adopted May 27, 1998; and Ord. No. 2996, adopted May 24, 2017. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this chapter is to encourage alarm users and alarm businesses to maintain the operational reliability and the proper use of alarm systems in limiting unnecessary emergency responses to false alarms. 
(b)  This chapter governs alarm systems, requires permits (when deemed necessary), establishes fees, provides penalties for violations, and creates a system of administration. 
(Ord. No. 3034, § 1, 9-26-18) 
Sec. 34-2. - Definitions. 
    Alarm enforcement official means the fire chief or designee, in regards to fire related alarms, and the chief of police or designee(s), in regards to all other alarms, who are responsible for administering and enforcing this chapter. 
    Alarm monitoring company means a person or entity performing or engaged in causing the services of monitoring as defined in F.S. § 489.505(27), as may be periodically amended, and having alarm customers within the territorial jurisdiction of this chapter. 
    Alarm site means any building, structure, facility, or premises, or portion thereof, wherein a separate or discrete alarm system is used, installed, or maintained. 
    Alarm system means any mechanical, electrical, or radio controlled device which is designed to be used for the detection of any unauthorized entry into a building, structure, or facility, or for alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure, or facility, or both, which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when activated, hereafter known as a security alarm; or any such device which emits a sound and transmits a signal or message when activated because of smoke, heat, or fire. Alarm system does not include: 
(1)  A device installed on a vehicle, unless the vehicle is permanently located at the site; or 
(2)  A device designed to alert only the inhabitants of the device site, and that is not audible or visible from the exterior of the structure. 
    Alarm system contractor means a person licensed or required to be licensed under F.S. ch. 489, as an electrical or alarm system contractor, and having alarm customers or performing alarm-related work within the territorial jurisdiction of this chapter. 
    Alarm user means any person or entity that has contracted for monitoring, repair, installation, or maintenance service from an alarm installation company or monitoring company for an alarm system, or that operates as an alarm system which is not monitored, maintained, or repaired under contract, or any person or entity in control of any building, structure, facility, or premises, or portion thereof, containing an alarm system. The term includes condominium or homeowner associations, apartment buildings, and other multifamily living units providing monitoring service via a master agreement to individual owners, residents, or tenants, through any maintenance, rental, or other fee. The term does not include homebuilders engaged in pre-wiring homes or other structures for possible future use by subsequent owners, as long as said alarm systems are not operational. 
    Arming station means a device that allows control of a security alarm system (keypad). 
    Automated dialing device means an alarm system, which automatically sends via telephone, radio, digital, or other means of electronic or electrical communication, a prerecorded voice message or other signal to the city police department, (directly or indirectly) indicating the existence of an emergency situation. 
    Cancellation means the process whereby an official response is terminated, when a security or fire alarm monitoring company (designated by the responsible party) for the premises, notifies the responding police or fire department that there is not an existing situation at the premises requiring an official response to the alarm. This notification must be received in the police or fire communications center prior to the police or fire arrival in order for the alarm to be considered cancelled. A proper cancellation will not be considered a false alarm for purposes of levying of a civil penalty and no civil penalty will be assessed in the event of such a cancellation. 
    Fire alarm system means a fire alarm is a life safety device that is installed in a building according to the fire code and/or ordinance. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or maintenance, or because of the negligent or intentional misuse of the system by the owner, lessee, occupant, or manager of the premises where the alarm is installed, or because of negligence or misuse of the system by an employee, servant, or agent of such person, or any other activation of the alarm system not caused by actual criminal offenses or with evidence of a criminal attempt, or not caused by fire, heat, or smoke. Excluded from this definition are: 
(1)  Alarms occurring during electrical storms, hurricanes, tornados, and other acts of God; where there is clear evidence of physical damage to the system; or 
(2)  The intermittent disruption or disruption of telephone circuits beyond the control of the alarm company and/or alarm user; or 
(3)  Electrical power disruption or failure in excess of four hours. 
    Fine means an administrative penalty and fee for services due to failure to comply with the provisions of chapter 34. 
    Governmental premises means a structure or area owned and/or operated by a government entity. 
    Jurisdiction means the area within the city limits and where the city police department responds to security alarms as the primary law enforcement agency and the city fire department responds to smoke, heat, or fire alarms. 
    Premises means any building, structure, or combination of buildings and structures, including the curtilage thereof, which is used for residential, commercial, or any other purpose. At the option of the responsible party, out buildings, separate or detached buildings may be deemed separate premises for the purpose of registration. 
    Responsible party means any person or entity that owns or controls the premises in which an alarm system is installed, including, but not limited to, a person or entity that leases, operates, occupies, or manages the premises. 
    Verification means an attempt by the monitoring company, or its representative, to contact the alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone and/or other electronic means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement dispatch. Verification shall require, at a minimum, that a second call be made to a different telephone, cell phone, page, or other communication device provided by the alarm user if the first attempt fails to reach an alarm user who can properly identify him or herself. 
(Ord. No. 3034, § 1, 9-26-18) 
Secs. 34-3-34-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECURITY ALARMS AND POLICE DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 34-33. - Alarm permit and fee process. 
(a)  Every person who installs, owns, leases, possesses, or operates any security alarm system within the city shall, within 30 days of the effective date of this chapter or installation thereafter, obtain a security alarm permit prior to activation of the security alarm system. Upon approval of the application, the enforcement official shall issue a security alarm permit, which shall be valid for the calendar year in which the permit was issued. Failure to obtain a security alarm permit will result in a fine assessment for each false security alarm occurrence using a higher fine payment structure than those who obtained a security alarm permit. 
(b)  All permits issued by the enforcement official expire annually on December 31 at 11:59 p.m. Annual renewal applications must be submitted to the enforcement official prior to December 1 to obtain an alarm permit for the following calendar year. 
(c)  For purposes of registration, a system shall be associated with the individual premises, or governmental unit being monitored. 
(d)  On each application, the alarm user shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The alarm user's name, current physical and mailing addresses (if different), contact telephone number(s); 
(2)  The address of the alarm site; 
(3)  Classification of the alarm site-Residential, commercial, governmental, or multi-family complex; 
(4)  Type of alarm system-Burglary, robbery, intrusion, or fire; 
(5)  Name, address, and contact telephone number of two people who have access to the alarm site, the ability to reset the alarm, and will be responsible for responding to the alarm site within 30 minutes of notification; 
(6)  Name, address, telephone number, and state license number of the alarm monitoring company; 
(7)  Name, address, telephone number, and state license number of the company/person responsible for alarm site installation; 
(8)  Name, address telephone number, and state license number of the company/person which performed the most recent maintenance on the alarm system; and 
(9)  Any other information deemed necessary by the chief of police or designee. 
(e)  The responsible person shall provide to the city police department any changes in the information required by section 34-33(d)(1)-(d)(9) within 15 days of such change.
