(2)  If the office of community relations determines that reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, it shall immediately issue a charge on behalf of the aggrieved person. 
(j)  Charge. 
(1)  A charge: 
a.  Shall consist of a short and plain statement of the facts upon which the office of community relations has found reasonable cause to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur; 
b.  Shall be based on the final investigative report; and 
c.  Need not be limited to the facts or grounds alleged in the complaint. 
(2)  Not later than three business days after the office of community relations issues a charge, the office of community relations shall cause a copy thereof, with information as to how to make an election of judicial determination as provided for in this section and the effect of such an election, to be served upon each respondent named in the charge, together with a notice of opportunity for a hearing at a time and place specified in the ordinance, unless an election of judicial determination has been made, and to each complaint or aggrieved person on whose behalf the complaint was filed. 
(k)  Land use law. If the office of community relations determines that the matter involves the legality of a state or local life, health, safety, zoning, land use or other similar ordinance, the office of community relations may not issue a charge without first referring the matter to the city attorney for advice or appropriate action. 
(l)  Dismissal. If the office of community relations determines that no reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, it shall promptly dismiss the complaint and advise each complainant or aggrieved person and respondent. 
(m)  Pending civil trial. The office of community relations may not issue a reasonable cause finding under this section regarding an alleged discriminatory housing practice after the beginning of the trial of a civil action commenced by the aggrieved person under federal or state law seeking relief with respect to that discriminatory housing practice. 
(n)  Election of judicial determination. 
(1)  A complainant, an aggrieved person, or a respondent may elect to have the claims asserted in the complaint decided in a civil action pursuant to subsection 46-35(c). 
(2)  The person making the election shall give written notice thereof within 20 days after the date of receipt by the electing person of service of a copy of the charge or, in the case of the community relations board, not later than 20 days after the charge was issued. Such notice of election shall be given to the office of community relations and to all other complainants, aggrieved persons, and respondents to whom the complaint relates. 
(o)  City attorney action for enforcement. 
(1)  If notice of election is timely given pursuant to subsection (n) above, the community relations board shall authorize the city attorney to file a civil action in the circuit court seeking relief under this section on behalf of the aggrieved person, and such action shall be filed within 30 days of giving such authorization. 
(2)  A complainant or aggrieved person may petition the court for leave to intervene in the action. 
(p)  Administrative hearing. 
(1)  If notice of election is not timely given pursuant to subsection (n) above, the community relations board shall provide for a hearing on the charge. 
(2)  The community relations board shall, in every case, arrange for the hearing to be conducted by the hearing office from the state division of administrative hearings. The hearing shall commence no later than 120 days following the issuance of the charge, unless it is impractical to do so. If the hearing officer is unable to commence, the hearing officer shall notify the director, the aggrieved person on whose behalf the charge is filed, and the respondent, in writing of the reasons for not doing so. 
(3)  The hearing officer shall follow a hearing procedure providing all parties the right to be heard, to be represented by counsel, to present evidence on their own behalf and to conduct cross-examination of witnesses, similar to the procedure for formal proceedings set forth in F.S. § 120.57(1). 
(4)  The city attorney shall provide legal representation for the complainant or aggrieved person in such administrative proceedings; however, representation by the city attorney shall not preclude representation by private legal counsel. 
(5)  The community relations board shall review the hearing officer's recommended order and the record and issue its final order within 30 calendar days of the date it receives the recommended order. 
(6)  A hearing under this section may not continue regarding any alleged discriminatory housing practice after the beginning of the trial of a civil action commenced by the aggrieved person seeking relief with respect to that discriminatory housing practice. 
(7)  The final order of the community relations board shall be subject to judicial review in the circuit court by petition for writ of certiorari in the manner provided by law and the rules of the court. 
(8)  Any resolution of a charge before a final order under this section shall require the consent of the aggrieved person on whose behalf the charge is issued. 
(q)  Effect of community relations board order. A community relations board order shall not affect a contract, sale, encumbrance, or lease that: 
(1)  Was consummated before the community relations board issued the order; and 
(2)  Involved a bona fide purchaser, encumbrancer, or tenant who did not have actual notice of the charge filed under this section. 
(r)  Licensed or regulated business. If the community relations board issues an order with respect to a discriminatory housing practice that occurred in the course of a business subject to a licensing or regulation by a governmental agency, the community relations board shall, not later than the 30th day after the date of the issuance of the order: 
(1)  Send copies of the findings and the order to the governmental agency; 
(2)  Recommend to the governmental agency appropriate disciplinary action. 
(s)  Order in preceding five years. If the community relations board issues an order against a respondent against whom another order was issued within the preceding five years, the community relations board shall send a copy of each order issued under that section to the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 2, 12-23-98; Ord. No. 2641, §§ 6-12, 12-13-00) 
Sec. 46-35. - Remedies; penalties. 
(a)  Temporary or preliminary relief. 
(1)  If the community relations board concludes at any time following the filing of a complaint that prompt judicial action is necessary to carry out the purposes of this section, the city commission shall authorize a civil action for appropriate temporary or preliminary relief pending final disposition of the complaint, in accordance with F.S. § 760.34(8). 
(2)  On receipt of the city commission's authorization, the city attorney shall promptly file the action. 
(3)  The filing of a civil action under this section does not affect the initiation or continuation of administrative proceedings under this section. 
(b)  Administrative penalties. 
(1)  Upon the conclusion of a hearing pursuant to section 46-34(p), if the community relations board believes a respondent has engaged in or is about to engage in a discriminatory housing practice, the community relations board may order the appropriate relief to the aggrieved person, including actual damages for quantifiable injuries, reasonable attorney's fees, costs, and other injunctive or equitable relief, to the extent permitted under applicable federal or state law. 
(2)  After a finding that a particular charge has been sustained, the community relations board may assess a civil penalty against the respondent in an amount that does not exceed: 
a.  $11,000.00 if the respondent has not been adjudged by order of the community relations board or a court to have committed a prior discriminatory housing practice; 
b.  Except as provided in subsection (b)(3) of this section, $27,500.00 if the respondent has been adjudged by order of the community relations board or a court to have committed one other discriminatory housing practice during the five-year period ending on the date of the filing of the charge; and 
c.  Except as provided by subsection (b)(3) of this section, $55,000.00 if the respondent has been adjudged by order of the community relations board or a court to have committed two or more discriminatory housing practices during the seven-year period ending on the date of the filing of the charge. 
(3)  If the acts constituting the discriminatory housing practice that is the object of the charge are committed by the same individual who has been previously adjudged to have committed acts constituting a discriminatory housing practice, the civil penalties in subsections (b)(2)b. and c. of this section may be imposed without regard to the period of time within which any other discriminatory housing practice occurred. 
(4)  Funds collected under this subsection shall be paid to the city and shall be used to offset expenses incurred by the city in enforcing this article, and in carrying out other efforts to further fair housing within the city. 
(5)  The penalties provided for in subsection (b) of this section are applicable regardless of whether the community relations board or an aggrieved party initiated the investigation. 
(c)  Private civil actions. 
(1)  A complainant or aggrieved person may file a civil action in the circuit court pursuant to F.S. § 760.35, not later than two years after an alleged discriminatory housing practice has occurred. 
(2)  An aggrieved person may file an action regardless of whether he or she has filed a complaint, and regardless of the status of any complaint filed under this section, unless: 
a.  The office of community relations has obtained a conciliation agreement with the consent of the aggrieved person; or 
b.  An administrative law judge has commenced a hearing on the record with respect to the charge. 
(3)  In such civil action, the plaintiff may seek a declaratory judgment, preliminary or temporary and permanent injunctive relief, actual and punitive damages, and costs and reasonable attorney's fees, as permitted by the court, or other order as the court determines is just and proper. 
(4)  Upon authorization by the city council, the city attorney may intervene in a private civil action brought by a complainant or aggrieved person, if the city commission certifies that the case is of significant public importance to the citizens of the city. 
(5)  If a complainant or respondent is unable to pay the costs of an attorney, the court may appoint an attorney on behalf of the complainant or respondent or authorize the commencement or continuation of the civil action without payment of fees, costs, or security, if in the opinion of the court such person is financially unable to bear the costs of such action. 
(d)  Judicial review. Any party to the complaint shall have the right to petition for judicial review of the final order of the community relations board in a court of competent jurisdiction. Such review shall be limited to a review of the final order and the record of the proceedings conducted by the community relations board under this section. A reviewing court may modify, revoke or remand the final order only upon a finding that such order is not supported by substantial competent evidence or that the proceedings did not comply with the essential requirements of law. 
(e)  Petitions for enforcement. The community relations board or any person entitled to relief under a final order issued under section 46-34 may seek enforcement of the order by filing a petition for enforcement in the circuit court. Such petition for enforcement may request declaratory relief, temporary or permanent equitable relief, a fine, forfeiture, penalty, or money judgment for actual damages, attorney's fees, and costs, or combination thereof, as provided in the community relations board's final order, or other order as the court determines is just and proper. 
(f)  Pattern or practice cases. 
(1)  Upon request of the city council, the city attorney shall file a civil action in the circuit court for appropriate relief if the city commission has reasonable cause to believe that: 
a.  A person is engaged in a pattern or practice of resistance to the full enjoyment of any right granted by this article; or 
b.  A person has been denied any right granted by this article and that denial raises an issue of general public importance. 
(2)  In an action under this subsection, the court may make such awards and order such relief as is provided for under F.S. § 760.35. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 2, 12-23-98; Ord. No. 2641, §§ 13-15, 12-13-00) 
Secs. 46-36-46-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ASSISTANCE PROGRAM 

Sec. 46-56. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article and the plans, program and committee established hereby, the definitions established by F.S. § 420.9071 and Fl. Admin. Code, rule 9I-37.002, are incorporated by reference. 
(Code 1971, § 13-41) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-57. - Local housing assistance trust fund. 
(a)  Creation. The local housing assistance trust fund ("trust fund") is hereby created and established. 
(b)  Deposit and administration of funds. All moneys received from the state pursuant to the state housing initiative partnership act ("SHIP") and any other funds received or budgeted to provide funding for the local housing assistance program ("program") shall be deposited into the trust fund. Administration of the trust fund shall comply with Fl. Admin. Code, rule 9I-37.007, and any funds deposited into the trust fund will be subject to the requirements of the SHIP program (F.S. § 420.9075(4)). 
(c)  Expenditures. Expenditures other than for the administration and implementation of the program shall not be made from the trust fund. 
(d)  Investments. Amounts on deposit in the trust fund shall be invested in accordance with the Laws of Florida. All investment earnings shall be retained in the trust fund and used for the purposes authorized by this article. 
(e)  Holdings in trust. Until utilized, moneys in the trust fund shall be held by the city in trust solely for use pursuant to the program. All program income, including investment earnings, shall be retained in the trust fund and used for the purposes authorized by this article. 
(f)  Separately stated on financial statements. The city agrees that the trust fund shall be separately stated as a special revenue fund in the city's audited financial statements. Copies of such audited financial statements shall be made available upon request to the Florida Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) as soon as such statements are available. 
(Code 1971, § 13-42) 
Sec. 46-58. - Local housing partnership. 
(a)  Creation. The local housing partnership ("partnership") is hereby created and established. 
(b)  Inclusion. The partnership shall include, but is not limited to, the city, community-based organizations, for-profit housing developers, lending institutions, providers of professional services relating to affordable housing and service organizations working on behalf of persons with special housing needs. 
(c)  Implementation. The partnership shall implement the program in a manner that provides for homeownership and rental housing activities, and other activities that create or preserve affordable housing and which provide for the administration of the program. Such implementation shall be consistent with the provisions of this article, F.S. §§ 420.907-420.9079, and F.A.C., rule 9I-37. 
(Code 1971, § 13-43) 
Sec. 46-59. - Program-Intent and purpose. 
(a)  The intent of the program is to: 
(1)  Increase the availability of affordable housing units by combining local resources and cost-saving measures into a partnership using private and public funds to reduce the cost of housing; 
(2)  Assist in achieving the growth management goals contained in the city's comprehensive plan by allowing more efficient use of land so as to provide increased housing units that are affordable to and economic opportunities for persons who have very low income, low income, moderate income or special housing needs; 
(3)  Promote innovative design of eligible housing that provides cost savings, flexible design options for housing and development (such as the combination of architectural styles, building forms and development requirements) and positive features (such as orientation toward the street and pedestrian access) without compromising the quality of the eligible housing; and 
(4)  Build the organizational and technical capacity of community-based organizations so as to optimize the role of community-based organizations in the production of affordable housing. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to aid in achieving the intent of the program while providing for: 
(1)  Protection of natural resources; 
(2)  Community development and economic growth; and 
(3)  A strong sense of community through increased social and economic integration. 
(Code 1971, § 13-44) 
Sec. 46-60. - Same-Establishment. 
(a)  The program is hereby created and established. 
(b)  The partnership shall use the funds received from the state pursuant to SHIP to implement the program. Approximately 95 percent of the SHIP funds shall be distributed in the following manner: 
(1)  Down payment assistance for new construction of first-time, owner-occupied single-family residences; and 
(2)  Rehabilitation of owner-occupied single-family residences. 
(c)  The city hereby finds the cost of administering the program shall not exceed five percent of the funding received from the state pursuant to SHIP. 
(d)  The program shall include all other lawful objectives not previously listed if such objectives have been adopted into the local housing assistance plan (L.H.A. plan) in the manner provided for by F.S. §§ 420.907-420.9079, and F.A.C., rule 9I-37. 
(Code 1971, § 13-45) 
Sec. 46-61. - Same-Designation of responsibility for administration and implementation. 
(a)  The partnership shall be responsible for implementation and administration of the program. However, if the city council determines it to be in the best interest of the public, all or part of the administration or other functions of the program may be contracted to a third person or entity. 
(b)  The city shall designate at least one city employee whose responsibility shall be to: 
(1)  Work with the partnership to monitor the success of the program and provide advice and suggestions as to whether and in what ways the program might be improved from year to year; and 
(2)  Work with the partnership participants to coordinate local programs such as community loan funds, inclusionary housing programs, and linkage programs with state programs such as the housing predevelopment trust fund, homeownership assistance program (HAP), single-family mortgage revenue bond (MRB) program and state apartment incentive loan (SAIL) program, and with federal programs such as the community development block grant (CDBG) program, home investment partnership program (HOME), low income rental housing tax credit (LIHTC) program, and section 8 rental assistance so as to maximize the production of eligible housing through the program. 
(c)  The total amount paid for any administrative expenses in connection with the program will not exceed five percent of the proceeds of the local housing distribution. 
(d)  In implementing the program, the partnership shall: 
(1)  Advertise the availability of a housing assistance program in a newspaper of general circulation and periodicals serving ethnic and diverse neighborhoods at least 30 days before the beginning of any application period. 
(2)  Adopt a maximum award schedule or system of awards to comply with the following criteria: 
a.  Sixty-five percent of the funds shall be reserved for homeownership for eligible persons; 
b.  Seventy-five percent of the funds shall be reserved for construction, rehabilitation or emergency repair of eligible housing; 
c.  The sales price of new or existing eligible housing shall not exceed 90 percent of the median area purchase price in the area where the eligible housing is located as established by the United States Department of Treasury in accordance with section 3(b)2 of the United States Housing Act of 1937; 
d.  All units constructed, rehabilitated or otherwise assisted with program funds shall be occupied by very low income, low income or moderate income persons and persons who have special housing needs. At least 30 percent of the units must be occupied by very low income persons and at least another 30 percent by low income persons. The remainder shall be occupied by persons who have special housing needs or moderate income persons; 
e.  The amount of monthly mortgage payments or the amount of monthly rents charged by the eligible sponsor or its designee must be affordable to eligible persons; 
f.  Loans shall be provided for periods not exceeding 30 years, except for deferred payment loans or loans that extend beyond 30 years which continue to provide eligible housing for eligible persons; 
g.  Eligible owner-occupied housing constructed, rehabilitated or otherwise assisted from proceeds provided from the program shall be subject to subsidy recapture provisions which are identical to those specified in section 143(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; 
h.  Eligible rental housing constructed, rehabilitated or otherwise assisted from proceeds provided from the program shall be reserved for eligible persons for the greater of 15 years or the term of the assistance. Eligible sponsors who offer eligible rental housing for sale before 15 years or that have remaining mortgages funded under the program must give a first right of refusal to eligible nonprofit organizations for purchase for continued occupancy by eligible persons; 
i.  The cost per unit and the maximum cost per unit for eligible housing benefitting from awards made pursuant to the program shall be established by resolution; 
j.  A qualification system for applicants for awards consistent with the intent of the program and F.S. §§ 420.907-420.9079 shall be established by the affordable housing advisory committee; and 
k.  The partnership shall annually monitor and determine tenant eligibility and amount of subsidy pursuant to the provisions of this article, F.S. §§ 420.907-420.9079 and Fl. Admin. Code, rule 9I-37.015. 
(e)  The city, partnership participants and all eligible sponsors shall not discriminate in the loan application process of eligible persons for eligible housing on the basis of race, creed, religion, color, age, sex, marital status, familial status, national origin or handicap. 
(f)  The city shall comply with all rules and regulations of the FHFA in connection with required reporting by the city of compliance with its program. 
(g)  Prior to receiving an award, all eligible persons or eligible sponsors shall enter into an agreement to comply with the affordable housing criteria provided under this article and F.S. §§ 420.907-420.9079. All eligible persons or eligible sponsors shall include in the deed transferring ownership of the property to the eligible person or eligible sponsor a covenant agreeing to comply with the terms of the above-described laws, which covenant will run with the land or, in the alternative, the agreement shall be made a part of the mortgage agreement. Failure to comply with the covenant in the mortgage shall result in a default of the mortgage with all remedies and rights for enforcement inuring to the benefit of the city. 
(h)  Eligible sponsors receiving assistance from both the SHIP program and the low income housing tax credit (LIHTC) program shall be required to comply with the income, affordability and other LIHTC requirements. Similarly, any eligible sponsors receiving assistance from SHIP and other federal programs shall be required to comply with any requirements specified by the federal program in addition to SHIP requirements. 
(Code 1971, § 13-46) 
Sec. 46-62. - Affordable housing advisory committee. 
(a)  Creation. The affordable housing advisory committee ("advisory committee") is hereby created and established. The members of the advisory committee shall be appointed by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Definition of "affordable housing." The resolution appointing the advisory committee shall define affordable housing as applicable to the city in a way that is consistent with the city's comprehensive plan. 
(c)  Number of members; quorum; types of members. The advisory committee shall consist of nine members. Five members shall constitute a quorum. The advisory committee may not take formal action unless a quorum is present but may meet to hear presentations if duly noticed. The advisory committee shall include the following: 
(1)  One citizen who is actively engaged in the residential building industry. 
(2)  One citizen who is actively engaged in the banking and mortgage industry. 
(3)  One citizen who is a representative of those areas of labor engaged in home building. 
(4)  One citizen who is designated as an advocate for low income persons. 
(5)  One citizen who is a provider of affordable housing. 
(6)  One citizen who is a real estate professional. 
(7)  Three citizens appointed as determined by the city council. 
(d)  Terms. Members of the advisory committee shall serve two-year terms and may be reappointed for subsequent terms. Appointments shall be made by the mayor with the approval of the city council. All members of the advisory committee shall serve until their respective successors have been appointed and qualified; provided, that the terms of the original members may be staggered so that all terms may not expire simultaneously. Each appointment to fill a vacancy shall be for the unexpired term and shall likewise be made by the mayor with approval of the city council. 
(e)  Meetings. Meetings of the advisory committee shall be held monthly for the first year of committee existence. 
(f)  Compliance with public meeting and record laws. All meetings of the advisory committee are public meetings and the advisory committee shall comply with the public records law and the special provisions regarding notice regarding plan considerations found in F.S. § 420.9076. Minutes of the meetings shall be kept by the city clerk and treasurer or his designee. 
(g)  Officers. The advisory committee shall annually elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson and such other officers as it deems necessary. The chairperson is charged with the duty of conducting meetings in a manner consistent with law. 
(h)  Support. Staff, administrative and facility support for the advisory committee shall be provided by the city. 
(i)  Review of policies, procedures, and regulations. The advisory committee shall review the established policies and procedures, ordinances, land development regulations and adopted local comprehensive plan of the city and shall recommend specific initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing while protecting the ability of the property to appreciate in value. 
(j)  Recommendations. Recommendations of the advisory committee may include the modification or repeal of existing policies, procedures, ordinances, regulations or plan provisions. At a minimum, the advisory committee shall make recommendations on affordable housing incentives in the following areas: 
(1)  The affordable housing definition in the appointing resolution. 
(2)  The expedited processing of permits for affordable housing projects. 
(3)  The modification of fee requirements, including reduction or waiver of fees and alternative methods of fee payment. 
(4)  The allowance of increased density level. 
(5)  The reservation of infrastructure capacity for housing for very low income persons and low income persons. 
(6)  The transfer of development rights as a financing mechanism for housing for very low income persons and low income persons. 
(7)  The reduction of parking and setback requirements. 
(8)  The allowance of zero lot lines. 
(9)  The modification of sidewalk and street requirements. 
(10)  The establishment of a process by which the city considers, before adoption, procedures and policies that have a significant impact on the cost of housing. 
(k)  Inclusion of other incentives. The advisory committee's recommendations shall also include other affordable housing incentives identified by the advisory committee. 
(l)  Quantification of housing cost reduction. To the maximum extent feasible, the approved affordable housing incentive recommendations submitted to the city council must quantify the affordable housing cost reduction anticipated from implementing the specific recommendation. 
(m)  Adoption of housing incentive recommendations. Within nine months from the adoption of this article, the advisory committee shall make recommendations approved by a majority of its membership at a public hearing. Notice of the time, date and place of the public hearing of the advisory committee to adopt final affordable housing incentive recommendations shall be published in a newspaper of general paid circulation in the city. Such notice shall contain a short and concise summary of the affordable housing incentive recommendations to be considered by the advisory committee. The notice shall also state the public place where a copy of the tentative advisory committee recommendation can be obtained by interested persons. 
(Code 1971, § 13-47) 
Sec. 46-63. - Adoption of affordable housing incentive plan. 
(a)  Within 90 days after the date of the receipt of the affordable housing incentive recommendations from the advisory committee, the city council shall adopt a plan. The plan shall consist of the adoption of specific initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing and a schedule for implementation and must include, as a minimum: 
(1)  A schedule for implementation of expedited permit processing for affordable housing projects; and 
(2)  An ongoing process for review of local policies, ordinances, regulation and comprehensive plan provisions that significantly impact the cost of housing. 
(b)  Upon adoption of the plan required by this section, the city council shall so notify the FHFA by certified mail. The notice shall include a copy of the approved plan. 
(Code 1971, § 13-48) 
Chapter 50 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 62. 
State Law reference- Uniform traffic control law, F.S. ch. 316. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Adoption of Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law. 
    There is hereby adopted in the city the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, as such law may be amended from time to time by the state legislature and the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 16-1) 
Sec. 50-2. - Removal and impounding of illegally parked, abandoned and disabled vehicles. 
    Members of the police department of this city are hereby authorized to remove and shall cause to be removed any vehicle from any street, alley or city parking lot within the city, to a public garage or other place of safety, under the circumstances enumerated as follows: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended on a sidewalk, in front of a public or private driveway, within six feet of a fire hydrant, within an intersection or in a crosswalk. 
(2)  When properly signposted, warning vehicle operators of the nature and hazard of such area, any vehicle left unattended within 20 feet of a driveway entrance to a fire station or on the side of a street opposite the entrance of any fire station within 70 feet of such entrance; alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking will obstruct traffic. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended at any place where official signs prohibit parking, stopping or standing. 
(4)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any street or in any city parking lot for any period of time longer than 24 hours in the downtown fire district or 48 hours in any other district. 
(5)  When a vehicle upon a street or alley is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, or the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury or condition incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(6)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any street or alley and is parked illegally and such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to normal movement of traffic. 
(7)  When any vehicle which has on at least ten prior occasions been found stopped, standing or parked on any street, alley or thoroughfare within the city in violation of a city ordinance or parking meter regulation or for which the registered or titled owner has failed or refused to appear in response to an existing warrant, citation or summons for such offenses and such vehicle is found parked on any street, alley or thoroughfare or public property within the city. 
(8)  Impounding and storage charges. The cost of towing, removing and storing a vehicle impounded under this section shall be chargeable against the owner and shall be a lien upon the vehicle. The owner of the vehicle shall pay these charges together with all unpaid fines before the vehicle will be released. The vehicle may be stored in a public or private place. If the vehicle is stored in a private place the amount charged for storage shall be the amount the city must pay for the vehicle's storage. For vehicles stored on city property, the charges for storage are on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. The charges to the owner for towing shall be the cost of towing to the city. 
(9)  Notice to the owner. Upon taking possession of any such vehicle, as provided in this section, the police department shall endeavor to notify the owner thereof that such vehicle has been impounded and is being held. A notice shall be given to the person to whom the vehicle is licensed in accordance with the registration list furnished by the office of motor vehicles. The notice shall be served within a reasonable time by certified mail or in person and a charge which is filed in the city clerk and treasurer's office for the giving of such notice shall be collected at the time the vehicle is returned to the owner thereof. 
(10)  Recovery. The registered owner of such vehicle shall be entitled to recover such vehicle only after making payment for the charges provided for in this section. The registered owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for paying the charges and fines as provided for in this section whether such registered owner was the person who unlawfully parked or left standing such vehicle or not, unless such vehicle was reported as stolen. In each instance the police department shall require payment of the sums provided for in this section before restoring to the registered owner possession of such vehicle. 
(11)  Sale of unredeemed vehicles. If the impounded vehicle is not claimed and all charges paid within 30 days after the police or police officers have given notice of taking possession of such vehicle, an action may be commenced in the county court or other court having jurisdiction in the name of the city as plaintiff and against the registered owner as defendant for the amount of such charges. 
(12)  In lieu of towing or removing a vehicle, such vehicle may be incapacitated by use of a wheel locking device or similar device used for the purpose of incapacitating a vehicle. This subsection shall not require the use of any such device and it shall remain the sole discretion of the city and the members of the police department whether or not to purchase or use such a device. 
(Code 1971, § 16-6) 
State Law reference- Abandoned property, F.S. ch. 705; abandoned vehicles, F.S. § 715.101 et seq. 
Sec. 50-3. - Hitchhiking prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to stand or loiter upon or adjacent to any sidewalk, street, avenue, alley, public highway, or public grounds within the limits of the city for the purpose of "thumbing," requesting, asking or soliciting a ride for himself or any other person from the operator of any motor vehicle. It shall further be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to offer or give a ride to any person requesting, asking, soliciting or "thumbing" a ride from any sidewalk, street, avenue, alley, highway or public grounds or from property adjacent thereto. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prevent a person upon or adjacent to a sidewalk, street, avenue, alley, public highway or public grounds from soliciting, or a driver of a vehicle from giving, a ride where an emergency actually exists, nor to prevent a person from signalling or requesting transportation from a vehicle for hire for the purpose of becoming a passenger thereon for hire. 
(Code 1971, § 17-8(a), (c)) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit hitchhiking, F.S. § 316.008. 
Secs. 50-4-50-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-36. - Prohibited in specified places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing, and it shall be unlawful for the registered owner of any vehicle to park or leave standing or to permit another to park or leave standing, any vehicle: 
(1)  In any metered or unmetered parking space for a period of time longer than that allowed in such space authorized by signs or meters. 
(2)  Unoccupied and upon a public street of the city at any place, in a manner, or for a length of time, prohibited by an ordinance of the city or prohibited by law. 
(3)  Upon a public street for a continuous length of time in excess of 48 hours; provided, that nothing herein shall operate to extend the hours of limited parking as indicated by authorized meters and signs. 
(4)  In any city off-street parking lot in excess of 48 hours. 
(5)  In excess of 25 feet in length in designated parking spaces except for emergency breakdowns and for unloading or loading purposes. 
(6)  On the property or premises of another without the permission of the owner or occupant of such property or premises. 
(7)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(8)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(9)  Displaying advertising. 
(10)  Storage, or as junk or dead storage for more than 24 hours. 
(11)  The city clerk and treasurer and his authorized personal representatives during the performance of their official duties in enforcing this section may park their vehicles in all areas designated no parking, or in which parking is prohibited by ordinance. 
(12)  Where any angle parking is provided, to back any vehicle into such parking space. 
(13)  In a parking space in which there is already parked or left standing another motor vehicle. 
(14)  Each vehicle parked on a public street with marked spaces, in a city parking lot with marked spaces or in a city parking garage with marked spaces shall be parked wholly within a marked parking space. Failure to do so shall be unlawful. 
(15)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle by backing into any parking space both within or outside any parking garage where such method of parking into is designated as being prohibited. 
(16)  It is unlawful to park any vehicle in any parking space designated as an electric vehicle charging station except for the purposes of charging such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 16-4; Ord. No. 2866, § 1, 6-27-07; Ord. No. 2916, § 1, 4-14-10; Ord. No. 2943, § 1, 9-26-12) 
Sec. 50-37. - Designation of parking spaces, loading zones, safety zones. 
(a)  Generally. In order to assure an orderly flow of traffic and to provide for maximum utilization of street parking areas, the city council hereby authorizes the city clerk and treasurer to mark off and designate street parking spaces, loading zones, taxistands, bus stops, safety zones and driveways. He is also authorized to determine the maximum time for parking on specified streets. Such determinations shall be made in accordance with provisions of the state uniform traffic control law and city parking meter bond resolutions. Determinations shall be made in writing and shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and treasurer and available to the public and shall be of the same force and effect as though set forth in this article. 
(b)  Parking fees. Parking fees for the city shall be adopted by resolution of the city council. A copy of the resolution shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and treasurer and available to the public and of the same force and effect as if set forth in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 16-2) 
Sec. 50-38. - Curb loading zones, bus stops, taxistands. 
(a)  The city clerk and treasurer is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating such zones and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. 
(d)  The city clerk and treasurer is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets, in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop, bus stand, taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(e)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than a bus stand so designated as provided in this section. 
(f)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with a bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(g)  No parking zones may be designated by sign or by painting the curb adjacent to the no parking zone yellow. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle adjacent to a yellow curb or in a no parking zone. 
(h)  Loading zones may be painted red or designated by sign, or both. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in a loading zone when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. Unless otherwise stated on an applicable sign, loading zone hours shall be 24 hours per day. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any motor vehicle on any sidewalk. 
(Code 1971, § 16-5) 
Sec. 50-39. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  (1)  For each violation of parking in a timed space on a city roadway for a period of time in excess of that permitted, the fine shall be $25.00. For each additional time period between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, in which a violation occurs there shall result an additional fine of $15.00 subject to a vehicle receiving a maximum of three fines in any 12-hour period. 
(2)  For each violation of parking in metered parking space for a period of time in excess of that permitted the fine shall be $15.00. 
(3)  For any vehicle parking in a fire lane the fine shall be $30.00. 
(4)  For any vehicle parking in a space designated as a handicap zone such as those handicap zones designated by the international symbol of accessibility or the caption "parking by disabled permit only" the fine shall be the amount of $200.00. 
(5)  The fine for any violation of this article not otherwise specifically provided for in this section shall be $25.00. 
(6)  In addition, there shall be levied and charged and collected the delinquency charge of $10.00 for each fine not paid within ten days from the date of citation, unless a parking violation hearing has been requested. These fines shall not apply to section 50-1 and may be cumulative to other penalties provided by ordinance and by law. 
(b)  Any person wishing to request a preliminary parking ticket review shall make such request within three days of the date of the violation and the parking enforcement supervisor shall make a determination within five days of receiving a parking ticket preliminary review request. The determination can affirm the issuance of the ticket, dismiss the ticket, or allow for a reduction in the penalty. The request for a preliminary parking ticket review will not toll any time periods herein. The preliminary review shall at a minimum allow review of an improperly written ticket, or a vehicle which has been sold or stolen and is no longer the property of the registered owner of the license plate affixed to the vehicle when the ticket was written. 
(c)  If any person or owner of any vehicle wishes to contest the issuance of a parking ticket, such individual may apply to the parking enforcement supervisor for a hearing to determine whether or not such parking ticket was issued in accordance with the rules and regulations of the ordinances of the city. Requests shall include a complete name and address of the person requesting the hearing, and if available, a phone number and email address. A copy of the parking ticket, a copy of the requester's driver's license, and a copy of the vehicle registration must be included with the request for a hearing. Upon such a request, a notice of hearing will be issued, confirming the time and date of the hearing. The chief of police will designate a hearing officer, who may, upon a proper showing by the complaining party, void or cancel the parking ticket if, in his reasonable determination, he finds that such parking ticket was not properly issued. The request for a hearing shall be made within five days from the date of receiving such parking ticket or citation, and shall be heard within five days from the date of the request or as soon as practicable thereafter. The delinquency charge provided in subsection (a), during the time which the appeal is pending, shall not accrue. 
(d)  The notice of hearing will state: 
(1)  The date, time, and location of a pre-scheduled parking violation hearing; 
(2)  That a person who elects to contest the ticket may be assessed a penalty of up to $100.00 if found in violation after a hearing by a hearing officer, unless otherwise authorized or prohibited by law; 
(3)  That a person who elects to contest a violation and then fails to appear at the parking violation hearing shall be deemed to have waived this or her right to a hearing and may be found in violation by default subject to a penalty of up to $100.00, unless otherwise authorized or prohibited by law; 
(4)  That unpaid violations will be in delinquent status and are subject to being sent to collections for payment. 
(e)  Cancellation or continuances of hearings; burden of proof; payment after hearing. 
(1)  A scheduled parking violation hearing will be cancelled if full payment of the pending violation(s) is received prior to the hearing date. A person wanting to continue a parking violation hearing date shall deliver a written request for continuance to the parking enforcement supervisor at least 72 hours prior to the hearing date and shall be granted one continuance and provided notice of the rescheduled parking violation hearing time and date. 
(2)  A violation shall be proven at a hearing by the preponderance of the evidence. 
(3)  A finding of violation requires all penalties and costs to be paid within seven (7) calendar days unless additional time is granted by the hearing officer. 
(4)  Failure to pay outstanding penalties or costs after a finding of a violation at a hearing shall result in the ticket being in delinquent status if not paid within the time period allowed. 
(f)  In addition to any civil actions instituted by the city, the city may institute proceedings under F.S. chs. 316 and 318 to charge the violator with a noncriminal traffic infraction. Each violation shall be the subject of a separate action under such statutes. 
(g)  In addition to any criminal or noncriminal traffic infractions instituted by the city, the city may institute civil proceedings in a court of appropriate jurisdiction to collect all fines incurred. For the purposes of such civil action, all fines may be deemed to have accumulated and may be sought and collected in one civil action. In addition to all fines, the defendant shall be responsible for all court costs and reasonable attorneys' fees incurred by the city. 
(h)  Any person who parks a vehicle in a parking space designated for handicapped or disabled only or by the international symbol of accessibility, or the caption "parking by disabled permit only," or by both such symbol and caption, shall be fined the amount of $200.00. 
(i)  A list of persons having three or more outstanding parking tickets or an unpaid ticket handicapped parking violation shall be maintained as follows: 
(1)  The city police department, or its designated representatives, shall furnish to the clerk of the county court or traffic violations bureau and the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles (DHSMV), or its successors ,a list by electronic means which is compatible with the computer system of the DHSMV, or its successors, of persons having three or more outstanding parking violations or any violations for parking in spaces designated for use by handicapped or disabled persons as set forth in F.S. §§ 316.1955 and 316.1956, as from time to time may amended and this chapter. If at any time the DHSMV requires such list be furnished in any different format or additional formats the city police department or its designated representative, shall have the authority to comply with such request. The provisions of F.S. § 320.03(8), as from time to time amended, shall apply to each person that appears on such list. 
(2)  Under the authority of F.S. § 320.03(8), as amended, if the name of an applicant for a license plate or revalidation sticker appears on the list referred to in subsection (f)(1) and F.S. § 316.1967(6), the license plate or revalidation sticker shall not be issued until the applicant's name no longer appears on the list or until the applicant presents a receipt from the police department showing the parking fines have been paid. 
(j)  The city and its police department is hereby authorized to participate in a traffic violations bureau, including any division of such bureau established for the city by the circuit court in and for the county, and the city's police department and the city clerk and treasurer's office are authorized to execute any necessary documents to participate in such bureau and comply with any orders issued by the circuit court and the state department of highway safety and motor vehicles. 
(Code 1971, § 16-9; Ord. No. 2766, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-04; Ord. No. 2954, § 1, 9-25-13; Ord. No. 3019, § 1, 2-14-18) 
Sec. 50-40. - Parking, placing, locating large commercial vehicles on city streets restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park, place or locate any commercial vehicle larger than a three-quarter-ton truck on any public street within the city, except while loading and unloading such vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park, place or locate any commercial vehicle larger than a three-quarter-ton truck in any residential zoning district within the city, except while loading and unloading such vehicle. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to park any travel trailer, boat trailer, utility trailer and any other trailer or any licensed or unlicensed vehicle that is towed or transported by another motorized vehicle on any public street, public park or parking lot within the city limits for a period longer than six hours except for loading or unloading. At no time during the aforementioned six-hour period shall the trailer or towed vehicle be detached from the towing vehicle. At no time during the aforementioned six-hour period that any trailer is parked shall it be used for any living purposes. 
    The penalty for any violation of this provision shall be as per section 50-39 above. 
(Code 1971, § 21-18; Ord. No. 2563, § 1, 11-13-96) 
Secs. 50-41-50-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - METERS 

Sec. 50-56. - Installation. 
    In order to implement this article, the city clerk and treasurer is hereby authorized to install parking meters and spaces at the curbline, alongside of or next to individual parking spaces in the manner provided by uniform traffic law and city parking meter bond resolutions. Each parking meter shall be set so as to display a signal indicating whether or not the individual parking space adjacent thereto is in use. Each parking meter shall be installed and set to display a signal indicating legal parking upon deposit therein of the required coin or coins of the United States of America. Upon the deposit of the required coin or coins, such signal shall indicate legal parking for the period of time lawfully designated for that area. Such designations shall be made in writing by the city clerk and treasurer and maintained in his office and shall have the same effect as if set forth at length in this article. The determinations shall be made using standards set forth to section 50-37. Each meter shall be so arranged that upon the expiration of the time paid for, it will indicate by mechanical operation that the lawful parking period has expired. The city clerk and treasurer shall provide for the installation, regulation, control, operation and use of the parking meters provided for in this division and shall maintain such meters in good workable condition. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3(a)) 
Sec. 50-57. - Period of operation; use. 
(a)  Parking meters shall be in operation from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(b)  When any vehicle shall be parked in any space alongside of or next to which there is located a parking meter, the owner, operator or driver of the vehicle shall, upon entering the parking space, immediately deposit a coin of the United States, in the amount as may be designated by the parking meter, in the parking meter alongside of or next to the parking space, and the parking space may be used by the vehicle during the legal parking limit or during such part of the legal limit as shall be allocated for the particular type of coin deposited, which parking period shall be as allowed for that part of the street in which the parking space is located. If the motor vehicle shall remain parked in the parking space for longer than the time allotted for the type of coin deposited in the parking meter, or for longer than the legal parking limit, the parking meter shall display a sign showing illegal parking. 
(c)  The parking of any vehicle for longer than the legal period of time as may be allotted for the type of coin deposited shall be unlawful and a violation of this division. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any motor vehicle of which he shall be the driver or which shall have been registered or licensed in his name to be parked beyond the lawful legal period of time permitted and on record in the office of the city clerk and treasurer or beyond the period of time that may be allotted to the motor vehicle by the type of coin deposited in the parking meter. 
(d)  Each vehicle shall be parked wholly within the metered parking space for which the meter shows parking privilege has been granted. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3(b)-(e)) 
Sec. 50-58. - Violations. 
(a)  Use of slugs, misshaped coins. It is a violation of this division for any person to deposit or attempt to deposit in any parking meter anything other than a lawful coin of the United States or any coin that is bent, cut, torn, battered or otherwise misshaped. 
(b)  Tampering with meter. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove, deface, tamper with, open, willfully break, destroy or damage any parking meter. No person shall willfully manipulate any parking meter in such a manner that the indicator will fail to show the correct amount of unexpired time before a violation. 
(c)  Overtime parking. 
(1)  No person shall park a vehicle or permit a vehicle to be parked or remain parked in any parking space next to which a parking meter has been installed during the regulated time applicable thereto, for an additional consecutive period of maximum time for which parking is lawfully permitted in such metered space, irrespective of the number or amounts of coins deposited in such meter. The maximum consecutive period of time permitted in such space shall be indicated either on the parking meter itself or upon an appropriate and visible sign in the immediate area. The purpose of this provision is to prohibit the practice referred to as "feeding meters" and to require such vehicle to be removed from a parking space at or before the period of time has elapsed for a single metered cycle of time as permitted by such meter. If a vehicle is found parked in such metered space and such vehicle is also found parked in the same place at a time during the next succeeding normal time cycle lawfully permitted in such metered space, then such vehicle shall be deemed to be parked in violation of the provisions of this section, notwithstanding that additional coins may have been deposited in the meter adjacent to such parking space. Each succeeding time cycle beyond that authorized for one period of time in such parking space shall be deemed to be a violation of this division and the person responsible therefor shall be required to pay a fine for each period during which such vehicle is so parked. 
(2)  Continued parking of a vehicle on the street in a space for a period of time beyond that authorized for such space shall constitute a separate violation for each time cycle during which the vehicle is parked in the parking space, and it shall subject the vehicle parked on the street to additional penalties. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3(f)-(i), (l)) 
Sec. 50-59. - Marking of tires. 
    The city clerk and treasurer or his authorized representatives are hereby authorized to place chalkmarks on tires of all vehicles parked on public streets in the city or on off-street parking lots owned or controlled by the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to erase or obscure any chalkmarks placed for such purposes on tires on any vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3(k)) 
Sec. 50-60. - Purpose of parking fees. 
    The coins required to be deposited as provided in this division are hereby levied by the city as bond repayments, regulations and inspection fees to cover the cost of the outstanding bonds, inspection and regulation involved in the inspection, installation, operation, control and use of the parking spaces and parking meters described in this division and involved in checking on and regulating the parking of vehicles in parking meter spaces. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3(j)) 
Secs. 50-61-50-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 50-76. - Issuance; placement on vehicle. 
(a)  The city clerk and treasurer shall be responsible for issuing special parking permits and regulating their purchase and cost. 
(b)  Special parking permits shall be issued to any person upon payment of the required fee. Such permits shall be hung from the rear view mirror with the months facing out and in view when a sunshield is in place. Such permitted vehicle may legally park in any metered space designated on the application form and as on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(Code 1971, § 16-7(a), (b)) 
Sec. 50-77. - Lost or stolen permits. 
    If a special permit issued under this division is lost or stolen, upon proper certification to the city clerk and treasurer, the lost or stolen permit shall be voided and a new permit shall be issued upon payment of a fee on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office. 
(Code 1971, § 16-7(c)) 
Sec. 50-78. - Fees. 
    The city council shall set the required fees for all special parking permits. 
(Code 1971, § 16-7(d)) 
Secs. 50-79, 50-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RED LIGHT INFRACTION ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 50-81. - Procedures. 
(a)  The city does hereby provide for and authorize the administration and implementation of F.S. § 316.0083. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section or the city's administration and implementation shall be in conflict with or in contravention of F.S. § 316.0083 and in the event of such conflict, the provisions of F.S. § 316.0083 shall control. 
(c)  The city police department, with the assistance of the public works department if needed and the city clerk's office if needed, shall select locations for the traffic infraction detectors in compliance with the requirements of F.S. § 316.0083 and state rules adopted thereunder. 
(d)  Payment of traffic infraction fines as set forth by F.S. § 316.0083 shall be paid at the Bradenton Police Department or such other location from time to time authorized by city council or, when provided by F.S. § 316.0083 and according to its terms, to the clerk of the county court. 
(Ord. No. 2932, 6-8-11) 
Secs. 50-82-50-95. - Reserved. 
Chapter 54 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Fines and forfeitures in county court payable to municipality, F.S. § 34.191; punishment for misdemeanors, F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Misdemeanors under state law. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit, within the limits of the city, any act which is or shall be recognized by the laws of the state as a misdemeanor. Whoever shall violate this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by the same penalty as is therefor provided by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1971, § 17-1(a)) 
Case Law reference- A municipality may enact an ordinance which creates an offense against municipal law for the same act that constitutes an offense against state law. Jaramillo v. City of Homestead , 322 So. 2d 496 (Fla. 1975). 
A municipality by ordinance may adopt state misdemeanor statutes by specific reference or by general reference, such as that contained in an ordinance making it unlawful to commit, within city limits, any act which is or shall be recognized by the laws of the state as a misdemeanor. Id . 
An adoption by general reference of a misdemeanor statute permits subsequent amendments, revisions and repeals of the laws by the state legislature to apply to the municipal ordinances. Id . 
See also Hecht v. Shaw , 112 Fla. 762, 151 So. 333 (1933); McFarland v. Roberts , 74 So. 2d 88 (Fla. 1954); and State v. Smith , 189 So. 2d 846 (Fla. 4th D.C.A. 1966). 
State Law reference- Misdemeanors defined, F.S. § 775.08; penalty for violation of misdemeanors, F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083; discharging firearms in public, F.S. § 790.15. See also Fla. Stats. general index under heading "Fines and Civil Penalties" for listing of state law misdemeanors. 
Sec. 54-2. - Court costs levied. 
    There is hereby assessed by the city council, in compliance with F.S. § 943.25(5), an additional fee, on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office, as court costs against every person convicted for violation of a state penal or criminal statute or convicted for a violation of a municipal or county ordinance where such offense occurred within the city limits. An additional fee, on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office, shall be deducted from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal statutes or ordinances. However, no such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for a violation of any state statute, municipal or county ordinance relating to the parking of vehicles. All such assessments shall be collected by the appropriate court and shall be remitted to the city and earmarked for law enforcement education and training for members of the police department. The use and expenditure of such funds shall be in accordance with education and training programs for law enforcement personnel as determined by the chief of police and in accordance with F.S. § 943.14(4). 
(Code 1971, § 17-1(b)) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt, use of funds, F.S. § 943.25(13). 
Sec. 54-3. - Posting bills, posters or advertisements. 
    No person shall, within the limits of the city, paste, tack or otherwise fasten any bill, poster or advertisement of any kind to, upon, or against any shade or other tree, telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole upon any street or sidewalk of this city. 
(Code 1971, § 17-4) 
Sec. 54-4. - Handbills, distributing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or throw, or cause to be distributed or thrown, upon any street, sidewalk, parkway or other public way or park or in any vehicle, or upon the private premises of another without the consent of the owner of such premises, any handbill, pamphlets, cards, circulars, samples or advertising matter of any kind. 
(Code 1971, § 17-5) 
Sec. 54-5. - Injuring, defacing property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, defile, or destroy any property within the city belonging to the city or to another person. 
(Code 1971, § 17-11) 
State Law reference- Trespass and injury to realty, F.S. § 810.08 et seq. 
Sec. 54-6. - Slingshots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to use a slingshot. 
(Code 1971, § 17-18) 
Sec. 54-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2934, § 1, adopted Sept. 14, 2011, repealed § 54-7, which pertained to discharging guns and pistols and derived from Code 1971, § 17-20(a). 
Sec. 54-8. - Fireworks, blank cartridges. 
(a)  Prohibited generally; exception. The possession, discharge, firing or use of firecrackers, rockets, torpedoes, Roman candles or other fireworks or substances designed and intended for pyrotechnic display and of pistols, canes, cannons, or other appliances using blank cartridges or caps containing chlorate of potash mixture is hereby prohibited. However, the mayor or city council shall have the authority to approve the public display of fireworks by properly qualified individuals, which display shall be of such a character and so located, discharged or fired as, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department, shall not be hazardous to surrounding property or endanger any person. 
(b)  Sale; seizure of illegal fireworks. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer or expose for sale any pyrotechnics or blank cartridges or caps or appliances prohibited under subsection (a) of this section for the discharge thereof. The chief of the fire department may, at his discretion, remove or have removed, at the owner's expense, all stocks of pyrotechnics or other such combustibles offered or exposed for sale or held in stock in violation of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 17-21) 
State Law reference- Fireworks generally, F.S. § 791.01 et seq. 
Sec. 54-9. - Palma Sola Bay idle speed/no wake zone. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply to this section: 
    Idle speed/no wake shall mean that a watercraft can not proceed at a speed greater than that speed which is necessary to maintain steerage way and does not leave a wake. Idle speed/no wake is also referred to as "bare steerage way". 
    Wake shall mean the visible track of turbulence and consequent lateral waves left by passage of a vessel through water. 
    Watercraft shall mean and include, but is not limited to, any boat, vessel, barge, personal watercraft, sailboard, wind surfer, water ski, or any other similar contrivance or devise used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on the water. 
    Watercraft operator shall mean a person who is in actual physical control of steering a watercraft or who is exercising control over or steering any device being towed by a watercraft. 
(b)  Areas encompassed. The areas encompassed by this section are as follows: 
(1)  That land and waterway known commonly as Palma Sola Bay lying within the city limits and adjacent to the centerline of the right-of-way of State Road 64 (also known as Manatee Avenue); 
(2)  Reserved. 
(c)  Conduct prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to steer, sail, propel or operate any watercraft at any speed greater than idle speed/no wake in the following areas: 
(1)  The area of Palma Sola Bay that lies within the city limits of the City of Bradenton, and adjacent to the centerline of the right-of-way of State Road 64 (also known as Manatee Avenue); 
(2)  Reserved. 
(d)  The city clerk and the public works director of the city are authorized to direct appropriate signage, such as, markers, floats or ropes and any other items deemed desirable to carry out the terms of this section and these officials are authorized to obtain permits from the State of Florida for placement of such markers, floats or ropes. 
(e)  Penalties. A violation of this section is a misdemeanor and may be prosecuted in the name of the state and the court having jurisdiction of misdemeanors by the prosecuting attorney thereof and upon conviction shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and/or including imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed 60 days or by both such fine and/or imprisonment. In addition, a violation may be punished by issuance of a citation for noncriminal infraction pursuant to chapter 327, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2557, 7-10-96; Ord. No. 2654, §§ 1, 2, 4-11-01; Ord. No. 2898, § 1, 10-8-08) 
Sec. 54-10. - Manatee protection for the Riverdale Subdivision. 
(a)  Purpose and authority. 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to provide protection to the Florida manatee and its habitat against disturbance, harassment, injury or harm caused by motorboats and personal watercraft, in the canal system of a residential development within the city, commonly known as Riverdale and the adjacent waters of the Manatee River. 
(2)  Local governments are authorized by F.S. § 370.12(2)(o) to regulate vessel speed and operation in areas where manatees are frequently sighted and can be generally assumed to inhabit periodically or continuously. 
(3)  Manatees are sighted and can be generally assumed to inhabit periodically or continuously, the Riverdale canal system and the Manatee River adjacent to the Riverdale canal system. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Idle speed no wake and idle speed means may be used interchangeably and mean that a vessel must proceed at a speed no greater than that which will maintain steerageway and headway. At no time is any vessel required to proceed so slowly that the operator is unable to maintain control over the vessel or any other vessel or object that it has under tow. 
(2)  Motorboat means any vessel equipped with machinery for propulsion, irrespective of whether the propulsion machinery is in actual operation. 
(3)  Personal watercraft means a vessel less than sixteen (16) feet in length which uses an inboard motor powering a water jet pump, as its primary source of motive power and which is designed to be operated by a person sitting, standing, or kneeling on the vessel, rather than in the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel. 
(4)  Riverdale subdivision means a residential area within Manatee County consisting of residential subdivisions known as the Inlets, Hawk Island and Harbor Walk, among others. 
(5)  Slow speed and slow speed minimum wake means may be used interchangeably and mean that a vessel must be fully off plane and completely settled into the water. The vessel must then proceed at a speed which is reasonable and prudent under the prevailing circumstances so as to avoid the creation of an excessive wake or other hazardous condition which endangers or is likely to endanger other vessels, manatees or other persons using the waterway. A vessel that is: 
a.  Operating on plane is not proceeding at this speed; 
b.  In the process of coming off plane and settling into the water or coming up onto plane is not proceeding at this speed; 
c.  Operating at a speed that creates a wake which unreasonably or unnecessarry endangers other vessels or other persons using the waterway, or is likely to do so, is not proceeding at this speed; 
d.  Completely off plane and which has fully settled into the water and is proceeding at a reasonable and prudent speed with little or no wake is proceeding at this speed. 
(c)  Areas of enforcement. 
(1)  Slow speed area of enforcement. The slow speed area of enforcement begins at the termination of the canal into the Riverdale Subdivision approximately marked by an imaginary line between proposed channel markers at the same location of the marked channel between the Riverdale Subdivision and the Manatee River Federal Channel and extends in a north-westerly direction towards the Manatee River Federal Channel for a distance of approximately 1,425 feet along the marked channel between the Riverdale Subdivision and the Manatee River Federal Channel. The slow speed area of enforcement also extends along the southern shore of the Manatee River, adjacent to the Riverdale Subdivision, within a marked channel approximately 125 feet wide, between proposed channel markers which are approximately located at the east and west limits of the Riverdale Subdivision. The slow speed area of enforcement is also graphically depicted on the exhibit to this section. 
(2)  Idle speed area of enforcement. The no wake area of enforcement begins at the termination of the canal into the Riverdale Subdivision approximately marked by an imaginary line between proposed channel markers at the same location of the marked channel between the Riverdale Subdivision and the Manatee River Federal Channel and extends into all canals within the Riverdale Subdivision that are continuously connected by tidal water to the Manatee River and that were annexed into the city under City of Bradenton Ordinance No. 2642. The idle speed area of enforcement is also graphically depicted on the exhibit to this section. 
(3)  The areas of enforcement are more particularly identified in City of Bradenton Ordinance No. 2642, which annexed portions of the Riverdale canal system, as well as a portion of the marked channel between the Riverdale Subdivision and the Manatee River Federal Channel, into the city. A copy of the ordinance is available at the city clerk office, along with a sketch depicting the annexed canals. 
(d)  Means of enforcement. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by code enforcement officers (CEO) or their designees, unless otherwise delegated or assigned to other law enforcement agencies or departments. Citations for violations of the provisions of this section shall be issued in accordance with section 2-358 unless otherwise delegated to another agency as provided for herein. 
(e)  Regulation of operators; violations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to operate a powerboat or personal watercraft within the Slow Speed area of enforcement at a rate in excess of slow speed. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to operate a powerboat or personal watercraft within the idle speed area of enforcement at a rate in excess of idle speed. 
(f)  Exemptions. This section shall not apply in the case of an emergency or to a law enforcement, fire fighter or rescue vehicle owned or operated by a government entity. 
(g)  Penalties. Any person cited for a violation of this article shall be deemed to be charged with a non-criminal infraction and shall be cited for such infraction under section 2-358, except that the CEO shall not be required to give the violator a reasonable time period in which to correct the violation, as such a speed violation within the areas of enforcement is irreparable and irreversible. 
(Ord. No. 2693, §§ 1-7, 10-9-02) 
Sec. 54-11. - Mooring or anchoring of water vessels within public waterways; prohibited. 
(a)  The term "water vessel or vessel" is synonymous with "boat" as referenced in section 1(b), article VII of the State Constitution and includes every description of watercraft, barge and airboat other than a seaplane on the water used or capable of being used as means of transportation on the water and includes, however, is not limited to, sailboats, powerboats, houseboats, rowboats, canoes, and personal watercraft. Live-a-board vessel shall have that meaning as defined by F.S. ch. 327. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to anchor or moor a vessel in the public waterways of the City of Bradenton in excess of 72 hours except in an emergency situation or unless the vessel is attached to a dock or pier or similar facility, or within a marina or approved anchorage. 
(c)  In the event of an emergency situation the owner or occupant of the vessel shall immediately contact the city and inform the mayor and police department of the city of the nature of the emergency and an allotted time required to remedy the current situation. Upon abatement of the emergency the vessel shall be removed. 
(d)  Violation of this section shall result in a fine not to exceed $500.00 dollars or imprisonment not to exceed 60 days or both. In addition thereto the city through its appropriate authorities may remove the offending vessel and the owner and occupants of said vessel shall be responsible for all costs of such removal, storage or disposal of such vessel. The city may also utilize any code enforcement remedies it has in place and may seek injunctive relief. 
(e)  The owners and occupants shall be given 24 hours notice prior to removal or disposal of a marine vessel except that in the event the vessel poses an immediate or eminent danger to the public and property, notice need only be given as soon as practical after removal or disposal. 
(f)  This section shall not apply to those vessels that are engaged in an approved business activity such as marine repair, construction, research, dredging or other similar activity. 
(g)  In the event the vessel is unregistered and/or the owner cannot be located notice may be effected by posting on the vessel and by posting a copy in the public lobby of the Bradenton City Centre. 
(h)  This section shall not apply to the anchorage or moorage of non-live-aboard vessels engaged in the exercise of the rights of navigation. 
(Ord. No. 2720, §§ 1-8, 9-10-03) 
Sec. 54-12. - Unlawful lodging out-of-doors prohibited. 
(a)  The following words and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the following meanings:
