(1)  Lodging out-of-doors means using public or private property for living accommodation purposes by the erection, use or occupation of any tent, hut, lean-to, shack or temporary shelter for sleeping purposes or the laying down of bedding, such as a blanket or sleeping bag or similar material for the purpose of sleeping. 
(2)  Living accommodation purposes means to remain living, to dwell or to reside at a place for a period of time for the purpose of using such a place as a home. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any public or private property in the city out-of-doors for lodging except with the permission and consent of the city or the property owner. 
(c)  Being in a tent, hut, lean-to, shack or in a temporary shelter or being asleep atop or covered by materials in a public place or private place out-of-doors without the permission and consent of the city or the property owner may be evidence of a violation but is not alone sufficient to constitute a violation of this section. One or more of the following must also exist before a law enforcement officer can find probable cause to issue a summons or to make an arrest: 
(1)  Numerous items of personal belongings are present; 
(2)  The person is engaged in cooking activities; 
(3)  The person has built or is maintaining a fire. 
(4)  The person has engaged in digging or earth breaking activities; 
(5)  The person is asleep and when awakened states he or she has no other place to live. 
(d)  Except as provided for in subsection (e), whenever a law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that a violation of this section has occurred, he or she shall advise the person of the violation and afford the person an opportunity to be transported by a law enforcement officer to a public shelter. The law enforcement officer shall advise the person that all his or her personal property which is not taken to the public shelter, except that which is of no apparent utility or which is in an unsanitary condition, shall be inventoried and stored by the Bradenton Police Department for a maximum of 60 days, until reclaimed. If the person elects to be transported to a public shelter the law enforcement officer shall make available such transportation as may be available for such purpose and the person making such election shall not be charged with a violation of this section. If the person refuses to be transported to a public shelter, then such person may be charged with a violation of this section. 
(e)  Subsection (d) shall not apply to any person who cannot be properly identified, or is intoxicated by alcohol or drugs or who, within the past year, was previously charged with a violation of this section or who elected to be transported to a public shelter. For purposes of this subsection, proper identification shall include, but be limited to, a driver's license, a government or employment identity card with photograph or other form of identification, which would satisfy a reasonable law enforcement officer as to the identity of the person. 
(f)  Any personal property that was inventoried and stored by the Bradenton Police Department for a person transported to a shelter under the provisions of this section which has not been reclaimed within 60 days of the date the personal property was inventoried and stored shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of according to F.S. chapter 705. 
(Ord. No. 2814, § 1, 8-16-06) 
Sec. 54-13. - Public urination/defecation prohibited; exceptions. 
(1)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings ascribed to them: 
    Business or commercial district shall mean all other places not included in the definition of residential district below. 
    Persons with impairments within the meaning of this section does not include intoxicated individuals or individuals who are impaired due to the taking of illegal substances or substances not legally prescribed to them. 
    Dump means to dump, throw, discard, place, deposit, discharge, spill, leak, or dispose of. 
    Public place includes, but is not limited to, any street or highway, alley, parking lot, driveway, sidewalk, boulevard, park, beach, wharf, pier, or other place open to the public view. A public place does not include an enclosure designated for use as a toilet or lavatory. Residential district shall have the meaning ascribed for it in the Land Use and Development Regulations of the City of Bradenton. 
(2)  Certain acts prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to do any of the following acts: 
(a)  Urinate or defecate on any public place within the city, or within any property zoned as a residential district without the express permission of the owner where such permissive urination or defecation does not create a public nuisance or otherwise violate any section of this Code, or within any portion of the city zoned as a business or commercial district or for industrial, or public uses unless such urinating or defecating is made into a receptacle that has been provided for that purpose, that stores or disposes of the wastes in a sanitary manner and that is enclosed from the view of the general public. 
(b)  Dump, unload or otherwise dispose of any urine or feces, in or on any public place within the city, or within any property within a residential district without the express permission of the owner, or within any portion of the city zoned as a business or commercial district or for industrial or public uses other than in areas designated for such purpose. 
(3)  Exceptions. Subsection (2) shall not apply to children under 11 years old, or to persons with impairments who lack the physical or mental ability to control their bodily functions; except that such a person's parent, guardian, or custodian is responsible for cleaning up any waster expelled by the child or person with impairments. Failure of the parent, guardian, or custodian of the minor child or person with impairments to clean up and dispose of solid waste in a sanitary manner shall be a violation of subsection (2). 
(4)  Any person found in violation of this section shall be punished by up to 60 days in jail or a fine of up to $500.00 or both such jail time and fine. 
(Ord. No. 2862, 5-9-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2862, adopted May 9, 2007, added § 53-10 to the Code. Inasmuch as §§ 54-10-54-12 already existed, the new provisions have been redesignated as § 54-13 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 54-14. - Trespass warnings on public property and other property generally open to the public. 
(a)  Officers of the city police department are authorized to issue a trespass warning to any individual who violates any city ordinance, rule or regulation, or state law which violation was committed while on or within any city facility, building, or outdoor area that is open to the general pubic, including municipal parks and including public sidewalks adjacent to municipal parks where there is also a public sidewalk on the opposite side of the street (but excluding other public rights-of-way). The trespass warning shall be limited to the specific property where the violation occurred. 
(b)  Trespass warnings shall be in writing and issued for a period not to exceed one year. 
(c)  A copy of the trespass warning shall be provided by mail or hand delivery to the individual given the warning. The written trespass warning shall advise of the right to appeal and the location at which to file the form to initiate the appeal. 
(d)  A written trespass warning shall also be issued when officers of the city police department are acting on behalf of another governmental agency or private property owner and issuing a trespass warning to an individual located on public property not owned by the city or on private property subject to a public access easement. For purposes of this section 54-14, the term public access easement shall mean an easement in favor of the city granting general public access to private property or limited public access to patrons and invitees of a particular business establishment or establishments. 
(e)  Any person found on or within any city facility, building, or outdoor area, including municipal parks, in violation of a trespass warning issued in accordance with this section may be arrested for trespassing, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(f)  Any person found on or within any public property belonging to another governmental agency other than the city or found on or within any private property subject to a public access easement, in violation of a trespass warning issued in accordance with this section may be arrested for trespassing. 
(g)  The city clerk, or his/her designee, may upon request, authorize an individual who has received a trespass warning to enter the property or premises to exercise his or her First Amendment rights if there is no other reasonable alternative location to exercise such rights or to conduct necessary municipal business. Such authorization must be in writing, shall specify the duration of the authorization and any conditions thereof, and shall not be unreasonably denied. 
(h)  This section shall not be construed to limit the authority of any city employee or official to issue a trespass warning to any person for any lawful reason for any city property, including rights-of-way when closed to general vehicular or pedestrian use, when necessary or appropriate in the sole discretion of the city employee or official. 
(i)  This section shall not be construed to limit the authority of officers of the city police department to arrest or cite individuals for violating any section of the City Code or the Florida Statutes. 
(j)  Appeal of trespass warning. A person to whom a trespass warning is issued under this section shall have the right to appeal the issuance of the trespass warning as follows: 
(1)  An appeal of the trespass warning must be filed, in writing, within 20 days of the issuance of the warning, and shall include the appellant's name, address and phone number, if any. No fee shall be charged for filing the appeal. 
(2)  Appeals shall be heard by a special magistrate with whom the city contracts to provide this service. 
(3)  Within seven business days following the filing of the appeal, the special magistrate shall schedule a hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be provided to the appellant in one of three ways: 
a.  By providing the appellant a copy of the notice of hearing in person at the time he or she files the appeal. When it is not reasonably practical or possible to provide notice in this manner, the appellant shall be informed that notice of the hearing will be provided in accordance with either paragraph b. or c. below; 
b.  By leaving or posting the notice at the front desk of the city police department or on the bulletin board at city hall; or 
c.  By telephone if a telephone number has been provided and mailing when an address has been provided. 
(4)  The special magistrate shall hold the hearing as soon as possible. In no event shall the hearing be held later than 40 days from the filing of the appeal except that the person appealing may request an additional 40 days during the appeal period. 
(5)  Copies of documents in the city's control which are intended to be used at the hearing, and which directly relate to the issuance of the trespass warning to the appellant, shall be made available upon request to the appellant at no cost. 
(6)  The appellant shall have the right to testify and to call witnesses and present evidence and the right to engage an attorney to represent him or her. The appellant shall have the right to bring a court reporter, at his or her own expense. 
(7)  The special magistrate shall consider the testimony, reports or other documentary evidence, and any other evidence presented at the hearing. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall govern the proceedings. 
(8)  The city shall bear the burden of proof by clear and convincing evidence that the trespass warning was properly issued pursuant to the criteria of this section. 
(9)  If the appellant fails to attend a scheduled hearing, the special magistrate shall review the evidence presented and determine if the trespass warning was properly issued pursuant to the criteria of this section. 
(10)  Within seven business days of the hearing, the special magistrate shall issue a written decision on the appeal which shall be mailed to the appellant at the address provided. 
(11)  The decision of the special magistrate shall be final and the appellant shall be deemed to have exhausted all administrative remedies. Such decision may be subject to judicial review in the manner provided by law. 
(12)  The trespass warning shall remain in effect during the appeal and review process, including any judicial review. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1, 1-23-13) 
Secs. 54-15-54-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Curfew, F.S. § 877.20 et seq. 

Sec. 54-36. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the city council to protect minors in this city from harm and victimization, to promote the safety and well-being of minors and to reduce the crime and violence committed by minors in this city, by adopting a local juvenile curfew. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 877.20. 
Sec. 54-37. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances which results in a situation that requires immediate attention to care for or prevent serious bodily injury, loss of life, or significant property loss. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or an automobile accident. 
    Establishment means a privately owned place of business to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, a place of amusement or a place of entertainment. 
    Minor means any person under 16 years of age. 
    Parent means a person who has legal custody of a minor as a: 
(1)  Natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)  Legal guardian; 
(3)  Person who stands in loco parentis to the minor; or 
(4)  Person who has legal custody of the minor by order of the court. 
    Public place means a place to which the public has access, including, but not limited to, streets, highways, public parks, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transportation facilities, and shops. 
    Remain means to stay unnecessarily in a particular place. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 877.21. 
Sec. 54-38. - Minors prohibited in public places and establishments during certain hours; penalty; enforcement. 
(a)  A minor may not be or remain in a public place or establishment between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, Sunday through Thursday, except in the case of a legal holiday. A minor may not be or remain in a public place or establishment between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. 
(b)  A minor who has been suspended or expelled from school may not be or remain in a public place, in an establishment, or within 1,000 feet of a school during the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. during any school day. 
(c)  A minor who violates this section shall receive a written warning for his first violation. A minor who violates this section after having received a prior written warning is guilty of a civil infraction and shall pay a fine of $50.00 for each violation. 
(d)  If a minor violates a curfew and is taken into custody, the minor shall be transported immediately to a police station or to a facility operated by a religious, charitable, or civic organization that conducts a curfew program in cooperation with a local law enforcement agency. After recording pertinent information about the minor, the law enforcement agency shall attempt to contact the parent of the minor and, if successful, shall request that the parent take custody of the minor and shall release the minor to the parent. If the law enforcement agency is not able to contact the minor's parent within two hours after the minor is taken into custody, or if the parent refuses to take custody of the minor, the law enforcement agency may transport the minor to his residence or proceed as authorized under F.S. ch. 39, part III. 
(Code 1971, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 877.22. 
Sec. 54-39. - Legal duty of parent; penalty. 
(a)  The parent of a minor has a legal duty and responsibility to ensure that the minor does not violate section 54-38(a). 
(b)  The parent of a minor has a legal duty and responsibility to personally supervise, or arrange for a responsible adult to supervise the minor so that the minor does not violate section 54-38(b). 
(c)  The parent of a minor who knowingly permits the minor to violate section 54-38(a) or (b) shall receive a written warning for a first violation. A parent who knowingly permits the minor to violate section 54-38(a) or (b) after having received a prior written warning is guilty of a civil infraction and shall pay a fine of $50.00 for each violation. 
(Code 1971, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 877.23. 
Sec. 54-40. - Exceptions. 
    Section 54-38 does not apply to a minor who is: 
(1)  Accompanied by his parent or by another adult authorized by the minor's parent to have custody of the minor. 
(2)  Involved in an emergency or engaged, with his parent's permission, in an emergency errand. 
(3)  Attending or traveling directly to or from an activity that involves the exercise of rights protected under the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. 
(4)  Going directly to or returning directly from lawful employment, or who is in a public place or establishment in connection with or as required by a business, trade, profession, or occupation in which the minor is lawfully engaged. 
(5)  Returning directly home from a school-sponsored function, a religious function, or a function sponsored by a civic organization. 
(6)  On the property of, or on the sidewalk of, the place where he resides, or who is on the property or sidewalk of an adult next-door neighbor with that neighbor's permission. 
(7)  Engaged in interstate travel or bona fide intrastate travel with the consent of the minor's parent. 
(8)  Attending an organized event held at and sponsored by a theme park or entertainment complex as defined in F.S. § 509.013(9). 
(Code 1971, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 877.24. 
Secs. 54-41-54-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRUGS[3]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 54-66-54-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NUISANCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2895, § 1, adopted Sept. 10, 2008, amended div. 2 in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former div. 2 derived from Code 1971, § 17-81; and Ord. No. 2582, §§ 1-7, adopted June 10, 1998. 
State Law reference- Authority to abate drug- or prostitution-related public nuisances, F.S. § 893.138. 

Sec. 54-81. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the nuisance abatement board, hereinafter referred to as the "board". 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-82. - Composition; appointment; terms of office; procedures. 
    The board shall consist of seven members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. Initial appointments to the board shall be as follows: Three members shall be chosen to serve for one year; two members shall be chosen to serve for two years; two members shall be chosen to serve for three years. Thereafter, all appointees to the board shall serve for a term of three years. There may also be appointed tow alternate members. The board shall adopt rules of procedure which shall be subject to review and approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-83. - Jurisdiction; definitions. 
    The board shall hear complaints alleging that a nuisance, as defined hereafter, exists or existed at a particular place or premises. The board is empowered to hold public hearings and to declare that any place or premises is or has been a public nuisance which may be abated or continued to be abated pursuant to the procedures provided in this division. A nuisance shall be deemed to exist or to have existed if the board after hearing finds by a preponderance of the evidence that a place or premises has been used: 
(1)  On more than two occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of F.S. § 796.07 relating to prostitution; or 
(2)  On more than two occasions within a six-month period as the site of the unlawful sale, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance; 
(3)  On one occasion as the site of the unlawful possession of a controlled substance, where such possession constitutes a felony and such place or premises has been previously used on more than one occasion as the site of the unlawful sale, delivery, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance; 
(4)  By a youth and street gang for the purpose of conducting a pattern of youth and street gang activity as defined by F.S. § 874.03; or 
(5)  On more than two occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of F. S. § 812.019, relating to dealing in stolen property. 
    A nuisance shall be deemed to be or to have been abated when the board finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the causes of the nuisance have been eliminated or suppressed to such a degree that an additional predicate violation, as set forth in subsections (1) through (5) herein, is unlikely to reoccur. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-84. - Procedures; initiation of proceeding. 
    The city may bring a complaint before the board alleging a nuisance as that term is defined in section 54-83 (hereinafter the use of the term "complainant" shall mean the city). A complaint may be filed with the city by a resident of the city or any occupant of real property within the city who is aggrieved by an alleged nuisance. A complaint filed with the city or brought by the city before the board shall contain sufficient facts to identify the precise nature of the alleged nuisance. The board shall provide not less than three days' written notice of such complaint to the owner of the place or premises complained against, at the last known address of the owner. The written notice shall be served on the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested; by personal service through a process server; or by hand delivery. The written notice shall include the date, time and place of the public hearing on the complaint and brief description of the facts alleged to constitute a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-85. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  The hearing before the board shall be a public hearing. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply. 
(b)  The board shall conduct a public hearing on any complaint brought before it pursuant to section 54-84. The board may hold the public hearing on a complaint although the owner of the place or premises complained against is absent from the hearing as long as the owner has received notice of the hearing pursuant to section 54-84. 
(c)  The burden of proof at the public hearing shall be on the complainant to establish a nuisance, as that term is used in section 54-83, by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(d)  The order of presentation in the public hearing shall be as follows: 
(1)  The complainant; 
(2)  Witnesses on behalf of the complainant; 
(3)  The owner of the place or premises; 
(4)  Witnesses on behalf of the owner of the place or premises; 
(5)  Members of the general public in attendance at the public hearing; 
(6)  Summation by the complainant; 
(7)  Summation by the owner of the place or premises. 
(e)  Testimony given at the public hearing by the complainant, the owner of the place or premises complained against, witnesses and members of the public shall be under oath. The parties may cross-examine each other, any witness or any member of the public who testifies. All evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs shall be admissible, whether or not such evidence would be admissible in a trail in a court of law within the state. Evidence of the general reputation of the place or premises shall be admissible. 
(f)  At the conclusion of the public hearing, the board may take any action provided for in section 54-86. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-86. - Penalties. 
(a)  The board may declare that a place or premises is or has been a public nuisance as defined in section 54-83; the board may enter an order requiring the owner of such place or premises to adopt such procedures as may be appropriate to abate such nuisance, or to ensure its continued abatement for one year after the board finds or has found the nuisance to be abated; the board shall enter an order which may include the imposition of a civil fine, not to exceed $250.00 per day, or not to exceed $500.00 per day for recurring public nuisances, for each day the nuisance existed or continues to exist on the place or premises, reasonable costs incurred by the city for the investigation and prosecution of the matter, for the administrative hearing and for the recording of orders and satisfaction of liens, and reasonable attorney fees associated with investigations of and hearings on the matter, upon finding that a nuisance exists or existed on the place or premises; and, the board may enter an order immediately prohibiting: 
(1)  The continued maintenance of the nuisance; 
(2)  The reoccurrence of any additional predicate violations as set forth in subsections 54-83(1) through (3); 
(3)  The operating or maintaining of the place or premises including the closure of the place or premises of any part thereof; or 
(4)  The conduct, operation, or maintenance of any business or activity on the premises which is conducive to such nuisance. 
In entering its order, the board may provide for its continued jurisdiction in the matter for one year after the board finds or has found the nuisance to be abated, and in the event the board finds, after proper notice and hearing, that, during such period, another predicate violation, as set forth in subsections 54-83(1) through (3) has reoccurred, or there is noncompliance with its order, the board may declare that a public nuisance exists or existed on the place or premises or that there has been noncompliance with its order and impose any of the penalties as set forth in this section, including the imposition of a fine not exceeding $500.00 for each day the nuisance existed or continues to exist on the place or premises, or for each day there is noncompliance with its order. 
(b)  At the conclusion of the public hearing, the board may orally render its order. In such event, the order shall be reduced to writing and shall be signed by the chairperson or vice chair of the board. The order shall be mailed by U.S. mail or shall be served on the owner. Any order entered pursuant to this section shall expire one year after the date of such order, or at such earlier time as is stated in the order. A certified copy of the order may be recorded in the public records of Manatee County, Florida, and upon recording shall constitute notice to and be binding upon any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest or assigns of the real property which is the subject of the order. 
(c)  In those cases when the nuisance abatement board enters an order requiring a property owner to pay a fine not exceeding $250.00 or $500.00 for recurring public nuisances for each day a nuisance exists or existed on the place or premises, the following shall apply: 
(1)  Each day a nuisance continues or existed constitutes a separate offense punishable pursuant to this section; 
(2)  The nuisance abatement board may reduce or nullify a fine imposed pursuant to this division; 
(3)  A certified copy of the order imposing a fine or costs or both may be recorded in the public records of the Manatee County. Upon recording, the order shall constitute a lien against the place or premises which shall be superior to all other liens, except a lien for taxes, and shall bear interest at the maximum rate allowed by law as set forth in F.S. § 687.03, as amended from time to time, from the date of its filing. Interest shall continue to accrue until a judgment is rendered in a suit to foreclose on the lien or alternatively, as provided by law for the foreclosure of mortgages. Upon foreclosure, the city shall be entitled to recover all costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, associated with the recording of orders and foreclosure. Upon recording, the lien shall continue for a period of 20 years. No lien created pursuant to this chapter may be foreclosed on real property which is homestead under section 4, article X of the State Constitution; When a fine is imposed pursuant to this division, based on a stolen property nuisance, against a property owner operating an establishment where multiple tenants, on one site, conduct their owner retail business, the property owner shall not be subject to a lien against his or her property or the prohibition of operation provision if the property owner evicts the business declared to be a nuisance within 90 days after notification by registered mail to the property owner of a second stolen property conviction of the tenant. 
(4)  The total fines imposed pursuant to the authority of this section shall not exceed $15,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-87. - Appeal. 
    The city or the owner of the place or premises complained against may appeal a ruling or order of the board by proceedings in the Circuit Court for Manatee County in accordance with rule 9.190, the Florida Rules of Appellate Procedure. An appeal shall be filed within 30 days of the execution of the order to be appealed. The nature of the appeal shall be from a final administrative order. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 54-88. - Enforcement. 
    An order entered under section 54-86 may be enforced pursuant to the procedures contained in F.S. § 120.69. Alternatively, the board may bring a complaint under F.S. § 60.05 seeking temporary and permanent injunctive relief against any nuisance declared by the board. These remedies shall be in addition to any other available remedy. 
(Ord. No. 2895, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Secs. 54-89-54-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES USED TO FACILITATE PROSTITUTION OR DRUG RELATED CRIMES 

Sec. 54-100. - Definitions. 
    Business days shall mean any day, Monday through Friday, which is not designated as a holiday pursuant to the city's personnel rules and regulations. 
    Co-owner shall mean any natural person owning a motor vehicle in common with another, regardless of marital relationship or the conjunctive term used on registration or title documents. 
    Lienholder shall mean any individual or entity which, as of the time of impoundment, has properly perfected a lien on the vehicle subject to impoundment. 
    Owner shall mean the natural person who is a registered or titled owner of a motor vehicle, or a natural person having other indicia of ownership of a motor vehicle, including but not limited to, a bill of sale or open title signed by a pervious owner. 
    Special master shall mean the special master or special masters appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. Special master shall be an attorney and shall be in good standing with the Florida Bar Association. 
    Stolen shall mean the trespassory taking and carrying away of the tangible personal property of another with the intent to permanently deprive. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-101. - Motor vehicles subject to impoundment. 
    A motor vehicle shall be subject to seizure and impoundment whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that the vehicle: 
(1)  Was used to facilitate the commission or attempted commission of an act of prostitution, assignation or lewdness as defined in F.S. § 796.07; as amended; or 
(2)  Was used to facilitate the commission of an act of solicitation for prostitution, lewdness, or assignation in violation of F.S. § 796.07; or 
(3)  Was used to facilitate the commission of an unnatural or lascivious act in violation of F.S. § 800.02; 
(4)  Was used to facilitate the commission of the exposure of sexual organs in violation of F.S. § 800.03; or 
(5)  Contains any controlled substance as defined in F.S. § 893.02, as amended; or 
(6)  Was used, intended or attempted to be used, to facilitate the commission of any violation of F.S. ch. 893, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-102. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply and no vehicle shall be impounded if: 
(1)  The vehicle was stolen at the time that it was otherwise subject to seizure and impoundment; 
(2)  At the time the vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment, it is under the control of a person other than an owner or co-owner and the owner or co-owner was not present at the time the vehicle became subject to seizure and impoundment. 
(3)  This article shall not apply and no vehicle shall be seized or impounded pursuant to this section if a law enforcement agency seizes the vehicle pursuant to the state's contraband forfeiture act. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-103. - Procedure. 
    Upon seizing a motor vehicle, the police officer or other officer or agent of the city police department shall: 
(1)  Arrange for the towing of the vehicle by a company used by the city to provide towing and motor vehicle storage services, to the impound lot maintained by the company for the storage of motor vehicles pursuant to the agreement; and 
(2)  Provide written notice of seizure by hand delivery to any owner, or co-owner of the vehicle who is present at the time the vehicle is impounded. The notice shall include a statement of the fact of the vehicle seizure, the right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 54-104 and the right to request a final hearing pursuant to section 54-106; and 
(3)  The police department shall provide notice of seizure by hand delivery or send notice by certified mail to all other co-owner(s) or leinholder of the vehicle at address(es) set forth in the vehicle registration, if any, within three business days of the date of seizure. The notice shall include the fact of the seizure, the right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 54-104 and the right to request a final hearing pursuant to section 54-106. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-104. - Preliminary hearing; administrative penalty. 
(a)  Within five business days of receipt of the notice seizure the owner, co-owner(s) or lienholder may request a preliminary hearing, by delivering to the city, at the address set forth in the notice, a written request for a preliminary hearing. The written request must be received by the city in the allotted time or the right to a preliminary hearing shall be waived. The request must include a telephone number(s) where the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent can be telephonically notified of the date, time and location of the preliminary hearing, and the hours indicating when the owner, co-owner(s), leinholder or the owner's designated agent or designated agent will be available for such telephonic notification. 
(b)  Upon timely receipt of any owner's, co-owner(s), leinholder's, or the owner's designated agent written request for a preliminary hearing, the city shall schedule a hearing to be held within three business days following the date of receipt of the request, or as soon as practicable thereafter. The city shall make a good faith effort to notify the requesting owner, co-owner(s), leinholder, or the owner's designated agent telephonically of the date, time and location of the hearing, at the telephone number(s), during the hours indicated, as set forth on the request for preliminary hearing. However, at the election of the city, notice may be provided by any other means. 
(c)  If the requesting owner, co-owner(s), leinholder, or the owner's designated agent fails to attend the preliminary hearing, and the special master finds that the city has complied with the notice procedures, as set forth herein, then such failure shall constitute a waiver of the owner's, co-owner(s), leinholder's or the owner's designated agent right to a preliminary hearing. Any failure of the requesting owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent to receive actual notice of the preliminary hearing shall not otherwise invalidate the administrative penalty proceedings as set forth herein. 
(d)  The preliminary hearing shall be held before a special master. The sole issue to be considered by the special master is whether the seizing police officer had probable cause under this section to seize and impound the vehicle. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply and hearsay evidence, including any relevant police report, is admissible. The burden of demonstrating probable cause is on the city. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-105. - Administrative fine/posting bond. 
    If a preliminary hearing is not requested, or if it was waived or if the special master finds that there was probable cause to seize and impound the vehicle, then the vehicle shall continue to be impounded pending final hearing or the payment of an administrative civil penalty of $500.00 together with all towing costs and storage. Alternatively, the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent may secure release of the vehicle by posting a cash bond (money order or certified check) in the amount of $500.00 together with all towing and storage costs, plus final hearing costs of $50.00, if such final hearing is requested. If no probable cause is found at the preliminary hearing, the vehicle shall be released to the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent as soon as practical without the imposition of any administrative fine, towing and storage costs or hearing costs. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-106. - Final hearing. 
(a)  The vehicle owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent may request a final hearing by delivering to the city, within 15 days of receipt of the notice of seizure, a request for a final hearing together with a $50.00 final hearing fee. The request and final hearing fee must be delivered to the address provided in the notice of seizure and must include an address and phone number(s) where the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent can be notified of the date, time, and place of the final hearing. 
(b)  Upon timely receipt of a request for final hearing, the city shall schedule a hearing to be held within 30 days of the receipt of the request, or as soon as practicable thereafter. The city shall provide written notice to the requesting owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent by hand delivery or by U.S. certified mail to the address on the request for final hearing. The notice shall state the date, time and location of the final hearing to be conducted by the special master pursuant to this subsection. 
(c)  If an owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent fails to timely request a final hearing, or if the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent fails to attend the final hearing, and the special master finds, that the city has complied with the notice procedures, as set forth herein, then such failure shall constitute a waiver of the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent right to a final hearing and it shall be deemed admitted that the seized vehicle was used in violation of section 54-101. 
(d)  If not waived, the final hearing shall be held before the special master. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the final hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The city shall have the burden to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the vehicle was used as set forth in section 54-101. It shall be a defense that the vehicle was stolen at the time that it was seized and impounded or that the vehicle was under the control of a person other than an owner or co-owner and the owner or co-owner was not present at the time the vehicle became subject to seizure and impoundment. The owner or co-owner(s) of the vehicle shall have the burden to prove said defense by a preponderance of evidence. 
(e)  If the final hearing has been waived, or if, after the hearing, the special master finds by clear and convincing evidence that the vehicle was used as set forth in section 54-101, the special master shall enter an order authorizing the continued impoundment of the vehicle pending payment of a $500.00 administrative civil penalty, towing and storage costs, plus hearing cost of $50.00 or until otherwise released by the city. Any bond posted shall be used to satisfy the imposition of such penalty and costs. If the special master finds that the city did not meet its burden of proof, or that one of the exceptions set forth in subsection (d) apply, the vehicle shall be released to the vehicle owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent as soon as practicable without the imposition of an administrative fine, towing, storage or hearing costs, and any cash bond posted shall be returned. 
(f)  If the final hearing is not provided as set forth in this article the vehicle shall be released to the owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent as soon as practical without the impositions of penalties or fees. The owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent shall not be entitled to release of the vehicle for delays in receiving notice of the final hearing absent a showing of resulting prejudice. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-107. - Costs. 
    A certified copy of an order of the special master imposing an administrative civil penalty and assessing towing, storage and hearing costs may be recorded in the public records of any county. Upon recording, the order shall constitute a lien against any real or personal property owned by the vehicle owner. Such lien shall be superior to all other liens, except a lien for taxes and shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the date of its filing. Upon petition to the circuit court, such order may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of that state, including levy against the real or personal property, but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. The city attorney or his designee is authorized to foreclose any lien established hereby in the same manner as is provided by law for the foreclosure of other municipal liens or alternatively, as provided by law for the foreclosure of mortgages. No lien created pursuant to this chapter may be foreclosed on real property which is homestead under Section 4, Article X of the State Constitution. In an action to enforce an order or to foreclose on a lien as provided in this section the city shall be entitled to recover all costs, including a reasonable attorney's fee, that it incurs thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-108. - Settlement agreements. 
    The city attorney, or his designee, is hereby authorized to enter into settlement agreements as may be appropriate to accomplish the objectives of this section. In addition, nothing herein shall prohibit the city from releasing a motor vehicle seized under the provisions of this section, if such release is determined to be in the best interests of the city. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the city from enforcing the provisions of this section against a vehicle initially seized pursuant to the state's contraband forfeiture act (but not both) if in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Sec. 54-109. - Appeals. 
    The owner, co-owner(s), lienholder, or the owner's designated agent of the vehicle which was seized and impounded may appeal a ruling or order of the special master by proceedings in the circuit court for the county. An appeal shall filed within 30 days of the execution of the order to be appealed. The nature of the appeal shall be from a final administrative order. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-10-98; Ord. No. 2949, 5-22-13) 
Chapter 58 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-291 et seq.; restriction on location of dumpsters, § 42-82; utilities, ch. 70. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means all solid refuse emanating from and usual to housekeeping, and refuse resulting from the preparation and serving of food, which is capable of being deposited in a garbage container of the type and size required by this chapter. 
    Industrial waste means refuse, other than garbage, rubbish and trash, resulting from manufacturing, processing or repairing, including oils, sludges and inflammable wastes. 
    Junk means discarded machinery, household furnishings and appliances and parts thereof, and all other refuse not otherwise defined in this section. 
    Refuse means all solid wastes, except body wastes, accumulating in the city, which may be classified as garbage, rubbish, trash, yard trash, industrial waste, rubble and junk. 
    Rubbish, trash means all solid refuse, other than garbage, usual to the operation of stores and offices, such as sweepings, discarded wrapping and packaging materials and containers, which is capable of being deposited in a trash container that is approved as to size and location by the city sanitary department. 
    Rubble means refuse resulting from the construction, repair or demolition of buildings, lot clearings which are not defined as yard trash, and excavated materials. 
    Yard trash means clippings resulting from the care of shrubbery and portions of trees not exceeding six feet in length or three inches in diameter. 
(Code 1971, § 12-33) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. Any person convicted thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1971, § 12-32) 
Sec. 58-3. - Regulations for collection and disposal of refuse. 
    The director of public works shall have the power to make regulations concerning the days of collection, the type and location of refuse containers, and such other matters appertaining to the collection and disposal of refuse as he shall find necessary, and to change and modify such regulations after such notice as shall be required by the city council; provided, that such regulations are not contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 12-34) 
Secs. 58-4-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 58-31. - Collection of garbage, rubbish and trash by city. 
    The city shall collect at least twice each week, unless prevented by uncontrollable circumstances, all garbage deposited by the residents, tenants, owners or occupants of premises as required in this article, and remove such garbage to the place provided for use of the city sanitary department. All rubbish and trash, including yard trash, deposited as required in this article, shall be collected and disposed of in the same manner as often as deemed necessary by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 12-35) 
Sec. 58-32. - Removal of industrial wastes, rubble and junk. 
    Industrial wastes, rubble and junk accumulating in the city shall be removed at least once each week by the resident, tenant, owner or occupant of the premises to some point outside the city or to such place within the city as the city shall designate, unless such waste, rubble or junk is enclosed and kept from sight of the public or is incidental to a building operation. 
(Code 1971, § 12-36) 
Sec. 58-33. - Private disposal or conveyance without permission prohibited. 
    No garbage, rubbish or trash, not including yard trash, shall be disposed of by any person not authorized by the city. No person shall collect or convey over the streets of the city any garbage without the permission of the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 12-37) 
Sec. 58-34. - Unauthorized removal of garbage. 
    No person shall remove any garbage or other refuse which has been deposited or placed for collection by the city sanitary department, other than the owner of such refuse or some person authorized by him, or by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 12-38) 
Sec. 58-35. - Garbage containers; construction, capacity. 
    All garbage containers shall be made of metal or plastics, equipped with suitable handles and a tightfitting cover; shall be watertight; shall have a capacity of not more than 30 gallons; and shall be of such weight that they can be handled by one man. 
(Code 1971, § 12-40) 
Sec. 58-36. - Number of garbage cans per lot; how determined. 
    At least one garbage can shall be provided by the resident, tenant, owner or occupant of every lot or other premises within the city having an active water or sewer account, unless the city shall determine differently and notify the city clerk and treasurer that such lot or premises is not capable of requiring garbage or trash collection, or that such lot or premises requires a stated number of garbage and/or trash cans or units in excess of one, whereupon the determined number of garbage and/or trash cans or units shall be provided by the resident, tenant, owner or occupant. 
(Code 1971, § 12-41) 
Sec. 58-37. - Rubbish and trash container; type, content. 
    Rubbish and trash containers shall be of a type and content required by regulations of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 12-42) 
Sec. 58-38. - Deposit, placement of garbage and trash for collection. 
    Each resident, tenant, owner or occupant of any building or house trailer within the city shall deposit or cause to be deposited all garbage, rubbish and trash accumulating at such premises in containers of the type required by this article, which shall be placed at an accessible location at the rear of the premises, or such other location as may be approved by the city, and shall have such containers ready for removal at such times as may be designated by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 12-43) 
Sec. 58-39. - Preparation, placement of yard trash and newspapers for collection. 
    Yard trash and newspapers shall be deposited in neat piles along the side of the street or alley. Grass cuttings and leaves shall be in containers, bags, boxes, or of the type that is not affected by wind or rain. If the owner wishes to keep the container, it shall be marked accordingly. Paper will be handled in the same manner or tied in bundles to prevent it from blowing over streets. No container shall weigh in excess of 100 pounds. 
(Code 1971, § 12-44) 
Secs. 58-40-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES AND BILLING PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-216 et seq. 

Sec. 58-61. - Fees for removal of garbage and trash by city. 
    All residents, tenants, owners or occupants of lots or premises where there is an accumulation of garbage or trash required to be removed by the city shall pay to the city for such services the sums as established by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1971, § 12-45) 
Sec. 58-62. - Deposit; monthly billing. 
    Any person desiring garbage and trash collection by the city who does not have a water and/or sewer account with the city shall make a deposit for such services, which deposit shall be treated in the same manner as a water meter deposit, and such person shall be charged the fees provided in this article and shall be billed monthly for such services in the manner approved by the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1971, § 12-46(b)) 
Sec. 58-63. - Collection, payment of fees. 
    The fees provided for in this article shall be charged on a calendar month basis, but shall be billed with current monthly billings of the water and sewer department of the city and may not be paid separately therefrom when so billed. The full fee for a calendar month shall be charged for any fraction of a month in which garbage collection service is rendered. If any bill for the fees provided for in this article shall not be paid before the date indicated on the bill, an additional charge as established by the city council and on file in the city clerk and treasurer's office will be added thereto. 
(Code 1971, § 12-46(a)) 
Chapter 62 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-291 et seq.; consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages prohibited in certain public places, § 6-4; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 50; vacation of public rights-of-way or easements, part III, § 202G.; standards for streets, part III, § 301C. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Obstruction of street right-of-way; peddler's license. 
(a)  Except when a permit has been issued as provided in this Code or otherwise authorized by the rules of the state department of transportation, it is unlawful to make any use of the right-of-way of any city street, including appendages thereto, in any manner that interferes with the safe and efficient movement of people and property from place to place on the city street. Failure to prohibit the use of right-of-way in this manner will endanger the health, safety, and general welfare of the public by causing distractions to motorists, unsafe pedestrian movement within travel lanes, sudden stoppage or slowdown of traffic, rapid lane changing and other dangerous traffic movement, increased vehicular accidents, and motorist injuries and fatalities. Such prohibited uses include, but are not limited to, the free distribution or sale, or display or solicitation for free distribution or sale, of any merchandise, goods, property or services; the solicitation for charitable purposes; the servicing or repairing of any vehicle, except the rendering of emergency service; the storage of vehicles being serviced or repaired on abutting property or elsewhere; and the display of advertising of any sort, except that any portion of a city street may be used for an art festival, parade, fair or other special event if a permit has been obtained from the city. The city may issue permits of limited duration for the temporary use of the right-of-way for any of these prohibited uses if it is determined that the use will not interfere with the safe and efficient movement of traffic and the use will cause no danger to the public. Before a street may be temporarily closed for a special event, the city must determine that the temporary closure of the street is necessary. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to authorize such activities on the interstate highway system. 
(b)  Persons holding valid peddler's licenses issued by the city may make sales from vehicles standing on the right-of-way to occupants of abutting property only. 
(Code 1971, § 17-8(b)) 
State Law reference- Unlawful use of right-of-way, F.S. § 337.406. 
Sec. 62-2. - Overhanging trees or shrubs; duty of abutting property owner. 
    Any tree or shrub which overhangs any public street or sidewalk in such a way as to impede or interfere with travel upon such street or sidewalk shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or of the premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. Any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across any public street or sidewalk shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such tree grows or stands. The director of public works may trim any such tree or shrub or remove any such tree or branch thereof so that the obstruction to passage of persons using such public street or sidewalk shall be eliminated. The roots of trees that obstruct, break up or otherwise damage existing public streets or sidewalks or which prevent the proper and efficient construction or laying of any public street or sidewalk shall be cut and removed to the extent that such roots encroach upon the public easement or right-of-way. Such roots shall be cut and removed by the owner of the property upon which they grow within ten days after receiving written notice of the necessity for such removal by the director of public works. If such owner does not cut and remove such roots within the ten-day period so provided, the director of public works shall cause such roots to be cut and removed and the cost thereof assessed against the property owner. 
(Code 1971, § 21-10) 
Sec. 62-3. - Permission required to plant trees or shrubs in grass plot. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, set out or maintain in any grass plot between the street, curb and sidewalk any trees, plant or shrub of any kind without first obtaining permission from the superintendent of parks. 
(Code 1971, § 21-13) 
Sec. 62-4. - Damaging grass plots or grass therein. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to destroy, deface or mar any grass plot in and along the streets of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy any grass in any of the grass plots in and along the streets of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any automobile or vehicle of any character or kind over, along or across any of the grass plots or parkways in any of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 21-14) 
Sec. 62-5. - Excavations. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to break into, tear into, cut into or to go beneath any paved or hard-surfaced street, highway or sidewalk for the purpose of laying any gas, sewer, water, electric or any other lines, pipes or connections whatsoever, or for any purpose whatsoever, without having previously obtained from the director of public works a permit so to do, in the manner and form as prescribed in this section. 
(b)  Application for permit; investigation of costs; cash deposit required for restoration of surface. It shall be the duty of any person mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, before securing any such permit, to make application to the director of public works for such permit. The director of public works shall cause an investigation to be made and an estimate of the approximate cost of repairing such street, highway or sidewalk. The director of public works shall require the person requesting such permit to deposit in cash the amount of estimate so arrived at by the director of public works before any such permit is granted. If any such person does not repair such street, highway or sidewalk within ten days, to the satisfaction of the director of public works, the director of public works is hereby authorized and ordered to use any such fund so deposited for the purpose of repairing any such street, highway or sidewalk and return to such person any amount of deposit not used in the repairing, plus ten percent supervision. 
(Code 1971, § 21-15) 
Sec. 62-6. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1971, § 21-27) 
Secs. 62-7-62-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 62-36. - Approval required for construction or repair. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public sidewalk, or to repair the same, without having first secured approval therefor. Applications for such approval shall be made to the building department and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person who is to do the actual construction work. No such approval shall be issued except where the work will conform to the requirements of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 21-31) 
Sec. 62-37. - Obstructions. 
(a)  A person cannot, either alone or along with others, stand, sit, lie, congregate or place objects in such a manner as to obstruct: (1) The safe and efficient movement of pedestrian traffic upon any sidewalk, walkway, or right-of-way upon which the public has a right to travel, or (2) any person's safe and efficient access to the entryway of any building, where such entryway abuts a sidewalk, walkway, or right-of-way upon which the public has a right to travel. These prohibitions do not apply to a person who causes an obstruction during the course of performing activities specifically allowed by a valid government-issued permit or in accordance with the conditions of a maintenance or traffic plan that has been approved by a government entity. 
(b)  If a person is in violation of this section, a law enforcement officer shall notify the person that he or she is causing an obstruction in violation of this section and shall request the person to move his or her objects so as to remove the obstruction. The person shall not be charged with a violation of this section if the person voluntarily removes the obstruction and does not repeat a violation of this section for the 72-hour period following the law enforcement officer's notice and request. 
(c)  The prohibition in this section shall not apply to any person who causes such obstruction during the course of performing activities specifically permitted by a valid government-issued permit or in accordance with the conditions of a maintenance of traffic plan that has also been approved. 
(Code 1971, § 21-33; Ord. No. 3013, § 1, 9-27-17) 
Secs. 62-38-62-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREETS 

Sec. 62-56. - Rollerskating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate with rollerskates in the street. 
(Code 1971, § 21-4) 
Sec. 62-57. - Street names. 
(a)  Intent. A well-planned street-naming system aids motorists in identifying destinations, providing points of reference, and contributes to safe traffic flow and contributes to the interest of public health, safety, and welfare. Public inconvenience should also be considered since changing an existing name may be disruptive and costly to residents and business owners. 
(b)  General standards. The term "street" as used in this section may refer to any roadway used for automotive purposes. The following general standards are applicable for all street names within the jurisdiction of the city: 
(1)  Existing numbering pattern. Street names must follow the existing numbering pattern such as "1st Street," and "2nd Avenue," to maintain interconnectivity with the entire street grid. Private streets that are located within a gated community, business park, or planned development project that have two or less connections with existing streets outside of the community or project, may be designated with non-numbered names that are consistent with the theme of the development. 
(2)  Hierarchy of streets. While all streets are important, more careful consideration will be given to the naming or renaming of higher order streets, scenic highways, and specific highway corridors. In determining existing traffic systems, a hierarchy of streets has been established according to various criteria including traffic volume, ratio of traffic service to access service, number of lanes, and length of street segment. 
(3)  Duplication of names. Exact and near duplication of street names is not permitted. For example, the use of both Elm Street and Elm Avenue may be confusing and should, therefore, be avoided. It may be appropriate, however, for a minor subsidiary street to duplicate the primary name of a larger street with which it is associated, e.g., Island Court, a cul-de-sac, running off of Island Avenue. It is preferable not to use names which sound alike or which might be confused with one another, such as Beach Street and Beech Street. 
(4)  Prohibited names. It is desirable to use names which are simple and logical and which foster clarity and efficiency. Use of frivolous or complicated words or unconventional spellings in road names is prohibited. Names which might be reasonably perceived to be offensive are prohibited. The use of alphabetical letters such as "A Street," is generally prohibited. 
(5)  Names of local relevance. It is sometimes desirable to use names which have some association with the city and specifically with the immediate location of the street, such as reference to historical residents or physiographic features. Uses of names which may be misleading in terms of association are strongly discouraged. In order to preserve local history, care should be exercised in changing historical names. 
(6)  Naming streets after a person. Honoring an individual is a valid but secondary function of street naming. As such, it is desirable for there to be a direct association between the individual and the location of the named street. In determining whether a street should be named in honor of a particular person, consideration should be given to that person's relationship to the city, character, public image and contribution. More thoughtful and careful consideration should be rendered in the nomination of a person who is still living, younger in age, or still engaged (rather than retired) in his/her career. The size, significance and classification of the thoroughfare should not be out of proportion to the significance of the individual's contribution. However, it should not be construed that one's contribution is small if his/her name is affixed to a lower order street. 
a.  Names given to arterials and collectors should be reserved for individuals whose contribution has clearly been of great significance to the citizens within and outside of the city. A biographical profile of the individual for whom the street name is being requested may be required. 
b.  Naming of local streets after individuals is generally prohibited. 
(7)  Segment identification. A street's individuality should be easily definable, continuous, and unitary in its identity. Consideration will be favored toward the automobile driver, and how the driver would expect to see a street name end or continue. The minimum criteria for making this determination are as follows: 
a.  Termini. A street should have two distinct and appropriate termini. Appropriate termini may include: a street that dead ends or terminates at a "T" or "Y" intersection; an abrupt change in compass direction; a jurisdictional boundary; a natural boundary such as a river or dramatic change in topography; or a change in street type or size. 
b.  Street direction. A street name should not change abruptly before its terminus, take surprising turns, or extend oddly beyond a logical terminus. 
c.  Angled streets. Streets that continue through an intersection at or near a 180-degree angle should bear the same name. If the angle is significantly less, such as less than 135 degrees, it may be appropriate to use different names. At a three-way intersection, the two streets which form an angle closest to 180 degrees should bear the same name. A street running in a consistent compass direction should have one name throughout that distance. If it takes a sharp change in direction (excluding intersections) for a significant distance it may be appropriate to rename that portion of roadway. Where that section is clearly part of, and subsidiary to the larger roadway, it should bear the same name. 
d.  Multijurisdictional streets. It is preferable for most local and collector street names to continue across jurisdictional boundaries into adjacent cities or unincorporated areas. In selecting names for these streets, it should be considered which section of roadway is more defining in character and greater in length, and whether annexation is likely. 
(8)  Suffix designation. Thoroughfare suffixes (street, avenue, road, boulevard, parkway, highway, drive, lane, way, court, place, circle, etc.) should be appropriate to the type and size of the street. Suffix designations provide directional assistance in locating addresses by how roads look and travel. 
(c)  Procedures for naming or renaming streets. 
(1)  New streets. Naming of a newly created street shall require approval by the department of development services through the site plan review process, or other applicable review process, and shall not require city council approval. 
(2)  Renaming streets. A request for renaming an existing street shall require the submittal of a completed street renaming application package and the applicable fee to the department of development services as indicated in the procedures manual. All street renamings shall require consideration by the city council who may approve or deny the renaming. In rendering street renaming recommendations and decisions, the city council may consider unnecessary hardship to those affected property owners whose properties are directly addressed on the subject street. The city council reserves the right to change any street name, with proper public notice and hearing, when such change enhances public safety or welfare, including but not limited to duplication of, or similar-sounding street names; emergency or logistical problems of the street name; postal delivery problems; or for other reasons determined by the city council. 
(3)  Penalty. Violation of these guidelines or procedures may constitute a misdemeanor, punishable by law. 
(Ord. No. 2756, § 1, 6-9-04) 
STREET RENAMING APPLICATION: PROCEDURES 
Step 1: Preapplication Meeting. Schedule a meeting with the graphics coordinator, 941-708-6200 to discuss the proposed street renaming. The graphics coordinator will perform a cursory review of the request and answer any questions the applicant may have. See Table A for street suffix parameters. Step 2: Application and Fee. Obtain a "street renaming application," and do the following: 1. Complete the cover sheet and obtain the required information. 2. Complete the petition form and property owner signatures from at least 75% of the property owners directly abutting and addressed from the street petitioned for renaming. Only one property owner signature per address is permitted. 3. At the time of application submittal, pay a $350 street renaming fee and a $100 legal advertising fee. NOTE: If the renaming is approved by city council, the contact person listed on the cover sheet will be required to pay an additional fee to cover the costs of signage replacement. The street renaming shall not take effect until all fees have been paid. If after 20 working days of approval, all fees have not been paid, then the street renaming becomes null and void, and of no force or effect. Step 3: Development Services Review and Public Notice. 1. Once the application is determined to be complete, a staff evaluation and analysis report will be prepared, providing a recommendation to the city council. 2. At least 10 days prior, an advertisement will be placed in the Bradenton Herald indicating the date, time, and location of the public hearing by the City Council. Also, all affected property owners will be contacted by the city notifying them of the proposed street renaming. Step 4: City Council Public Hearing The contact person for the requested street renaming shall be required to attend the city council public hearing. Failure to attend may result in a denial of the application, and forfeiture of any fees paid. Step 5: Payment of Signage and Labor Fees 1. Upon approval by the city council of the street renaming, the graphics coordinator shall issue a "change of signage work order" to the public works department. The public works department will contact the contact person to submit payment of the actual signage replacement costs. Failure to submit payment within 30 days shall result in Denial of the street renaming request, and no signage will be changed. 2. NOTE: Signage costs due to errors in misspellings or misplacement of signage by the city will be paid for by the city. Signage replacement or changes as the result of neighborhood disputes, continual theft of signage due to novel signage text, or misspellings due to applicant/petition error shall be paid for by the contact person. Step 6: Sign Installation Once public works receives payment from the contact person, then the sign(s) will be replaced or added, as determined by the city.  
Table A. Street Suffix Parameters. 
Suffix Designation Physical Description Freeway/Highway Usually an interstate, intrastate, or intra metropolitan facility running east/west or north/south. Usually divided. Very limited access. Parkway Facility usually traveling to or through major points of interest and urban metropolitan areas, or providing access to those areas. Often used as a toll way to large cities, resort areas, regional parks, or nature areas. Very limited access. Boulevard Street that travels through a community or communities, often divided by a landscaped median. Sometimes terminates at a specific point of interest. Assists in providing identity to a community. Moderate access. Avenue Collector that serves an entire community or neighboring communities, or a local road. Always travels in straight east/west directions. May be used to assist in providing identity to a community. High degree of access. Street Collector that serves an entire community or neighboring communities, or a local road. Usually travels in straight north/south directions. May be used to assist in providing identity to a community. High degree of access. Drive, Trail Usually longer collectors that travel in all directions, often winding in several directions. May be used for scenic points of interest. Low to moderate access. Road Generic suffix. Often used for industrial and rural collectors or streets that take motorists to specific uses within those areas. Street Generic suffix. Can be used for most local residential, commercial, and urban systems. Usually straight in direction. Often provides access between higher order streets. Lane Local residential designation. Can meander slightly or travel straight. Used for local travel only May provide access between or to higher order streets. Loop, Circle Can be used for residential, commercial, or industrial park areas. No real terminus, often bringing traveler back to starting point. Sometimes provides two access points from a single, higher order street. Way, Court, Place, Point, Path Local residential designation. Terminates at a cul-de-sac or dead end. Usually does not provide through traffic.  
(Ord. No. 2756, § 1, 6-9-04) 
Sec. 62-58. - Vending on public roads; activities of ice cream trucks on roadways. 
    The provisions of chapter 2-19 subsections 2-19-21 through 2-19-24 of Ordinance No. 07-74 of Manatee County, Florida, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in this section as if fully set forth herein. A copy of said sections is attached to Ordinance No. 2880. 
    Regulations contained herein shall be applicable to all roads within the City of Bradenton, designated as public roads, including surfaces paved and maintained for vehicular travel along with any curb or medium associated with such roads. 
    Ordinance No. 2880 shall apply throughout the City limits of the City of Bradenton. 
    No ice cream truck operator shall undertake any vending activities unless and until such ice cream truck has obtained an operative permit from the Manatee County Administrator or his designee pursuant to Manatee County Ordinance No. 07-74, effective April 1, 2008. 
    Any violation of any provision of this section shall be punishable upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 60 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the criminal penalties provided herein, the city may institute any appropriate any civil action or proceeding, including injunctive relief, as may be deemed necessary in order to prevent or abate future violations of this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2880, §§ 2, 3, 10-24-07) 
Sec. 62-59. - Private roads. 
(1)  Intent. 
a.  It is the intent of this section to regulate the construction, maintenance and use of new and existing private roads within the city; the use thereof by traffic; the administration and enforcement thereof; to set fees to defray administrative and enforcement costs incident thereto; to provide procedures for review and appeal; establish the policy required for the dedication of private roads to public ownership, and to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare. It is further the purpose of this section to ensure that private roads are maintained by the private property owners who own and use the road. 
b.  The city council hereby finds that unobstructed, safe, continuous access to lots and parcels of real estate is necessary to promote and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public through emergency, police and fire services. The city council further finds that such access is necessary to insure that such services can safely and quickly enter and exit private property at all times and access to the interior of various sections within Bradenton should be promoted through the orderly development of the city. Such access should meet minimum standards and specifications to permit the subsequent upgrading and dedication of such access rights-of-way by the city when public dedication is desirable or required. The procedures, standards, and specifications hereinafter set forth are determined to be the minimum procedures, standards, and specifications necessary to meet the intent of this section. 
(2)  Scope of section. The provisions of this private road section apply to the creation, construction, extension, improvement, maintenance, and public dedication of private roads. 
(3)  Definitions. 
a.  Applicant -A person who holds a legal interest in land and who submits an application seeking approval for a private road on the land. 
b.  As-built drawings -Approved private road drawings that are revised to show actual constructed locations and elevations of road and any utility structures and inverts, signed and sealed by a professional engineer or surveyor licensed in the state. 
c.  Easement -The right of an owner of property by reason of such ownership, to use the property of another for purposes of ingress, egress, utilities, drainage, and similar uses. In the context of this section, private road easements shall be designated for purpose of vehicle ingress and egress. 
d.
