    Cross-connection shall mean any physical arrangement whereby a public potable water supply or reclaimed water supply is connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device which contains or may contain contaminated water, sewage or other waste, or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public potable water supply or reclaimed water supply as the result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeable devices, and other temporary or permanent devices through which or because of which backflow could occur are considered to be cross-connections. 
    Customer shall mean the owner(s) of the property being served, as recorded on the county ad valorem tax rolls. 
    Delivery points shall mean the points of connection of the city's reclaimed water system to the user's system. 
    Department shall mean the City of Bradenton Department of Public Works. 
    Director shall mean the director of the city's department of public works or his/her designated representative(s). 
    Distribution mains shall mean those conduits used to supply reclaimed water to service lines. 
    FDEP shall mean the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. 
    Initial Users shall mean: 
(1)  Mixon Fruit Farms, Inc. 
(2)  Tropicana Products, Inc. 
(3)  Carl and Dora Shepard 
(4)  Coastal Power Company, its Successors and Assigns. 
    Irrigation system shall mean an underground system with permanently placed sprinkler devices or below-ground hose bibbs contained in a locked valve box. Above-ground hose bibbs (faucets) with hoses and sprinklers shall not constitute an irrigation system. Irrigation systems also include agricultural ditch and swale type systems and other conventional agricultural systems where applicable and as authorized by the director. 
    Reclaimed water shall mean water that has received at least advanced secondary treatment and basic disinfection and is reused after flowing out of a wastewater treatment facility. 
    Reuse shall mean the deliberate application of reclaimed water, in compliance with Florida Department of Environmental Protection and Southwest Florida Water Management District rules, for a beneficial purpose. 
    Service line shall mean that conduit for reclaimed water from the distribution main to the property line. 
    Setback distances shall mean the setback distances between the wetted site area subject to land application of reclaimed water, and surface waters and potable water supply wells, as required by the provisions of Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code, Rule 62-610.471. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-222. - Connection to system. 
    Customers in designated service areas may connect to the reclaimed water system when service is available and upon submission of a proper application and compliance with all other city requirements. Service to subdivisions and multi-family complexes will be considered upon receipt by the city of a petition signed by at least 50 percent of the residents in said subdivision or complex or as otherwise directed by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-223. - Authority to adopt rates, fees and charges. 
(a)  The council shall have the authority by resolution duly adopted after a public meeting, to establish rates, fees and charges for the reclaimed water system and to provide terms and conditions for the payment and collection of same. 
(b)  In addition to the regular charges for reclaimed water services supplied inside the city, there shall be added a surcharge equal to 25 percent of the rate charged for reclaimed water supplied outside of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-224. - Discontinuing service by city. 
    The city may discontinue reclaimed water service to any customer due to a violation of the terms of this article or any other city regulation, non-payment of bills, tampering with any service, plumbing of cross-connections with another water source, change in land use, or the undertaking of any other activity that may be detrimental to the system. The city has the right to cease service until the condition is corrected and all costs due the city are paid. These costs may include delinquent billings, connection charges, and payment for any damage caused to the system. Should discontinued service be restored without authorization, then the department shall remove the service and make such additional charges as are established by resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-225. - Interruption of service by city. 
    The city reserves the right to temporarily discontinue service to any portion of, or the entire reclaimed water system, as deemed necessary by the director. The director shall have the authority to establish schedules which restrict the use of the reclaimed water system at certain times in order to reduce maximum demands on the system and to regulate usage during periods of limited reclaimed water availability. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-226. - Easement dedications. 
    An applicant for reclaimed water service to a site which does not have public access shall dedicate land or shall grant perpetual easements to the city for reclaimed water distribution facilities as required to provide reclaimed water service. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-227. - Permits. 
    The city shall obtain and fulfill, at its expense, all necessary permits and approvals for the construction and operation of the reclaimed water distribution facilities constituting the city's reclaimed water system. Once service is available, any additional permits or approvals required for service to any particular customer, for the customer's benefit, shall be obtained at the sole expense of said customer. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-228. - Priorities for extending reclaimed water service. 
    The department shall determine priorities for reclaimed water distribution pipelines and their extensions. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-229. - Potable water wells. 
    As mandated by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, the city shall not provide reclaimed water service to sites where wells are used as a source of potable water, and where setback requirements cannot be maintained. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city to install a well intended for use as a potable water supply within the setback requirements of existing or known proposed reuse sites. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-230. - Right to service. 
    No payment of any costs, submittal of any application or petition, or undertaking of any other act to receive reclaimed water service shall guarantee such service. The city shall have the right, at all times, to refuse to extend service on the basis of a use detrimental to the system, inadequate supply of reclaimed water, lack of payment of required fees, or for any other reason which, in the judgement of the director, will cause the extension not to be beneficial to the city. 
Sec. 70-231. - Service outside the city. 
    Reclaimed water service may be provided to properties located outside the corporate limits of the city within the county. Such service will be extended on an actual cost basis and may include service to a governmental unit. All applications for service outside the city shall be reviewed by the department and such service shall be approved only if an adequate supply of reclaimed water is and will be available to meet all anticipated needs. The director shall review and approve all service line sizes and all other necessary design components. In any event, final approval of reclaimed water service outside the corporate limits of the city must be approved, in open session, by the council. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-232. - Service application requirements. 
(a)  Reclaimed water service shall be applied for in the department by completing and signing an application form. 
(b)  Applications for all reclaimed water services within any city, county or state maintained rights-of-way shall include a dimensional plan showing the location of the requested service line relative to the nearest street intersection, etc., as required by the city, the county or the state department of transportation. 
(c)  Before an application for reclaimed water service will be approved, the customer must have a suitable irrigation system or suitable reclaimed water piping system for other authorized uses. An irrigation system to be provided by the customer shall consist of an underground system with permanently placed sprinkler devices or below-ground hose bibbs contained in a locked valve box. No system for irrigation or other authorized uses with a cross-connection to the potable water system will be considered for connection to the reclaimed water system. Temporary systems will not be considered for connection. The systems shall not include above-ground faucets or other devices or connections that could permit reclaimed water to be used for any purpose other than irrigation or other authorized uses, unless such uses and systems have been approved in writing by the director. 
(d)  All new irrigation systems or reclaimed water piping system constructed in areas where the city has determined to make reclaimed water available shall be constructed in accordance with Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code. The customer shall provide the city with an irrigation system plan or reclaimed water piping system plan consisting of a schematic drawing of the irrigation or reclaimed water piping system before receiving service. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-233. - Meter requirements. 
    All reclaimed water users shall be required to utilize an appropriate sized flowmeter. All meters for the reclaimed water system will be installed and owned by the city. An estimate for the installation cost (including cost of the meter) will be prepared by the department and submitted to the applicant for payment prior to installation. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-234. - Cross-connection control. 
(a)  In all premises where reclaimed water service is provided, the public or private potable water supply shall be protected by an approved backflow prevention device. All devices and material installed for backflow prevention must comply with FDEP criteria and be approved by the city. Where any cross-connection is found, it shall be disconnected. Before reconnection of that service, the public potable water system shall be protected against the possibility of future cross-connections, and additional devices may be required as specified by the director and installed at the customer's expense. 
(b)  To determine the presence of any potential hazards to the public potable water system and for the purposes of perpetual maintenance and repair of reclaimed water system appurtenances, the city shall have the right to enter upon the premises of any customer receiving reclaimed water. Each customer of reclaimed water service shall, by application, give written consent to such entry upon his/her/its premises. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-235. - Construction specifications. 
(a)  Pipe, including color and labeling, shall meet or exceed standards set by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection and standards of the American Waterworks Association. 
(b)  Mains in the public rights-of-way shall be located a uniform distance from the curb and the location shall be approved by the director. 
(c)  Vertical and horizontal clearances from potable water lines and sewage collection lines shall be as specified in the applicable Florida Department of Environmental Protection rules. 
(d)  All valves and outlets shall be placed in appropriately tagged or labeled to warn the public and employees that the water is not intended for drinking. 
(e)  Where irrigation mains are to be turned over to the city, the customer shall submit such documents as are normally required for the dedication of public facilities. 
(f)  "As-built" drawings shall be submitted to the department upon completion of the irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-236. - Maintenance by the customer. 
    The customer shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of all irrigation lines, reclaimed water pipes and appurtenances on his/her/its property, unless said facilities are located within land previously dedicated to the city or land in which the city has been issued a license or permit to operate said facilities. The city reserves the right to disconnect the service to any property when the irrigation system, reclaimed water pipes and appurtenances are not properly maintained or fail to meet the requirements of Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code. In addition, should the customer require reclaimed water at difference pressures, or different quality, or in any way different from that normally supplied by the city, he/she/it shall be responsible for the necessary devices to make these adjustments and for obtaining the approval of the director. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-237. - Maintenance by the city. 
(a)  All facilities that have been accepted by the city shall become the property of the city and will be operated, maintained and repaired by the city. No person shall perform any work nor be reimbursed for any work on the system unless written authorization from the city is received prior to the work being accomplished. 
(b)  The city shall make a reasonable effort to inspect and keep its facilities in good repair, but assumes no liability for any damage caused by the system that is beyond the control of normal maintenance or due to situations not previously reported to the department. This shall include damage due to breaking of the pipes, poor quality of water caused by unauthorized or illegal entry of foreign material into the system, faulty operation of fire protection facilities, or other reasons. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-238. - Common service lines. 
    The director shall have the authority to approve one service line to connect two or more customers when sufficient capacity is available. In these cases, each customer shall each pay the full connection charge. Common service lines will be sized to provide adequate service to each customer serviced. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-239. - Public easement. 
    For reclaimed water lines and appurtenances which are initially installed by a person or entity other than the city, said lines and appurtenances shall not be accepted by the city for maintenance unless the facilities are within a dedicated public right-of-way or easement and the facilities are determined by the director to be in good working order. Any new easement or licensed or permitted area shall be adequately sized to accommodate construction and maintenance of any reclaimed water system component. No obstruction of whatever kind shall be planted, built, or otherwise created within the limits of the easement, right-of-way or licensed or permitted area without the written permission of the director. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-240. - Ownership by city. 
    All reclaimed water facilities and appurtenances within dedicated public rights-of-way or easements when constructed or accepted by the city shall become and remain the property of the city. No applicant or customer shall by payment of any charges provided herein, or by causing any construction of facilities accepted by the city, acquire any interest or right in any of these facilities or any portion thereof, other than the privilege of having his/her/its property connected thereto for reclaimed water service in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-241. - Appeals to the council. 
    Any refusal by the director to grant service to an applicant, or any other decision made by the director pursuant to this article, shall be appealable to the council, in open session, for a final and binding decision. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-242. - Adoption of Chapter 62-610, FAC. 
    The rules and regulations appearing in Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code, as may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted by reference as though fully set forth within this article. In the event of any variation between the provisions of Chapter 62-610, FAC, and the provisions of this article, the more strict provision shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-243. - Transfer of reclaimed water. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person or entity to sell, barter, trade or otherwise transfer reclaimed water to any other person or entity, after having initially received said reclaimed water from the city, without written authorization from the director. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Sec. 70-244. - Applicability to initial users. 
    It is not the legislative intent of the council to, by the enactment of this article, vitiate, invalidate or otherwise render ineffective any term, provision or condition of any Reclaimed Water Supply Contract entered into between the city and any initial user herein identified prior to the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2679, § 1, 4-24-02) 
Chapter 74 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-291 et seq.; occupational licenses, § 66-176 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC CONVEYANCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the area within the incorporated city limits. 
    Exempt vehicles shall be: 
(1)  Motor vehicles used exclusively for transporting children to and from school. 
(2)  Hearses and ambulances when operated by licensed embalmers, morticians, or ambulance service companies or their agents or employees in this state. 
(3)  Motor vehicles operated by a governmental agency. 
(4)  Public conveyances whose sole business is transporting passengers to and/or from airports located outside the city limits of Bradenton. 
    Operator means any person owning, leasing or controlling any taxicab or vehicle for hire; an operator may or may not be a driver. 
    Operator's permit means the city occupational license. 
    Public conveyance means any motor or other vehicle, by whatever name called, which is held out to the general public for and is used or operated for the purpose of transporting passengers for any fee, hire, or compensation in the city limits, except exempt vehicles. This shall apply only to public conveyances which pick up passengers within the city limits of Bradenton. 
    Taxicab means any public conveyance of nine passengers or less, including the driver, which is engaged in the transportation of persons for compensation on occasional trips not on a regular schedule or between terminals or over regular routes. Taxicabs shall be equipped with a taximeter as described in section 74-33. 
    Vehicles for hire means any public conveyance other than a taxicab, and shall not be equipped with a taximeter as described in section 74-33. Vehicles for hire may not solicit business at a taxistand or other location, but may operate only on a prearranged trip basis. 
(Code 1971, § 25-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-32. - Limitation on number of permits; transfers. 
    In order to avoid traffic congestion and ensure safe and adequate service to the public, it is hereby deemed to be in the best public interest that the city may, by majority action of its city council, limit the number of permits issued for taxicabs and vehicles for hire. In the event of such limitations, the holder of any such permit for taxicab or vehicle for hire may assign the permit to anyone otherwise qualified therefor under the terms of this article, however, a nonrefundable transfer fee shall be first required for each permit. The transfer fee shall be established by city council resolution in an amount which accurately reflects the administrative costs involved. 
(Code 1971, § 25-17) 
Sec. 74-33. - Taxicab meters required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any taxicab within the city unless the taxicab is equipped with a taximeter of such a type and design as will properly and accurately compute and display on its face the charge for the distance traveled and the waiting time. The operation of any taxicab with a taximeter which is defective or which does not properly and accurately compute and display on its face the charge for distance traveled or the charge for waiting time shall constitute a violation of this article. The taximeter shall be inspected and certified by the state department of weights and measures or such other governmental agency empowered and equipped to measure the accuracy of such devices each time a periodic inspection of the vehicle is required and at such other times as may be deemed necessary by the city clerk and treasurer or his designee. All taximeters shall be placed in such a position in the taxicab that the face thereof and the fare numerals may be easily seen and read by a passenger sitting in any part of the taxicab. Taximeters used between sunset and sunrise shall be illuminated by a light so arranged as to throw a continuous light thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 25-18) 
Sec. 74-34. - Posting of rates. 
(a)  Each operator shall have posted inside his taxicab, in a conspicuous place, the detailed tariff charged or to be charged for transportation within the city limits. This tariff shall be printed in a size easily readable by persons sitting in the rear seat of the public conveyance and shall conform to and be an exact duplicate of the tariff filed with the city clerk and treasurer as required by this article. 
(b)  Each owner of a taxicab or vehicle for hire holding a permit for operation of such vehicle, pursuant to this article, shall maintain on file with the city clerk and treasurer a schedule of fares, rates and charges for such vehicle. 
(c)  The operator shall have his name plainly printed or painted on the tariff posted on the inside of his motor vehicle and shall also state whether he is the owner or lessee of the vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 25-19) 
Sec. 74-35. - Charges to be in accordance with posted tariffs. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any public conveyance to charge more than the fares shown and disclosed by the tariff or schedule of rates then on file with the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1971, § 25-20) 
Sec. 74-36. - Information to be placed on sides of taxicab. 
    All taxicabs operated subject to this article shall have placed on both sides of the exterior of the taxicab, the name of the taxicab company or association. Each taxicab shall also be identified by a company or association number which shall be placed on both sides of the exterior of the taxicab in a conspicuous location. The letters and numbers shall be placed in a color contrasting to that of the taxicab and shall not be less than three inches in height. All exterior lettering and numbering required by this article shall remain legible and be visible from a distance of not less than 50 feet. 
(Code 1971, § 25-21) 
Sec. 74-37. - Prohibited conduct of drivers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab or vehicle for hire to: 
(1)  Fail to perform any act required by this article to be performed; 
(2)  Violate any of the terms, provisions or directions of this article; 
(3)  Fail to keep a written record of all trips, which record shall give information as to the time of each trip, the starting and ending point of each trip, together with the number of persons carried. The report shall be available to the inspection of the city clerk and treasurer or his designee and shall be kept available for a period of not less than six months; 
(4)  Fail to report promptly all motor vehicle accidents to the police department; 
(5)  Fail to report within 24 hours to the city clerk and treasurer any change of address; 
(6)  Operate any public conveyance when his driver's permit required by this article has been revoked or during the time when his driver's permit is suspended; 
(7)  Permit any other person to use his driver's permit issued pursuant to this article or any other identification; 
(8)  Fail to give a receipt for fares when requested by a passenger; 
(9)  Operate a public conveyance for more than 12 hours of any continuous 24-hour period; 
(10)  Possess in any public conveyance alcoholic beverages in conflict with state statutes; 
(11)  Possess or transport or at any time suffer, permit or allow any person to use the public conveyance he is operating for the purpose of transporting and/or possessing any unlawful controlled substance; or 
(12)  Knowingly transport or at any time suffer, permit or allow any person to use the public conveyance he is operating for the purpose of conducting illegal or criminal activities. 
(Code 1971, § 25-22) 
Sec. 74-38. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The city clerk and treasurer shall have the power and authority to make such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this article and to make such other rules and regulations as he may deem proper for the regulation of public conveyances that shall not be inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 25-23) 
Sec. 74-39. - Compliance with article prerequisite to operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator to allow, suffer or permit to be operated upon the public streets of the city any public conveyance until the operator shall have first performed all of the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 25-24) 
Sec. 74-40. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, operator or driver of any public conveyance to violate any of the terms, provisions or directions of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 25-25) 
Sec. 74-41. - Minimum standards for taxicabs and vehicles for hire. 
    In addition to the standards and requirements otherwise applicable through this article, all taxicabs and vehicles for hire and owners, operators and drivers thereof shall comply with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Taxicabs: 
a.  Installed exterior side view mirrors on the lefthand and righthand sides of the vehicle and an installed interior rearview mirror. 
b.  Speedometer properly installed, in good working order and exposed to view. 
c.  Interior clean, sanitary and free from torn upholstery or floor coverings and from damaged or broken seats. 
d.  All door hinges and interior and exterior door latches and handles in good mechanical working order and operating easily and closing securely. All doors shall have operative handles on the interior and exterior of the public conveyance. 
e.  Vehicle structurally sound and operating with a minimum of noise and vibration. 
f.  The body, fenders, doors, trim and grill reasonably free from cracks, breaks and dents that would impair the safety or appearance of the vehicle. 
g.  Vision unobstructed on all four sides. 
h.  Permit and license properly displayed. 
i.  Two-way radio installed and operating properly with access to or affiliated with a central dispatch facility. 
j.  All public conveyances shall be mechanically sound, including, but not limited to, properly operating brakes, interior and exterior lights, horn, windshield wipers and exhaust systems. 
k.  All operators shall supply the city with a notarized statement from the applicant's mechanic or from a factory authorized garage or a mechanic accepted by the city, certifying that the vehicle or vehicles meet the minimum requirements of this article. 
(2)  Vehicles for hire: 
a.  Installed exterior side view mirrors on the lefthand and righthand sides of the vehicles and an installed interior rearview mirror. 
b.  Speedometer properly installed, in good working order and exposed to view. 
c.  Interior clean, sanitary and free from torn upholstery or floor coverings and from damaged or broken seats. 
d.  All door hinges and interior and exterior door latches in good mechanical working order and operating easily and closing securely. 
e.  Vehicle structurally sound and operating with a minimum of noise and vibration. 
f.  The body, fenders, doors, trim and grill reasonably free from cracks, breaks and dents that would impair the safety or appearance of the vehicle. 
g.  Vision unobstructed on all four sides. 
h.  Permit and license properly displayed. 
i.  Comply at all times with the liability insurance requirements set forth in this article. 
j.  All public conveyances shall be mechanically sound, including, but not limited to, properly operating brakes, interior and exterior lights, horn, windshield wipers and exhaust systems. 
(Code 1971, § 25-26) 
Sec. 74-42. - Refusal to pay fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain the use of a vehicle for hire or taxicab with the intent to defraud by not paying the owner or operator of the vehicle for the use thereof. 
(Code 1971, § 25-27) 
Secs. 74-43-74-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATOR'S PERMIT 

Sec. 74-61. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, lease, control or drive a public conveyance requiring a permit under the terms of this article and drive on the public streets of the city or dispatched for hire on the public streets of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor as prescribed in this division, and in the case of a driver who is not the operator, without such permit having first been obtained by the operator. Such permits shall be obtained annually. 
(Code 1971, § 25-28) 
Sec. 74-62. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by this division shall make application therefor to the city clerk and treasurer on application blanks to be supplied by the city clerk and treasurer. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The owner of the vehicle(s) and, if not owned by the applicant, from whom the vehicle(s) is/are leased or rented. 
(2)  The make, model, year of manufacture and vehicle identification number of the vehicle(s) and the seating capacity thereof. 
(3)  The state license number of the vehicle(s). 
(4)  If the owner of the vehicle(s) is a corporation, the names and residences of the officers thereof. 
(5)  If the owner of the vehicle(s) is a partnership, the names and residences of each partner. 
(6)  A detailed tariff schedule to be charged for the vehicle(s). 
(7)  Whether the vehicle(s) is/are to be operated as a taxicab or vehicle for hire. 
(Code 1971, § 25-29) 
Sec. 74-63. - Prerequisite to issuance of permit for taxicabs and vehicles for hire. 
    Before a permit required by this division shall be issued by the city clerk and treasurer the operator of a taxicab and/or vehicle for hire shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  Pay to the city the occupational license fee required by section 66-187. 
(2)  For each vehicle operated, file with the city clerk and treasurer a policy of insurance in a solvent company authorized to do business in the state, the cost of such policy to be the responsibility of the applicant. The coverage contained in the policy shall be the greater of: 
a.  The amounts of coverage required by the state; or 
b.  That amount set by city council resolution. 
(3)  Obtain approval from the city council for the operation of a taxicab and/or vehicle for hire business. 
(Code 1971, § 25-30) 
Sec. 74-64. - Issuance. 
    After the applicant for a permit required by this division shall have complied with the prerequisites to the permit, the city clerk and treasurer may issue to the applicant the permit sought. The city may require an investigation to be made by the city police department or other law enforcement agency of the operator and/or applicant. 
(Code 1971, § 25-31) 
Sec. 74-65. - Term of permit. 
    A permit issued pursuant to this division shall conform to the fiscal year of the city and shall expire on September 30 following its issuance. Permits issued after March 31 shall be issued for the remainder of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1971, § 25-32) 
Sec. 74-66. - Notice of substitution of vehicle. 
    The occupational license division of the city shall be notified of any change or replacement of vehicles prior to placing a vehicle in operation on the city streets. 
(Code 1971, § 25-33) 
Sec. 74-67. - Revocation and suspension; appeals. 
(a)  The city clerk and treasurer shall have full power and authority to revoke a permit issued pursuant to this division if it shall be known before him that the operator has been guilty of or has permitted, suffered or allowed the violation of any of the provisions of this article or of any other ordinance of the city. 
(b)  Upon the cancellation or lapse of any insurance required under the provisions of this division, the permit issued to a person pursuant to this division shall be immediately revoked unless the person, prior to the expiration date of the policy of insurance, shall have obtained another policy of insurance containing all the requirements of the original policy of insurance. However, the holder of a permit may make application to the city clerk and treasurer for voluntary suspension of his permit for a term not to exceed six months and not to extend beyond the permit term. The city clerk and treasurer, in granting a voluntary suspension of a permit, shall require the holder to surrender possession of the permit to him, but the surrender of the possession of the permit shall not be construed to be a cancellation thereof unless the holder of the permit shall fail to file with the city clerk and treasurer a policy of insurance before the expiration date of the suspension period. During the suspension period it shall be unlawful for the person to operate a public conveyance upon the streets of the city in any capacity whatsoever. During the time of a voluntary suspension of a permit, the operator shall not be required to maintain the policy of insurance as required by this division; however, should the operator of any public conveyance who shall obtain a voluntary suspension of his permit fail to file with the city clerk and treasurer the policy of insurance required by this division before the expiration of the period of voluntary suspension of his permit, the permit shall, upon the expiration of the voluntary suspension period, be immediately revoked. 
(c)  Prior to making any revocation, the city clerk and treasurer shall give the permit holder five business days' notice of his intent to revoke the permit. Such notice of intent shall contain a statement of the grounds of revocation. Statement of such grounds shall not preclude the city clerk and treasurer from adding additional grounds as the city clerk and treasurer becomes aware of them. The permit holder, upon receipt of such notice, may request the city clerk and treasurer grant him a hearing in order to rebut the grounds stated in the notice and the city clerk and treasurer shall grant such hearing within ten days of receipt of the request or at some other time, as such time can be mutually agreed upon by the city clerk and treasurer and the permit holder. 
(d)  After the city clerk and treasurer issues any final revocation of a permit, the permit holder shall have the right to appeal such revocation to the city council by notice of such appeal filed with the city clerk and treasurer within 15 days of the revocation. The appeal shall be heard at the second regularly held council meeting occurring after receipt of the notice of appeal. 
(e)  All hearings and appellate and appeal procedures shall be informal but compatible with the requirements of justice and due process. 
(Code 1971, § 25-34) 
Secs. 74-68-74-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 

Sec. 74-86. - Required. 
    No person shall physically operate or drive any public conveyance over and upon the streets of the city unless he shall first have obtained from the city clerk and treasurer a permit to drive a public conveyance. 
(Code 1971, § 25-35) 
Sec. 74-87. - Application. 
(a)  Each applicant for a permit required by this division shall make application to the city clerk and treasurer on forms to be provided by the city clerk and treasurer or his designee, which application shall contain the information required by the city clerk and treasurer. The applicant shall furnish all the information required by the application as well as a nonrefundable processing fee as established by city council resolution in an amount which accurately reflects the administrative costs involved. 
(b)  Each applicant for a driver's permit under this division shall provide proof that: 
(1)  He is a Florida resident. 
(2)  He is 18 years of age or older. 
(3)  He possesses a valid applicable Florida driver's license. 
(c)  Each applicant for a driver's permit under this division shall file with his application two photographs of himself of a size designated by the city clerk and treasurer or his designee, which photographs shall be a good likeness of such applicant and shall have been taken within 30 days next preceding the date of the application. 
(d)  The police department shall take the fingerprints of each applicant for a permit under this division and shall retain a copy of them and return the originals to the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1971, § 25-36) 
Sec. 74-88. - Investigation of applicant. 
(a)  Upon the filing of the application required by this division, the city clerk and treasurer or his designee shall cause the applicant to be investigated. If the results of the investigation reveal one or more of the following, then the applicant shall be denied a permit. 
(1)  Conviction within the past five years of any felony. 
(2)  Conviction within the past three years of a misdemeanor involving a violation of the Florida Drug Abuse and Control Act. 
(3)  Conviction within the past three years of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of drugs or alcohol or with an unlawful blood alcohol level. 
(4)  A finding of guilt or a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere to a felony or misdemeanor or ordinance violation, any of which involve moral turpitude, or to any of the offenses listed in section (a)(2) or (3) of this section within the past three years, or five years if a felony. "Moral turpitude" shall be as defined by statutes, case law or ordinance. This applies notwithstanding suspension of sentence or withholding of adjudication or sentencing. 
(5)  Submission of false or materially misleading statements in his application. 
(6)  On parole at the time of application. 
(7)  Proof of physical or mental incapacity to safely operate a public conveyance or any other cause or reason why the applicant should not be permitted to operate or drive a public conveyance. 
(b)  If an applicant for a permit under this division has been arrested prior to or subsequent to the submission of his initial application or application for renewal, such application shall be held in abeyance until a prosecutorial decision or a judicial determination has been rendered. 
(Code 1971, § 25-37) 
Sec. 74-89. - Issuance. 
    All applicants for a driver's permit under this division must pay a nonrefundable processing fee as established by city council resolution in an amount which accurately reflects the administrative costs involved. Upon the satisfactory fulfillment of the requirements of this division and with the approval of the city clerk and treasurer or his designee, there shall be issued to the applicant therefor the permit required by this division. 
(Code 1971, § 25-38) 
Sec. 74-90. - Processing fee; term of permit; renewal. 
    All applicants for permits under this division must pay a nonrefundable processing fee as established by city council resolution in an amount which accurately reflects the administrative costs involved. All permits issued pursuant to this division shall conform to the fiscal year of the city and shall expire on September 30 following their issuance; however, permits issued during the months of August and September shall expire on September 30 of the year next following their issuance. Permits may be renewable from year to year upon the approval of the city clerk and treasurer or his designee following an investigation of the applicant. 
(Code 1971, § 25-39) 
Sec. 74-91. - Photo identification card; display. 
    Upon issuance of a permit required by this division, the driver shall obtain a photo identification card from the city clerk and treasurer or his designee. It shall be unlawful for a driver to drive any public conveyance unless at all times when driving or soliciting to drive, the photo identification card or other identification, as required by the city, is in full and plain view. 
(Code 1971, § 25-40) 
Sec. 74-92. - Revocation or suspension; appeals. 
(a)  Any permit issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the city clerk and treasurer or his designee upon satisfactory proof that the driver has been found guilty of any violation of this Code or has been guilty of conduct that disqualifies the driver as a driver of public conveyances. 
(b)  Upon conviction of the driver of any public conveyance for a violation of this article or any criminal traffic offense, the appropriate state court having jurisdiction may, in addition to the other penalties imposed by it, revoke or suspend the driver's permit issued pursuant to this division. The revocation or suspension shall be reported by the court to the city clerk and treasurer or his police department designee. 
(c)  Whenever a permit issued pursuant to this division shall be revoked, either by the city clerk and treasurer, his designee or a court, or where the permit shall be suspended, the city clerk and treasurer shall immediately require the driver to surrender the badge issued pursuant to this division. It shall be unlawful for any driver to fail or refuse to surrender his permit to the city clerk and treasurer or his designee upon notice that such permit has been revoked or suspended. 
(d)  Prior to making any revocation, the city clerk and treasurer shall give the permit holder five business days' notice of his intent to revoke the permit. Such notice of intent shall contain a statement of the grounds of revocation. Statement of such grounds shall not preclude the city clerk and treasurer from adding additional grounds as the city clerk and treasurer becomes aware of them. The permit holder, upon receipt of such notice, may request the city clerk and treasurer grant him a hearing in order to rebut the grounds stated in the notice, and the city clerk and treasurer shall grant such hearing within ten days of receipt of the request or at some other time, as such time can be mutually agreed upon by the city clerk and treasurer and the permit holder. 
(e)  After the city clerk and treasurer issues any final revocation of a permit, the permit holder shall have the right to appeal such revocation to the city council by notice of such appeal filed with the city clerk and treasurer within 15 days of the revocation. The appeal shall be heard at the second regularly held council meeting occurring after receipt of the notice of appeal. 
(f)  All hearings and appellate and appeal procedures shall be informal but compatible with the requirements of justice and due process. 
(Code 1971, § 25-41) 
Sec. 74-93. - Temporary driver's permit. 
    The city clerk and treasurer or his designee may issue a temporary driver's permit. In addition to the processing requirements of this division, i.e., photographs, fingerprints, etc., the following conditions must be met: 
(1)  Insurance coverage. The applicant must present proof of insurance pursuant to the requirements of section 74-63 of this article. 
(2)  Driver's license record check. As a condition precedent to the issuance of a temporary driver's permit, the police department shall conduct a state check of the applicant's driver's license record. Approval or denial of the issuance of a temporary driver's permit shall be made in accordance with the criteria in section 74-88. 
(3)  Local criminal record check. As a condition precedent to the issuance of a temporary driver's permit, the police department shall conduct a local record check to ascertain the criminal background of the applicant. Approval or denial of the issuance of a temporary driver's permit shall be made in accordance with the criteria of section 74-88. 
(4)  Duration of temporary driver's permit. The temporary driver's permit shall be valid only until the annual permit is issued. As outlined in section 74-88, a complete investigation shall be conducted forthwith. Should the results of the complete investigation reveal one or more of the items in section 74-88(1) through (3), then the temporary permit shall be immediately revoked. 
(5)  Definition. For purposes of this section, "local criminal record check" refers to those records and files which are readily accessible to, or which are located at, the city police department. 
(Code 1971, § 25-42) 
PART III - LAND USE REGULATIONS[1]
